Her maximum <fact5>temperature was 102°F (38.9°C)</fact5> taken the night before presentation. Her past medical history is notable for <fact6>major depressive disorder, obesity, fibromyalgia, and severe tension headaches</fact6>. She previously took <fact7>paroxetine</fact7> for a <fact8>2-month trial</fact8> but switched to <fact9>citalopram 6 months ago</fact9> as she did not feel like <fact7>paroxetine</fact7> was adequately helping her symptoms. Her mood has been stable on her current dose of <fact9>citalopram</fact9>. She takes <fact10>ibuprofen</fact10> for her headaches but previously borrowed a friend’s headache medication when her headaches became very severe. Of note, she has been trying to lose weight and recently started taking an <fact11>amino acid supplement</fact11> at the suggestion of her nephew who is a nutritionist. She is also trying out a new <fact12>low-carbohydrate diet</fact12>. She works as a nurse at a local primary care clinic. Her <fact13>temperature is 101.5°F (38.6°C)</fact13>, <fact14>blood pressure is 144/80 mmHg</fact14>, <fact15>pulse is 108/min</fact15>, and <fact16>respirations are 22/min</fact16>. She is <fact17>diaphoretic and shivering</fact17>. <fact18>Patellar and brachioradialis reflexes are 3+ bilaterally</fact18>. <fact19>Tone is increased in her bilateral upper and lower extremities</fact19>. Rapid dorsiflexion of her right ankle elicits <fact20>3 beats of clonus</fact20>. <fact21>Pupils are equally round and reactive to light</fact21>. A <fact22>basic metabolic panel is within normal limits</fact22>. Which of the following is the most likely inciting factor for this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>fever</fact2>, <fact3>malaise and diaphoresis</fact3>, <fact17>diaphoretic and shivering</fact17>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact18>hyperreflexia</fact18>, <fact19>increased tone in bilateral upper and lower extremities</fact19>, and <fact20>clonus</fact20>, it is suggestive of serotonin syndrome. The patient's recent start of an <fact11>amino acid supplement</fact11> is a potential contributing factor, but the key detail lies in her medication regimen. She has been stable on <fact9>citalopram</fact9> for <fact9>6 months</fact9>, but the mention of previously taking <fact7>paroxetine</fact7> and the fact that she <fact10>borrowed a friend's headache medication</fact10> indicates a possible recent change or addition to her medication regimen that could have led to an increase in serotonin levels. However, the most direct clue from the options provided points towards the <fact11>amino acid supplement</fact11> as a potential source of tryptophan, an amino acid that can increase serotonin production. Therefore, the most likely inciting factor for this patient's condition is {B}.

question:
An 11-month-old male infant is brought to his pediatrician by his mother. She is concerned about his leg and his inability to stand. He was born vaginally to a 33-year-old woman (gravida 3, para 2) from an uncomplicated pregnancy at 39 weeks. He has met all developmental milestones and is up to date on all vaccinations. His mother explains that he can normally stand without help and can walk briefly on his own. However, he hit his right leg against a chair 2 days ago. The area became edematous and bruised overtime and the infant became unable to stand or crawl and cries when he puts weight on it. The mother denies any child abuse from her family or child care. The patient’s vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg, heart rate 137/min, respiratory rate 25/min, and temperature 36.7°C (97.0°F). His length and weight are both between the 15th and 25th percentile. On physical examination, blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae are noted. Respiratory, cardiovascular, and abdominal examinations are within normal limits for his age. There is joint hypermobility and decreased tone in both upper and lower extremities. The patient’s right calf appears slightly deformed, edematous, and warm to the tough. The patient begins to cry loudly when the physician palpates his leg. The patient’s X-ray shows an incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?
A) Child abuse
B) Insufficient production of procollagen type 1
C) Mutation in the gene encoding fibrillin-1
D) Defective collagen type 3
E) Dysfunctional structure of laminins
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An <fact1>11-month-old male infant</fact1> is brought to his pediatrician by his mother. She is concerned about his leg and his inability to stand. He was born vaginally to a <fact2>33-year-old woman (gravida 3, para 2)</fact2> from an <fact3>uncomplicated pregnancy at 39 weeks</fact3>. He has met all <fact4>developmental milestones</fact4> and is up to date on all <fact5>vaccinations</fact5>. His mother explains that he can normally stand without help and can walk briefly on his own. However, he hit his right leg against a chair <fact6>2 days ago</fact6>. The area became <fact7>edematous and bruised overtime</fact7> and the infant became unable to stand or crawl and cries when he puts weight on it. The mother denies any <fact8>child abuse</fact8> from her family or child care. The patient’s <fact9>vital signs</fact9> are as follows: <fact10>blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg</fact10>, <fact11>heart rate 137/min</fact11>, <fact12>respiratory rate 25/min</fact12>, and <fact13>temperature 36.7°C (97.0°F)</fact13>. His <fact14>length and weight are both between the 15th and 25th percentile</fact14>. On physical examination, <fact15>blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae</fact15> are noted. <fact16>Respiratory, cardiovascular, and abdominal examinations</fact16> are within normal limits for his age. There is <fact17>joint hypermobility and decreased tone in both upper and lower extremities</fact17>. The patient’s right calf appears <fact18>slightly deformed, edematous, and warm to the touch</fact18>. The patient begins to cry loudly when the physician <fact19>palpates his leg</fact19>. The patient’s <fact20>X-ray shows an incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis</fact20>. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>11-month-old male infant</fact1> has met all <fact4>developmental milestones</fact4> and is up to date on all <fact5>vaccinations</fact5>, yet presents with an <fact20>incomplete fracture of the right tibial diaphysis</fact20> after a relatively minor trauma, along with <fact15>blue-grayish discoloration of the sclerae</fact15> and <fact17>joint hypermobility and decreased tone in both upper and lower extremities</fact17>, suggests an underlying condition affecting bone strength and connective tissue. The most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms is related to a genetic disorder affecting collagen production. Among the options provided, insufficient production of procollagen type 1 is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta, a condition characterized by brittle bones, blue sclerae, and joint hypermobility. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 41-year-old man comes to the emergency department with nausea, abdominal discomfort, and diarrhea for the past 2 days. His abdominal discomfort is worse shortly after meals. He has also had progressive perioral numbness and upper-extremity muscle cramping for the past 24 hours. Six months ago, he underwent a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass to treat obesity. He underwent a total thyroidectomy to treat a Hurthle cell lesion 4 days ago. His mother died of lung cancer at age 68. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years. His only current medication is a multivitamin supplement. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. While measuring the patient's blood pressure, the nurse observes spasm of the patient's hand. Physical examination shows a well-healing surgical wound on the neck. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation with well-healed laparoscopic incisional sites. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Na+ 138 mEq/L
K+ 4.2 mEq/L
Cl- 102 mEq/L
HCO3- 25 mEq/L
Mg2+ 1.7 mEq/L
Phosphorus 4.3 mg/dL
25-hydroxyvitamin D 20 ng/mL (N: 20-100 ng/mL)
Parathyroid hormone 115 pg/mL
Total bilirubin, serum 0.7 mg/dL
Alanine aminotransferase, serum 14 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase, serum 15 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase, serum 42 U/L
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?"
A) Obtain abdominal CT
B) Observation only
C) Begin rehydration therapy
D) Administer calcium gluconate
E) Supplementation with vitamin D
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>41-year-old man</fact1> comes to the emergency department with <fact2>nausea, abdominal discomfort, and diarrhea</fact2> for the past 2 days. His <fact3>abdominal discomfort is worse shortly after meals</fact3>. He has also had <fact4>progressive perioral numbness and upper-extremity muscle cramping</fact4> for the past 24 hours. Six months ago, he underwent a <fact5>Roux-en-Y gastric bypass</fact5> to treat obesity. He underwent a <fact6>total thyroidectomy</fact6> to treat a Hurthle cell lesion 4 days ago. His mother died of lung cancer at age 68. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years. His only current medication is a multivitamin supplement. He appears fatigued. His <fact7>temperature is 36°C (96.8°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 72/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 20/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg</fact10>. While measuring the patient's blood pressure, the nurse observes <fact11>spasm of the patient's hand</fact11>. Physical examination shows a well-healing surgical wound on the neck. The abdomen is mildly tender to palpation with well-healed laparoscopic incisional sites. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
<fact12>Na+ 138 mEq/L</fact12>
<fact13>K+ 4.2 mEq/L</fact13>
<fact14>Cl- 102 mEq/L</fact14>
<fact15>HCO3- 25 mEq/L</fact15>
<fact16>Mg2+ 1.7 mEq/L</fact16>
<fact17>Phosphorus 4.3 mg/dL</fact17>
<fact18>25-hydroxyvitamin D 20 ng/mL</fact18> (N: 20-100 ng/mL)
<fact19>Parathyroid hormone 115 pg/mL</fact19>
<fact20>Total bilirubin, serum 0.7 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Alanine aminotransferase, serum 14 U/L</fact21>
<fact22>Aspartate aminotransferase, serum 15 U/L</fact22>
<fact23>Alkaline phosphatase, serum 42 U/L</fact23>
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?

Answer:
Considering the patient's recent history of <fact6>total thyroidectomy</fact6> and symptoms of <fact2>nausea, abdominal discomfort, and diarrhea</fact2>, along with <fact4>progressive perioral numbness and upper-extremity muscle cramping</fact4>, it is essential to address potential hypocalcemia, especially given the <fact19>elevated parathyroid hormone level</fact19> in the context of post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia. The <fact11>spasm of the patient's hand</fact11> observed during blood pressure measurement further supports this concern. Among the provided options, the most appropriate initial step is to administer calcium gluconate to address the likely hypocalcemia. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 22-year-old woman with a history of asthma visits her physician for worsening shortness of breath. She states that she feels as though her “lungs are falling apart,” noting that her lung function has been steadily deteriorating. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of inhalers, but she feels that they have not helped her control her asthma exacerbations. She has experienced 4 episodes of pneumonia in the last 3 years and often suffers from “random” bouts of excessive coughing and wheezing. When asked if her coughing episodes produce sputum, she states, “Yes, the stuff is greenish with specks of red in it.” She also states that her coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs. The vital signs include: blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg, pulse 66/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the patient appears frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress. Auscultation reveals inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes. Chest radiograph, as shown below, reveals atelectasis in the right lung base. There are also branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows” (noted by the arrow in the image). Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?
A) Isoniazid
B) Fluconazole
C) Caspofungin
D) Prednisone
E) Surgical resection of the infiltrates
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> with a history of <fact2>asthma</fact2> visits her physician for worsening <fact3>shortness of breath</fact3>. She states that she feels as though her “lungs are falling apart,” noting that her <fact4>lung function has been steadily deteriorating</fact4>. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of <fact5>inhalers</fact5>, but she feels that they have not helped her control her <fact6>asthma exacerbations</fact6>. She has experienced <fact7>4 episodes of pneumonia in the last 3 years</fact7> and often suffers from “random” bouts of excessive <fact8>coughing and wheezing</fact8>. When asked if her <fact9>coughing episodes produce sputum</fact9>, she states, “Yes, the stuff is <fact10>greenish with specks of red in it</fact10>.” She also states that her <fact11>coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs</fact11>. The <fact12>vital signs</fact12> include: <fact13>blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg</fact13>, <fact14>pulse 66/min</fact14>, <fact15>respiratory rate 26/min</fact15>, and <fact16>temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact16>. On <fact17>physical exam</fact17>, the patient appears <fact18>frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress</fact18>. <fact19>Auscultation reveals inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes</fact19>. <fact20>Chest radiograph</fact20> reveals <fact21>atelectasis in the right lung base</fact21>. There are also <fact22>branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows”</fact22> (noted by the arrow in the image). <fact23>Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated</fact23>. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?

Answer:
Considering the patient's history of <fact2>asthma</fact2> and the presence of <fact22>branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows”</fact22> on the <fact20>chest radiograph</fact20>, which are indicative of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), the most appropriate therapy would be to manage the allergic response and reduce inflammation. Elevated <fact23>serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels</fact23> further support the diagnosis of ABPA. Given these factors, the most appropriate therapy is the use of systemic corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and manage symptoms. Therefore, the answer is {D} Prednisone.

question:
An 81-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his son to be evaluated for memory issues. The patient’s son says he has difficulty remembering recent events and names. He says the patient’s symptoms have progressively worsened over the last several years but became acutely worse just recently. Also, yesterday, the patient complained that he could not see out of his right eye, but today he can. When asked about these concerns, the patient seems to have no insight into the problem and reports feeling well. His medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension. He had a left basal ganglia hemorrhage 12 years ago and a right middle cerebral artery infarction 4 years ago. Current medications are amlodipine, aspirin, clopidogrel, metformin, sitagliptin, and valsartan. He lives with his son and can feed himself and change his clothes. There is no history of urinary or fecal incontinence. His vitals include: blood pressure 137/82 mm Hg, pulse 78/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical examination, the patient is alert and oriented. He is unable to perform simple arithmetic calculations and the mini-mental status exam is inconclusive. He can write his name and comprehend written instructions. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side. The tone is also slightly reduced on the right side with exaggerated reflexes. His gait is hemiparetic. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Alzheimer's disease
B) Frontotemporal dementia
C) Lewy body dementia
D) Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
E) Vascular dementia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An <fact1>81-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the clinic by his son to be evaluated for <fact2>memory issues</fact2>. The patient’s son says he has difficulty remembering <fact3>recent events and names</fact3>. He says the patient’s symptoms have <fact4>progressively worsened over the last several years</fact4> but became <fact5>acutely worse just recently</fact5>. Also, yesterday, the patient complained that he could not see out of his <fact6>right eye</fact6>, but today he can. When asked about these concerns, the patient seems to have no insight into the problem and reports feeling well. His medical history is significant for <fact7>diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension</fact7>. He had a <fact8>left basal ganglia hemorrhage 12 years ago</fact8> and a <fact9>right middle cerebral artery infarction 4 years ago</fact9>. Current medications are amlodipine, aspirin, clopidogrel, metformin, sitagliptin, and valsartan. He lives with his son and can feed himself and change his clothes. There is no history of urinary or fecal incontinence. His vitals include: blood pressure 137/82 mm Hg, pulse 78/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical examination, the patient is alert and oriented. He is unable to perform <fact10>simple arithmetic calculations</fact10> and the mini-mental status exam is inconclusive. He can write his name and comprehend written instructions. <fact11>Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side</fact11>. The tone is also slightly reduced on the right side with exaggerated reflexes. His gait is hemiparetic.

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>memory issues</fact2>, particularly difficulty remembering <fact3>recent events and names</fact3>, which have <fact4>progressively worsened over the last several years</fact4> and became <fact5>acutely worse just recently</fact5>, suggests a form of dementia. The patient's history of <fact7>diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension</fact7>, along with a <fact8>left basal ganglia hemorrhage 12 years ago</fact8> and a <fact9>right middle cerebral artery infarction 4 years ago</fact9>, points towards vascular factors contributing to his condition. The physical examination findings, including <fact11>muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side</fact11> and a hemiparetic gait, further support vascular involvement. Given these factors, the most likely diagnosis is vascular dementia, which is characterized by cognitive decline due to reduced blood flow to the brain, often as a result of a series of small strokes or changes in the brain's blood vessels. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 14-year-old obese boy presents with severe right hip and knee pain. The patient says that he has been limping with mild pain for the past three weeks, but the pain acutely worsened today. He describes the pain as severe, non-radiating, sharp and aching in character, and localized to the right hip and knee joints. The patient denies recent illness, travel, trauma, or similar symptoms in the past. No significant past medical history and no current medications. The patient is not sexually active and denies any alcohol, smoking or drug use. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 72/min, respiratory rate 15/min, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. The right leg is externally rotated, and there is a limited range of motion in the right hip. Strength is 4 out of 5 at the right hip joint and 5 out of 5 elsewhere. There is no tenderness to palpation. No joint erythema, edema or effusion present. Sensation is intact. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory tests are unremarkable. Plain radiographs of the right hip joint are significant for displacement of the right femoral head inferoposterior off the femoral neck. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of treatment for this patient?
A) Reassess in 3 months
B) Immobilize the right knee with conservative treatment (i.e. rest, ice)
C) Intra-articular corticosteroid injection of the right hip joint
D) Pavlik harness
E) Surgical pinning of the right hip
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>14-year-old obese boy</fact1> presents with severe <fact2>right hip and knee pain</fact2>. The patient says that he has been limping with mild pain for the past <fact3>three weeks</fact3>, but the pain acutely worsened today. He describes the pain as severe, non-radiating, sharp and aching in character, and localized to the <fact4>right hip and knee joints</fact4>. The patient denies recent illness, travel, trauma, or similar symptoms in the past. No significant past medical history and no current medications. The patient is not sexually active and denies any alcohol, smoking or drug use. The vital signs include: <fact5>temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact5>, <fact6>blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg</fact6>, <fact7>pulse 72/min</fact7>, <fact8>respiratory rate 15/min</fact8>, and <fact9>oxygen saturation 99% on room air</fact9>. <fact10>Body mass index (BMI) is 32 kg/m2</fact10>. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. The <fact11>right leg is externally rotated</fact11>, and there is a <fact12>limited range of motion in the right hip</fact12>. <fact13>Strength is 4 out of 5 at the right hip joint</fact13> and 5 out of 5 elsewhere. There is no tenderness to palpation. No joint erythema, edema or effusion present. Sensation is intact. <fact14>Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally</fact14>. Laboratory tests are unremarkable. Plain radiographs of the <fact15>right hip joint</fact15> are significant for <fact16>displacement of the right femoral head inferoposterior off the femoral neck</fact16>. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of treatment for this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, particularly the <fact16>displacement of the right femoral head inferoposterior off the femoral neck</fact16> seen on radiographs, the diagnosis is likely a slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). Given the patient's age, <fact1>14-year-old</fact1>, and <fact10>obesity with a BMI of 32 kg/m2</fact10>, this condition is a known risk. The <fact11>externally rotated right leg</fact11> and <fact12>limited range of motion in the right hip</fact12> are also consistent with SCFE. The most appropriate treatment for SCFE, especially in severe cases with significant displacement, is surgical intervention to stabilize the femoral head and prevent further complications. Among the options provided, <fact17>surgical pinning of the right hip</fact17> is the most appropriate course of treatment for this patient. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 63-year-old man from the countryside presents with leg swelling and right upper abdominal tenderness. He reports a history of myocardial infarction 4 years ago, but he has no supporting documentation. At the moment, his only medication is aspirin. He also stated that he used to have ‘high blood sugars’ when checked in the hospital 4 years ago, but he did not follow up regarding this issue. He works as a farmer and noticed that it became much harder for him to work in the last few days because of fatigue and syncope. He has a 24-pack-year history of smoking and consumes alcohol occasionally. The vital signs include: blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate 83/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and temperature 36.5℃ (97.7℉). On physical examination, the patient is pale and acrocyanotic. There is a visible jugular vein distention and bilateral lower leg pitting edema. The pulmonary auscultation is significant for occasional bilateral wheezes. Cardiac auscultation is significant for a decreased S1, S3 gallop, and grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border in the 4th left intercostal space. Abdominal percussion and palpation are suggestive of ascites. The hepatic margin is 3 cm below the right costal margin. Hepatojugular reflux is positive. Which of the following is the most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an echocardiogram?
A) Left ventricular ejection fraction of 41%
B) Increased peak tricuspid regurgitation
C) Hypokinetic wall of the left ventricle
D) Abnormal left ventricular relaxation
E) Decreased right atrial pressure
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>63-year-old man</fact1> from the countryside presents with <fact2>leg swelling</fact2> and <fact3>right upper abdominal tenderness</fact3>. He reports a history of <fact4>myocardial infarction 4 years ago</fact4>, but he has no supporting documentation. At the moment, his only medication is <fact5>aspirin</fact5>. He also stated that he used to have ‘<fact6>high blood sugars</fact6>’ when checked in the hospital 4 years ago, but he did not follow up regarding this issue. He works as a <fact7>farmer</fact7> and noticed that it became much harder for him to work in the last few days because of <fact8>fatigue</fact8> and <fact9>syncope</fact9>. He has a <fact10>24-pack-year history of smoking</fact10> and consumes alcohol occasionally. The vital signs include: <fact11>blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg</fact11>, <fact12>heart rate 83/min</fact12>, <fact13>respiratory rate 16/min</fact13>, and <fact14>temperature 36.5℃ (97.7℉)</fact14>. On physical examination, the patient is <fact15>pale and acrocyanotic</fact15>. There is a visible <fact16>jugular vein distention</fact16> and <fact17>bilateral lower leg pitting edema</fact17>. The <fact18>pulmonary auscultation</fact18> is significant for occasional <fact19>bilateral wheezes</fact19>. <fact20>Cardiac auscultation</fact20> is significant for a <fact21>decreased S1, S3 gallop</fact21>, and <fact22>grade 3/6 systolic murmur</fact22> best heard at the <fact23>left sternal border in the 4th left intercostal space</fact23>. <fact24>Abdominal percussion and palpation</fact24> are suggestive of <fact25>ascites</fact25>. The <fact26>hepatic margin is 3 cm below the right costal margin</fact26>. <fact27>Hepatojugular reflux is positive</fact27>. Which of the following is the most likely clinical finding observed in this patient on an echocardiogram?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's history of <fact4>myocardial infarction 4 years ago</fact4> and current symptoms of <fact8>fatigue</fact8> and <fact9>syncope</fact9>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact16>jugular vein distention</fact16> and <fact17>bilateral lower leg pitting edema</fact17>, it is suggestive of heart failure. The <fact20>cardiac auscultation</fact20> findings of a <fact21>decreased S1, S3 gallop</fact21>, and <fact22>grade 3/6 systolic murmur</fact22> further support this diagnosis. The presence of <fact25>ascites</fact25> and a positive <fact27>hepatojugular reflux</fact27> also indicate right-sided heart failure. Among the options provided, increased peak tricuspid regurgitation is a common echocardiogram finding in patients with right-sided heart failure. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of worsening abdominal pain for the past 2 days. She reports nausea and vomiting and is unable to tolerate oral intake. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), the pulse is 92/min, the respirations are 18/min, and the blood pressure is 132/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows yellowish discoloration of her sclera. Her abdomen is tender in the right upper quadrant. There is no abdominal distention or organomegaly. The laboratory tests show the following results:
Hemoglobin 13 g/dL
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3
Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL
Creatinine 2 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 432 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase 196 U/L
Aspartate transaminase 207 U/L
Bilirubin  
Total 3.8 mg/dL
Direct 2.7 mg/dL
Lipase 82 U/L
Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant shows dilated intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts and multiple hyperechoic spheres within the gallbladder. The pancreas is not well visualized. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and metronidazole are initiated. After 12 hours, the patient appears acutely ill and is not oriented to time. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), the pulse is 105/min, the respirations are 22/min, and the blood pressure is 112/82 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan
B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
C) Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
D) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
E) Percutaneous cholecystostomy

Physical examination shows <fact8>yellowish discoloration of her sclera</fact8>. Her abdomen is tender in the <fact9>right upper quadrant</fact9>. There is no abdominal distention or organomegaly.
