The patient has <fact4>smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years</fact4> and <fact5>binge drinks alcohol after work and on the weekends</fact5>. He underwent an <fact6>appendectomy when he was 14 years old</fact6>. He is a <fact7>long-distance truck driver</fact7>. Neither of his parents had any significant medical history. His <fact8>temperature is 37.7°C (100°F)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 102/min</fact10>, <fact11>respiratory rate is 20/min</fact11>, and <fact12>BMI is 25 kg/m2</fact12>. On examination, his <fact13>right first metatarsophalangeal joint is very tender, swollen, warm, and red in color</fact13>. Range of motion cannot be assessed due to extreme tenderness.
Laboratory test
Complete blood count:
<fact14>Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL</fact14>
<fact15>Leukocytes 16,000/mm3</fact15>
<fact16>Platelets 150,000/mm3</fact16>
<fact17>ESR 50 mm/hr</fact17>
Synovial fluid is aspirated from the joint. The findings are:
<fact18>Appearance Cloudy, dense yellow</fact18>
<fact19>WBC 30,000 cells/µL</fact19>
<fact20>Culture Negative</fact20>
<fact21>Needle-shaped birefringent crystals are observed in the joint aspirate</fact21>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s condition?

Answer:
Considering the patient's presentation, particularly the <fact2>pain in his right toe</fact2> that is <fact3>so severe it woke him up</fact3>, along with the findings of a <fact13>tender, swollen, warm, and red right first metatarsophalangeal joint</fact13>, and the presence of <fact21>needle-shaped birefringent crystals in the joint aspirate</fact21>, the diagnosis is consistent with gout. Gout is often associated with hyperuricemia, which can be caused by several factors including diet, alcohol consumption, and certain medical conditions. The patient's history of <fact5>binge drinking alcohol after work and on the weekends</fact5> is particularly relevant as alcohol can interfere with uric acid excretion, leading to increased levels. Among the provided options, the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition related to his alcohol consumption is the competition between organic acids (such as lactate, which can be elevated in alcohol metabolism) and urate for tubular secretion in the kidneys. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 35-year-old woman presents to a psychiatrist for an initial consultation. She reports that for the past 3 years, she has experienced several periods of depressed mood. The episodes do not coincide with any specific life events and seem to resolve after 4-6 weeks. During these episodes, she experiences a depressed mood, sleep disturbances, and a poor appetite, but she at times is able to enjoy spending time with her children and husband but other times she is distressed and cannot enjoy time with them. Upon further questioning, she also reports experiencing occasional episodes of elevated mood over the past ten years. During these episodes, she is very productive at her work as a lawyer and requires less sleep than usual. Her past medical history is notable for obesity, type I diabetes mellitus, and rheumatoid arthritis. She is on insulin and takes methotrexate. She smokes marijuana occasionally. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 17/min. On exam, she is quiet with a flattened affect, but is cooperative and answers questions thoroughly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Bipolar I disorder
B) Bipolar II disorder
C) Cyclothymic disorder
D) Persistent depressive disorder
E) Schizoaffective disorder
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>35-year-old woman</fact1> presents to a psychiatrist for an initial consultation. She reports that for the past <fact2>3 years</fact2>, she has experienced several periods of <fact3>depressed mood</fact3>. The episodes do not coincide with any specific life events and seem to resolve after <fact4>4-6 weeks</fact4>. During these episodes, she experiences <fact5>depressed mood, sleep disturbances, and a poor appetite</fact5>, but she at times is able to enjoy spending time with her children and husband but other times she is distressed and cannot enjoy time with them. Upon further questioning, she also reports experiencing occasional episodes of <fact6>elevated mood</fact6> over the past <fact7>ten years</fact7>. During these episodes, she is very productive at her work as a lawyer and requires <fact8>less sleep than usual</fact8>. Her past medical history is notable for <fact9>obesity, type I diabetes mellitus, and rheumatoid arthritis</fact9>. She is on insulin and takes methotrexate. She smokes marijuana occasionally. Her <fact10>temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C)</fact10>, <fact11>blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg</fact11>, <fact12>pulse is 78/min</fact12>, and <fact13>respirations are 17/min</fact13>. On exam, she is quiet with a <fact14>flattened affect</fact14>, but is cooperative and answers questions thoroughly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>35-year-old woman</fact1> has experienced periods of <fact3>depressed mood</fact3> for the past <fact2>3 years</fact2> that resolve after <fact4>4-6 weeks</fact4>, along with episodes of <fact6>elevated mood</fact6> over the past <fact7>ten years</fact7> where she requires <fact8>less sleep than usual</fact8> and is more productive. These mood swings are characteristic of bipolar disorders. However, the absence of any mention of full-blown manic episodes (which would include symptoms such as excessive spending, risky behavior, or psychotic symptoms) rules out Bipolar I disorder. Bipolar II disorder involves major depressive episodes and at least one hypomanic episode, which seems to fit her pattern of <fact5>depressed mood, sleep disturbances, and a poor appetite</fact5> followed by periods of <fact6>elevated mood</fact6> and increased productivity. Cyclothymic disorder is also characterized by periods of hypomanic symptoms interspersed with periods of mild depression that last at least 2 years; however, the symptoms do not meet diagnostic requirements for a hypomanic episode and a depressive episode. Given the information, the most likely diagnosis is Bipolar II disorder because it matches her pattern of depressive episodes and hypomanic episodes without full-blown mania. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion, generalized fatigue, and irritability for the past week. She has been unable to recall her husband's name or their address. She has had insomnia and daytime sleepiness during this period. Her last bowel movement was 3 days ago. One month ago, she underwent a transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt (TIPS) placement. She has alcoholic liver cirrhosis. Current medications include spironolactone and furosemide. She used to drink over a pint of vodka daily but quit 2 months ago. She is oriented to place and person. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. There are several telangiectasias over the chest and back. Palmar erythema is present. The abdomen is mildly distended and nontender. Shifting dullness is present. There is a flapping tremor of both hands when outstretched and dorsiflexed. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. She completes the number connection test slower than the age-normalized standard. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Reversal of TIPS
B) Paracentesis
C) Administer IV ceftriaxone
D) Administer lactulose
E) Administer vitamin B1
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>56-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of <fact2>increasing confusion, generalized fatigue, and irritability</fact2> for the past week. She has been unable to recall her husband's name or their address. She has had <fact3>insomnia and daytime sleepiness</fact3> during this period. Her last bowel movement was <fact4>3 days ago</fact4>. One month ago, she underwent a <fact5>transjugular intrahepatic portal shunt (TIPS) placement</fact5>. She has <fact6>alcoholic liver cirrhosis</fact6>. Current medications include spironolactone and furosemide. She used to drink over a pint of vodka daily but quit <fact7>2 months ago</fact7>. She is oriented to place and person. Her <fact8>temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 88/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 102/64 mm Hg</fact10>. Examination shows <fact11>scleral icterus and jaundice</fact11>. There are several <fact12>telangiectasias over the chest and back</fact12>. <fact13>Palmar erythema</fact13> is present. The abdomen is mildly distended and nontender. <fact14>Shifting dullness</fact14> is present. There is a <fact15>flapping tremor of both hands</fact15> when outstretched and dorsiflexed. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. She completes the number connection test slower than the age-normalized standard.

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>increasing confusion, generalized fatigue, and irritability</fact2>, along with <fact3>insomnia and daytime sleepiness</fact3>, and the presence of <fact11>scleral icterus and jaundice</fact11>, <fact13>palmar erythema</fact13>, and a <fact15>flapping tremor of both hands</fact15>, these are indicative of hepatic encephalopathy, a complication of <fact6>alcoholic liver cirrhosis</fact6>. The fact that she has not had a bowel movement in <fact4>3 days</fact4> suggests constipation, which can contribute to the development of hepatic encephalopathy. Given these factors, the most appropriate next step in management is to administer lactulose, which is used to treat constipation and hepatic encephalopathy by reducing ammonia production in the gut. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of low back pain and weakness for the past 4 weeks. He says that the pain is sharp, radiates to his left side, and has a burning quality. He has had a cough occasionally productive of blood-streaked sputum for the past 2 months. He has had 3.2-kg (7.0-lb) weight loss in that time. He is now unable to walk without assistance and has had constipation and difficulty urinating for the past 2 weeks. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Neurologic examination shows 3/5 strength of the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperreflexive. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. Sensory examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick below the T4 dermatome. He is unable to lie recumbent due to severe pain. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple round opacities of varying sizes in both lungs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
A) Radiation therapy
B) Intravenous dexamethasone therapy
C) Intravenous acyclovir therapy
D) Intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin therapy
E) Oral ibuprofen therapy
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>76-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the physician by his wife because of <fact2>low back pain and weakness</fact2> for the past <fact3>4 weeks</fact3>. He says that the <fact4>pain is sharp, radiates to his left side, and has a burning quality</fact4>. He has had a <fact5>cough occasionally productive of blood-streaked sputum</fact5> for the past <fact6>2 months</fact6>. He has had <fact7>3.2-kg (7.0-lb) weight loss</fact7> in that time. He is now unable to walk without assistance and has had <fact8>constipation and difficulty urinating</fact8> for the past <fact9>2 weeks</fact9>. He has <fact10>hypertension treated with enalapril</fact10>. He has <fact11>smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years</fact11>. His <fact12>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 75/min</fact13>, and <fact14>blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg</fact14>. He is oriented to person, place, and time. <fact15>Neurologic examination shows 3/5 strength of the lower extremities</fact15>. <fact16>Deep tendon reflexes are hyperreflexive</fact16>. <fact17>Babinski sign is present bilaterally</fact17>. <fact18>Sensory examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick below the T4 dermatome</fact18>. He is unable to lie recumbent due to <fact19>severe pain</fact19>. An <fact20>x-ray of the chest shows multiple round opacities of varying sizes in both lungs</fact20>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>low back pain and weakness</fact2>, <fact4>pain radiating to his left side with a burning quality</fact4>, <fact5>cough occasionally productive of blood-streaked sputum</fact5>, and significant <fact7>weight loss</fact7>, along with the findings of <fact15>neurologic examination showing 3/5 strength of the lower extremities</fact15>, <fact16>hyperreflexive deep tendon reflexes</fact16>, and <fact17>positive Babinski sign</fact17>, it is suggestive of a spinal cord compression, likely due to metastasis given the <fact20>x-ray findings of multiple round opacities in both lungs</fact20>. The most appropriate next step in management would be to initiate <fact21>intravenous dexamethasone therapy</fact21> to reduce inflammation and swelling around the spinal cord, thereby alleviating the compression. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 36-year-old man presents to his physician for a regular checkup, and he expresses an intent to quit smoking. He is a financial director with a 15-pack-year history of smoking who tried quitting several times. He tried different nicotine replacement products, none of which helped him. The patient has gastrointestinal reflux disease and takes omeprazole. The medical history is significant for a head trauma after which he had two seizure episodes. He does not have a history of any other disorders. Currently, he is not on any antiepileptic medication. He heard from his friend about an antidepressant that efficiently helps with smoking cessation. He would like to try this medication, and asks his physician for an advice. Which of the following statements regarding the use of the mentioned medication is correct?
A) Omeprazole interferes with bupropion metabolism and should be taken one hour prior to omeprazole consumption.
B) Bupropion is only effective when used together with nicotine replacement products.
C) Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of seizure disorder.
D) The physician may prescribe bupropion for this patient only after a full cardiac workup is performed.
E) This patient has no contraindications for bupropion and may safely use it.
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>36-year-old man</fact1> presents to his physician for a regular checkup, and he expresses an intent to quit smoking. He is a financial director with a <fact2>15-pack-year history of smoking</fact2> who tried quitting several times. He tried different nicotine replacement products, none of which helped him. The patient has <fact3>gastrointestinal reflux disease</fact3> and takes <fact4>omeprazole</fact4>. The medical history is significant for a <fact5>head trauma</fact5> after which he had two <fact6>seizure episodes</fact6>. He does not have a history of any other disorders. Currently, he is not on any antiepileptic medication. He heard from his friend about an <fact7>antidepressant that efficiently helps with smoking cessation</fact7>. He would like to try this medication, and asks his physician for an advice. Which of the following statements regarding the use of the mentioned medication is correct?

A) <fact4>Omeprazole</fact4> interferes with bupropion metabolism and should be taken one hour prior to <fact4>omeprazole</fact4> consumption.
B) Bupropion is only effective when used together with nicotine replacement products.
C) Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of <fact6>seizure disorder</fact6>.
D) The physician may prescribe bupropion for this patient only after a full cardiac workup is performed.
E) This patient has no contraindications for bupropion and may safely use it.

Answer: 
Given the patient's history of <fact6>seizure episodes</fact6> following a <fact5>head trauma</fact5>, it is crucial to consider the potential risks associated with certain medications. Bupropion, an <fact7>antidepressant that efficiently helps with smoking cessation</fact7>, is known to lower the seizure threshold. Therefore, it is contraindicated in patients with a history of <fact6>seizure disorder</fact6>. The correct statement regarding the use of the mentioned medication is that bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of <fact6>seizure disorder</fact6>. The answer is {C}.

question:
A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a cough, dyspnea, and fever for 1 day. The cough is productive of small amounts of green phlegm. He has metastatic colon cancer and has received three cycles of chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin; his last chemotherapy session was 2.5 months ago. He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and has been treated with antibiotics and prednisolone for acute exacerbations three times in the past year. His medications include a fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler and a tiotropium bromide inhaler. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. His temperature is 39.1°C (103.1°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 88/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles and rhonchi. An x-ray of the chest shows a left upper-lobe infiltrate of the lung. Two sets of blood cultures are obtained. Endotracheal aspirate Gram stain shows gram-negative rods. Two large bore cannulas are inserted and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
A) Ceftriaxone and azithromycin
B) Ertapenem
C) Colistin
D) Cefepime and levofloxacin
E) Clarithromycin and amoxicillin-clavulanate
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>68-year-old man</fact1> comes to the emergency department because of a <fact2>cough, dyspnea, and fever for 1 day</fact2>. The <fact3>cough is productive of small amounts of green phlegm</fact3>. He has <fact4>metastatic colon cancer</fact4> and has received three cycles of chemotherapy with <fact5>5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin</fact5>; his last chemotherapy session was <fact6>2.5 months ago</fact6>. He has <fact7>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease</fact7> and has been treated with antibiotics and prednisolone for acute exacerbations three times in the past year. His medications include a <fact8>fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler</fact8> and a <fact9>tiotropium bromide inhaler</fact9>. He has smoked <fact10>one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years</fact10>. His <fact11>temperature is 39.1°C (103.1°F)</fact11>, <fact12>pulse is 112/min</fact12>, <fact13>respirations are 32/min</fact13>, and <fact14>blood pressure is 88/69 mm Hg</fact14>. <fact15>Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%</fact15>. <fact16>Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles and rhonchi</fact16>. An <fact17>x-ray of the chest shows a left upper-lobe infiltrate of the lung</fact17>. Two sets of <fact18>blood cultures are obtained</fact18>. <fact19>Endotracheal aspirate Gram stain shows gram-negative rods</fact19>. Two large bore cannulas are inserted and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with a <fact2>cough, dyspnea, and fever for 1 day</fact2>, along with the <fact3>cough productive of small amounts of green phlegm</fact3> and the <fact16>pulmonary examination showing diffuse crackles and rhonchi</fact16>, it is clear that the patient has a severe respiratory infection. The <fact17>x-ray of the chest showing a left upper-lobe infiltrate of the lung</fact17> further supports this diagnosis. Given the patient's history of <fact7>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease</fact7> and recent chemotherapy with <fact5>5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin</fact5>, he is at increased risk for infections, particularly those caused by resistant organisms. The <fact19>endotracheal aspirate Gram stain showing gram-negative rods</fact19> indicates that the infection is likely caused by a gram-negative bacterium. Among the provided options, the combination of Cefepime and Levofloxacin offers broad-spectrum coverage against gram-negative bacteria, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is a common pathogen in patients with compromised immune systems and those with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Therefore, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient is option {D}.

question:
A 14-year-old teenager presents to his pediatrician complaining of frequent headaches and excessive fatigue during soccer practice. His mother notes that he seems to have gained a lot of weight despite the fact that he eats a healthy, well-balanced diet. His teachers have also become concerned because he leaves class to use the restroom frequently throughout the day. He has no medical problems and family history is insignificant. A physical exam is significant for a short, overweight child with nonpitting edema and decreased reflexes. His systolic blood pressure drops by 20 mm Hg when he stands. Fundoscopic exam is significant for papilledema and visual field exam is significant for bitemporal hemianopsia. Laboratory findings include:
BUN 22 mg/dL N: 7–20 mg/dL
pCO2 32 mm Hg N: 35–45 mm Hg
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL N: 0.8–1.4 mg/dL
Glucose 50 mg/dL N: 64–128 mg/dL
Serum chloride 95 mmol/L N: 101–111 mmol/L
Serum potassium 3.3 mEq/L N: 3.7–5.2 mEq/L
Serum sodium 120 mEq/L N: 136–144 mEq/L
Bicarbonate (HCO3) 15 mmol/L N: 18–22 mmol/L
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 0.1 mIU/L N: 0.5–5 mIU/L
Free T4 6 pmol/L N: 10–20 pmol/L
What is the necessary treatment?
A) Chemotherapy, surgical resection and radiation
B) Chemotherapy and radiation
C) Chemotherapy
D) Surgical resection
E) Hormone replacement therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>14-year-old teenager</fact1> presents to his pediatrician complaining of <fact2>frequent headaches and excessive fatigue</fact2> during soccer practice. His mother notes that he seems to have gained a lot of weight despite the fact that he eats a <fact3>healthy, well-balanced diet</fact3>. His teachers have also become concerned because he leaves class to use the <fact4>restroom frequently throughout the day</fact4>. He has no medical problems and <fact5>family history is insignificant</fact5>. A physical exam is significant for a <fact6>short, overweight child</fact6> with <fact7>nonpitting edema</fact7> and <fact8>decreased reflexes</fact8>. His <fact9>systolic blood pressure drops by 20 mm Hg when he stands</fact9>. <fact10>Fundoscopic exam</fact10> is significant for <fact11>papilledema</fact11> and <fact12>visual field exam</fact12> is significant for <fact13>bitemporal hemianopsia</fact13>. Laboratory findings include:
<fact14>BUN 22 mg/dL</fact14> N: 7–20 mg/dL
<fact15>pCO2 32 mm Hg</fact15> N: 35–45 mm Hg
<fact16>Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL</fact16> N: 0.8–1.4 mg/dL
<fact17>Glucose 50 mg/dL</fact17> N: 64–128 mg/dL
<fact18>Serum chloride 95 mmol/L</fact18> N: 101–111 mmol/L
<fact19>Serum potassium 3.3 mEq/L</fact19> N: 3.7–5.2 mEq/L
<fact20>Serum sodium 120 mEq/L</fact20> N: 136–144 mEq/L
<fact21>Bicarbonate (HCO3) 15 mmol/L</fact21> N: 18–22 mmol/L
<fact22>Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) 0.1 mIU/L</fact22> N: 0.5–5 mIU/L
<fact23>Free T4 6 pmol/L</fact23> N: 10–20 pmol/L
What is the necessary treatment?

Answer:
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>frequent headaches and excessive fatigue</fact2>, <fact4>frequent restroom use</fact4>, and significant findings on physical exam such as <fact7>nonpitting edema</fact7>, <fact8>decreased reflexes</fact8>, <fact11>papilledema</fact11>, and <fact13>bitemporal hemianopsia</fact13>, along with laboratory results showing <fact17>low glucose</fact17>, <fact20>hyponatremia</fact20>, and abnormalities in thyroid function tests (<fact22>low TSH</fact22> and <fact23>low Free T4</fact23>), the clinical picture suggests a pituitary tumor, likely a craniopharyngioma, affecting thyroid function and causing diabetes insipidus. The necessary treatment for such a condition, especially given the presence of <fact11>papilledema</fact11> indicating increased intracranial pressure, involves addressing the tumor directly. Therefore, the most appropriate treatment would involve a combination of chemotherapy, surgical resection, and radiation to manage the tumor and its effects. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 74-year-old man undergoes an open cholecystectomy. Surgery is performed under general anesthesia for which the patient is intubated with an endotracheal tube. Directly following the procedure, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. He is extubated as soon as he showed signs of alertness. Five minutes later, he becomes unresponsive. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, and hypertension. He underwent stenting of the right coronary artery 10 years ago. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 2 weeks ago for surgery. He drinks one to two beers daily. His current medications include metformin, enalapril, aspirin, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 73%. He is put on a non-rebreather mask with an FiO2 of 100%. Three minutes later, he is still unresponsive. His arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH 7.32
PCO2 33 mm Hg
PO2 73 mm Hg
HCO3 22 mEq/L
O2 saturation 73%
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?"
A) Perform tracheostomy
B) Continue using the non-rebreather mask
C) Reintubate
D) Close observation only
E) Start BiPAP
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>74-year-old man</fact1> undergoes an open cholecystectomy. Surgery is performed under <fact2>general anesthesia</fact2> for which the patient is intubated with an <fact3>endotracheal tube</fact3>. Directly following the procedure, his <fact4>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact4>, <fact5>pulse is 80/min</fact5>, and <fact6>blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg</fact6>. He is <fact7>extubated as soon as he showed signs of alertness</fact7>. Five minutes later, he becomes <fact8>unresponsive</fact8>. He has <fact9>type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, and hypertension</fact9>. He underwent <fact10>stenting of the right coronary artery 10 years ago</fact10>. He <fact11>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 2 weeks ago for surgery</fact11>. He drinks <fact12>one to two beers daily</fact12>. His current medications include <fact13>metformin, enalapril, aspirin, atorvastatin, and a multivitamin</fact13>. His <fact14>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact14>, <fact15>pulse is 102/min</fact15>, <fact16>respirations are 20/min</fact16>, and <fact17>blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg</fact17>. <fact18>Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 73%</fact18>. He is put on a <fact19>non-rebreather mask with an FiO2 of 100%</fact19>. Three minutes later, he is still <fact20>unresponsive</fact20>. His <fact21>arterial blood gas analysis</fact21> shows:
<fact22>pH 7.32</fact22>
<fact23>PCO2 33 mm Hg</fact23>
<fact24>PO2 73 mm Hg</fact24>
<fact25>HCO3 22 mEq/L</fact25>
<fact26>O2 saturation 73%</fact26>
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

Answer:
Given the patient's <fact8>unresponsive</fact8> state and <fact18>low oxygen saturation of 73%</fact18> despite being on a <fact19>non-rebreather mask with an FiO2 of 100%</fact19>, it is clear that he is not adequately oxygenating. His <fact21>arterial blood gas analysis</fact21> shows a <fact22>pH of 7.32</fact22>, which is slightly acidic, a <fact23>PCO2 of 33 mm Hg</fact23>, which is within normal limits, but a <fact24>PO2 of 73 mm Hg</fact24> and <fact26>O2 saturation of 73%</fact26>, both of which indicate hypoxemia. Given these findings, the best next step is to secure the patient's airway to ensure adequate oxygenation. Since he was previously <fact7>extubated</fact7> and is now failing on a non-rebreather mask, the most appropriate action is to reintubate him to provide a secure airway for ventilation and oxygenation support. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 36-year-old man presents to a physician after having a transient loss of consciousness while resting after dinner the previous night. His symptoms only lasted for a few seconds and resolved spontaneously. This is the third time he experienced such an episode. He says that he recently started having nightmares. His father died of sudden cardiac death at the age of 45 years without a history of hypertension or any chronic cardiac disorder. A complete physical examination was normal. A 12-lead electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevations in V1, V2, and V3, and the presence of incomplete right bundle branch block (RBBB). After a complete diagnostic evaluation, Brugada syndrome was diagnosed. He has prescribed a class I anti-arrhythmic drug, which is a sodium channel blocker that slows phase 0 depolarization in ventricular muscle fibers. The drug also blocks potassium channels and prolongs action potential duration, but it does not shorten phase 3 repolarization. The drug also has mild anticholinergic and alpha-blocking activity. If taken in high doses, which of the following are the most likely side effects of the drug?
A) Headache and tinnitus
B) Pulmonary fibrosis and corneal deposits
C) Dyslipidemia and hypoglycemia unawareness
D) Pedal edema and flushing
E) Hypothyroidism and phototoxicity
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>36-year-old man</fact1> presents to a physician after having a <fact2>transient loss of consciousness</fact2> while resting after dinner the previous night. His symptoms only lasted for a few seconds and resolved spontaneously. This is the third time he experienced such an episode. He says that he recently started having <fact3>nightmares</fact3>. His father died of <fact4>sudden cardiac death</fact4> at the age of 45 years without a history of hypertension or any chronic cardiac disorder. A complete physical examination was normal. A 12-lead electrocardiogram showed <fact5>ST-segment elevations in V1, V2, and V3, and the presence of incomplete right bundle branch block (RBBB)</fact5>. After a complete diagnostic evaluation, <fact6>Brugada syndrome</fact6> was diagnosed. He has prescribed a <fact7>class I anti-arrhythmic drug</fact7>, which is a <fact8>sodium channel blocker</fact8> that slows phase 0 depolarization in ventricular muscle fibers. The drug also blocks <fact9>potassium channels</fact9> and prolongs action potential duration, but it does not shorten phase 3 repolarization. The drug also has <fact10>mild anticholinergic and alpha-blocking activity</fact10>. If taken in high doses, which of the following are the most likely side effects of the drug?

Answer: 
Considering the prescribed medication is a <fact7>class I anti-arrhythmic drug</fact7> with <fact8>sodium channel blocking</fact8> activity, and also blocks <fact9>potassium channels</fact9> and has <fact10>mild anticholinergic and alpha-blocking activity</fact10>, it is likely that in high doses, the drug would exhibit side effects related to these mechanisms. Among the options provided, the most likely side effects related to these mechanisms, especially the anticholinergic activity, would include dry mouth, blurred vision, urinary retention, and constipation, but none of these options directly match the provided choices. However, considering the broader pharmacological profile of class I anti-arrhythmic drugs, one might expect side effects that could be related to the central nervous system due to the anticholinergic effects. Therefore, the closest match from the given options, taking into account the potential for central nervous system effects from anticholinergic activity, could be {A} Headache and tinnitus, though this is a bit of an indirect inference based on the information given.

question:
A 41-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with abdominal pain. He says that the pain “comes and goes” throughout the day and usually lasts 20-30 minutes per episode. He can point to the spot 1-2 inches above the umbilicus where he feels the pain. He denies any feeling of regurgitation or nighttime cough but endorses nausea. He reports that he used to eat three large meals per day but has found that eating more frequently improves his pain. He tried a couple pills of ibuprofen with food over the past couple days and thinks it helped. He has gained four pounds since his past appointment three months ago. The patient denies any diarrhea or change in his stools. He has no past medical history. He drinks 5-6 beers on the weekend and has a 20 pack-year smoking history. He denies any family history of cancer. On physical exam, he is tender to palpation above the umbilicus. Bowel sounds are present. A stool guaiac test is positive. The patient undergoes endoscopy with biopsy to diagnose his condition.

Which of the following is most likely to be found on histology?
A) Mucosal defect in the stomach
B) Urease-producing organism in the small intestine
C) PAS-positive material in the small intestine
D) Noncaseating granulomas in the small intestine
E) Crypt abscesses in the large intestine
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>41-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care provider with <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2>. He says that the pain “comes and goes” throughout the day and usually lasts <fact3>20-30 minutes per episode</fact3>. He can point to the spot <fact4>1-2 inches above the umbilicus</fact4> where he feels the pain. He denies any feeling of <fact5>regurgitation or nighttime cough</fact5> but endorses <fact6>nausea</fact6>. He reports that he used to eat <fact7>three large meals per day</fact7> but has found that eating more frequently improves his pain. He tried a couple pills of <fact8>ibuprofen with food</fact8> over the past couple days and thinks it helped. He has gained <fact9>four pounds</fact9> since his past appointment <fact10>three months ago</fact10>. The patient denies any <fact11>diarrhea or change in his stools</fact11>. He has no past medical history. He drinks <fact12>5-6 beers on the weekend</fact12> and has a <fact13>20 pack-year smoking history</fact13>. He denies any family history of <fact14>cancer</fact14>. On physical exam, he is tender to palpation <fact15>above the umbilicus</fact15>. <fact16>Bowel sounds are present</fact16>. A <fact17>stool guaiac test is positive</fact17>. The patient undergoes <fact18>endoscopy with biopsy</fact18> to diagnose his condition.

Which of the following is most likely to be found on histology?
A) Mucosal defect in the stomach
B) Urease-producing organism in the small intestine
C) PAS-positive material in the small intestine
D) Noncaseating granulomas in the small intestine
E) Crypt abscesses in the large intestine

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2> located <fact4>1-2 inches above the umbilicus</fact4>, <fact6>nausea</fact6>, and a <fact17>positive stool guaiac test</fact17>, these findings are suggestive of a gastrointestinal issue with possible bleeding. The fact that the patient's pain is improved by eating more frequently and that he has gained <fact9>four pounds</fact9> since his last appointment indicates that the issue may be related to gastric acid or ulceration. The most likely diagnosis would be a peptic ulcer, which would be represented on histology by a mucosal defect in the stomach. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of pallor and increasing lethargy for 2 days. One week ago, he experienced abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea that have since subsided. The patient's father states that they returned early from a 6-week roadtrip in Mexico because of these symptoms. His parents have been giving him oral rehydration solution. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears pale. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 94 μm3
Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3
Platelet count 45,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 12 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 34 sec
Serum
Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 2.5 mg/dL
Direct 0.1 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase 1658 U/L
A blood smear shows schistocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?"
A) Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
B) Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura
C) Hemolytic uremic syndrome
D) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
E) Disseminated intravascular coagulation
"
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>2-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician for evaluation of <fact2>pallor and increasing lethargy</fact2> for 2 days. One week ago, he experienced <fact3>abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea</fact3> that have since subsided. The patient's father states that they returned early from a <fact4>6-week roadtrip in Mexico</fact4> because of these symptoms. His parents have been giving him <fact5>oral rehydration solution</fact5>. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears <fact6>pale</fact6>. His <fact7>temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 130/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 35/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg</fact10>. Examination shows <fact11>scleral icterus</fact11>. The abdomen is <fact12>soft and nontender</fact12>; there is no rebound or guarding. <fact13>Bowel sounds are hyperactive</fact13>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
<fact14>Hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL</fact14>
<fact15>Mean corpuscular volume 94 μm3</fact15>
<fact16>Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3</fact16>
<fact17>Platelet count 45,000/mm3</fact17>
<fact18>Prothrombin time 12 sec</fact18>
<fact19>Partial thromboplastin time 34 sec</fact19>
Serum
<fact20>Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL</fact21>
Bilirubin
<fact22>Total 2.5 mg/dL</fact22>
<fact23>Direct 0.1 mg/dL</fact23>
<fact24>Lactate dehydrogenase 1658 U/L</fact24>
A blood smear shows <fact25>schistocytes</fact25>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer:
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>pallor and increasing lethargy</fact2>, recent history of <fact3>abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea</fact3>, and laboratory results showing <fact14>low hemoglobin</fact14>, <fact17>thrombocytopenia</fact17>, and <fact25>schistocytes</fact25> on the blood smear, the most likely diagnosis is Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS). HUS is characterized by the triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury, which is supported by the patient's <fact20>elevated urea nitrogen</fact20> and <fact21>creatinine levels</fact21>. The presence of <fact25>schistocytes</fact25> indicates microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, a hallmark of HUS. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fever, chills, and generalized weakness. He has no cough. He was treated for a neck abscess 6 months ago. He takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks two to three beers daily. He has been using intravenous cocaine and heroin for 6 years. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows track marks on both cubital fossae. There are retinal hemorrhages with pale centers. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the lower left sternal border. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.3 g/dL
Leukocyte count 14,300/mm3
Platelet count 278,000/mm3
Serum
Glucose 96 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL
AST 18 U/L
ALT 22 U/L
Transthoracic echocardiography shows multiple vegetations on the tricuspid valve and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Two sets of blood cultures are collected. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
A) Transesophageal echocardiography
B) Intravenous vancomycin therapy
C) X-ray of the chest
D) CT pulmonary angiogram
E) Intravenous ciprofloxacin therapy
"
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>28-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of a <fact2>3-day history of fever, chills, and generalized weakness</fact2>. He has no cough. He was treated for a <fact3>neck abscess 6 months ago</fact3>. He takes no medications. He has smoked <fact4>one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years</fact4> and drinks <fact5>two to three beers daily</fact5>. He has been using <fact6>intravenous cocaine and heroin for 6 years</fact6>. He appears ill. His <fact7>temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 112/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 20/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg</fact10>. Examination shows <fact11>track marks on both cubital fossae</fact11>. There are <fact12>retinal hemorrhages with pale centers</fact12>. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A <fact13>grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur</fact13> is heard best at the lower left sternal border. Laboratory studies show: <fact14>Leukocyte count 14,300/mm3</fact14>. <fact15>Transthoracic echocardiography shows multiple vegetations on the tricuspid valve and moderate tricuspid regurgitation</fact15>. Two sets of blood cultures are collected. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer:
Considering the patient's <fact2>3-day history of fever, chills, and generalized weakness</fact2>, along with the presence of <fact11>track marks on both cubital fossae</fact11> and a history of <fact6>intravenous cocaine and heroin use for 6 years</fact6>, there is a high suspicion for infective endocarditis, particularly given the <fact15>transthoracic echocardiography findings of multiple vegetations on the tricuspid valve and moderate tricuspid regurgitation</fact15>. The patient's elevated <fact14>leukocyte count of 14,300/mm3</fact14> also supports an infectious process. Given these factors, starting antibiotic therapy would be the most appropriate next step. Among the options provided, intravenous vancomycin therapy is a reasonable choice for treating suspected infective endocarditis, especially in the context of potential methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection, which is more common in intravenous drug users. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
Two hours after admission to the hospital for dialysis, a 63-year-old woman has severe pain in her lower back. The pain is 8 out of 10 in intensity and radiates down the legs. She underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 4 years ago. She has hypertension, chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and major depressive disorder. She lives with her daughter and reports frequent fights with her at home. Her current medications include sertraline, insulin, enalapril, sodium bicarbonate, and sevelamer. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 132/94 mm Hg. There is severe tenderness on palpation over the L2 vertebra; range of motion is limited. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 8,700/mm3
Platelet count 130,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 136 mEq/L
Cl- 101 mEq/L
K+ 5.1 mEq/L
Calcium 8.2 mg/dL
Urea nitrogen 33 mg/dL
Glucose 190 mg/dL
Creatinine 3.8 mg/dL
An x-ray of the spine shows a wedge compression fracture of the L2 vertebra. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?"
A) Tertiary hyperparathyroidism
B) Secondary hyperparathyroidism
C) Elder abuse
D) Pseudohypoparathyroidism
E) Primary hyperparathyroidism
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>63-year-old woman</fact1> has severe pain in her <fact2>lower back</fact2> 2 hours after admission to the hospital for <fact3>dialysis</fact3>. The pain is 8 out of 10 in intensity and radiates down the legs. She has a history of <fact4>hypertension, chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and major depressive disorder</fact4>. Her current medications include <fact5>sertraline, insulin, enalapril, sodium bicarbonate, and sevelamer</fact5>. There is severe tenderness on palpation over the <fact6>L2 vertebra</fact6>; range of motion is limited. Laboratory studies show a <fact7>hemoglobin of 10.1 g/dL</fact7>, <fact8>leukocyte count of 8,700/mm3</fact8>, <fact9>platelet count of 130,000/mm3</fact9>, <fact10>serum calcium of 8.2 mg/dL</fact10>, <fact11>urea nitrogen of 33 mg/dL</fact11>, <fact12>glucose of 190 mg/dL</fact12>, and <fact13>creatinine of 3.8 mg/dL</fact13>. An <fact14>x-ray of the spine</fact14> shows a <fact15>wedge compression fracture of the L2 vertebra</fact15>. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact4>chronic kidney disease</fact4> and the laboratory results showing an elevated <fact13>creatinine of 3.8 mg/dL</fact13> and <fact11>urea nitrogen of 33 mg/dL</fact11>, it is clear that she has impaired renal function. Additionally, the <fact15>wedge compression fracture of the L2 vertebra</fact15> seen on the <fact14>x-ray of the spine</fact14> suggests osteoporosis or bone disease. Given these factors, the most likely explanation for her condition is secondary hyperparathyroidism, which is a common complication of chronic kidney disease. Secondary hyperparathyroidism leads to an overproduction of parathyroid hormone, causing bone resorption and osteoporosis, which increases the risk of fractures. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 21-year-old male presents to his primary care provider for fatigue. He reports that he graduated from college last month and returned 3 days ago from a 2 week vacation to Vietnam and Cambodia. For the past 2 days, he has developed a worsening headache, malaise, and pain in his hands and wrists. The patient has a past medical history of asthma managed with albuterol as needed. He is sexually active with both men and women, and he uses condoms “most of the time.” On physical exam, the patient’s temperature is 102.5°F (39.2°C), blood pressure is 112/66 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He has tenderness to palpation over his bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints and a maculopapular rash on his trunk and upper thighs. Tourniquet test is negative. Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL
Hematocrit: 44%
Leukocyte count: 3,200/mm^3
Platelet count: 112,000/mm^3

Serum:
Na+: 142 mEq/L
Cl-: 104 mEq/L
K+: 4.6 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
BUN: 18 mg/dL
Glucose: 87 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
AST: 106 U/L
ALT: 112 U/L
Bilirubin (total): 0.8 mg/dL
Bilirubin (conjugated): 0.3 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Chikungunya
B) Dengue fever
C) Epstein-Barr virus
D) Hepatitis A
E) Typhoid fever
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>21-year-old male</fact1> presents to his primary care provider for <fact2>fatigue</fact2>. He reports that he graduated from college last month and returned <fact3>3 days ago from a 2 week vacation to Vietnam and Cambodia</fact3>. For the past <fact4>2 days</fact4>, he has developed a worsening <fact5>headache, malaise, and pain in his hands and wrists</fact5>. The patient has a past medical history of <fact6>asthma managed with albuterol as needed</fact6>. He is <fact7>sexually active with both men and women, and he uses condoms “most of the time”</fact7>. On physical exam, the patient’s <fact8>temperature is 102.5°F (39.2°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 112/66 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 105/min</fact10>, <fact11>respirations are 12/min</fact11>, and <fact12>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact12>. He has <fact13>tenderness to palpation over his bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints</fact13> and a <fact14>maculopapular rash on his trunk and upper thighs</fact14>. <fact15>Tourniquet test is negative</fact15>. Laboratory results are as follows:

<fact16>Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL</fact16>
<fact17>Hematocrit: 44%</fact17>
<fact18>Leukocyte count: 3,200/mm^3</fact18>
<fact19>Platelet count: 112,000/mm^3</fact19>

<fact20>Serum:</fact20>
<fact21>Na+: 142 mEq/L</fact21>
<fact22>Cl-: 104 mEq/L</fact22>
<fact23>K+: 4.6 mEq/L</fact23>
<fact24>HCO3-: 24 mEq/L</fact24>
<fact25>BUN: 18 mg/dL</fact25>
<fact26>Glucose: 87 mg/dL</fact26>
<fact27>Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL</fact27>
<fact28>AST: 106 U/L</fact28>
<fact29>ALT: 112 U/L</fact29>
<fact30>Bilirubin (total): 0.8 mg/dL</fact30>
<fact31>Bilirubin (conjugated): 0.3 mg/dL</fact31>

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer:
Considering the patient's recent travel history to <fact3>Vietnam and Cambodia</fact3> and the development of symptoms such as <fact5>headache, malaise, and pain in his hands and wrists</fact5>, along with a <fact14>maculopapular rash on his trunk and upper thighs</fact14>, the most likely diagnosis is Chikungunya. Chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted by mosquitoes, commonly found in Southeast Asia, and is characterized by symptoms such as fever, joint pain, and rash. The patient's laboratory results, including a <fact18>low leukocyte count</fact18> and <fact19>mild thrombocytopenia</fact19>, also support this diagnosis. Additionally, the <fact15>negative tourniquet test</fact15> helps to rule out dengue fever, another mosquito-borne illness. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of left knee pain as well as stiffness upon waking for about 10–15 minutes. The pain is worse after standing a lot at work and when she climbs stairs. There is no history of trauma. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Her mother died of metastatic breast cancer 15 years ago, at the age of 65 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include atorvastatin, labetalol, and aspirin. Over the past 2 months, she has been taking over-the-counter ibuprofen as needed for the joint pain. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31.8 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg. Examination of the left knee shows tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line; there is crepitus and pain with full flexion and extension. Serum uric acid concentration is 8.0 mg/dL and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely finding on imaging of the left knee?
A) Osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray
B) Calcification of synovia and cartilage on ultrasound
C) Diffuse lytic-sclerotic bone lesions on x-ray
D) Joint effusion and pannus on ultrasound
E) Fluid-filled pouch on ultrasound
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>58-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>3-month history of left knee pain</fact2> as well as <fact3>stiffness upon waking for about 10–15 minutes</fact3>. The <fact4>pain is worse after standing a lot at work and when she climbs stairs</fact4>. There is no history of <fact5>trauma</fact5>. She has <fact6>hypercholesterolemia and hypertension</fact6>. Her mother died of <fact7>metastatic breast cancer 15 years ago, at the age of 65 years</fact7>. She does not <fact8>smoke or drink alcohol</fact8>. Current medications include <fact9>atorvastatin, labetalol, and aspirin</fact9>. Over the past <fact10>2 months</fact10>, she has been taking over-the-counter <fact11>ibuprofen as needed for the joint pain</fact11>. She is <fact12>163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb)</fact12>; <fact13>BMI is 31.8 kg/m2</fact13>. Her <fact14>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact14>, <fact15>pulse is 88/min</fact15>, and <fact16>blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg</fact16>. Examination of the left knee shows <fact17>tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line</fact17>; there is <fact18>crepitus and pain with full flexion and extension</fact18>. <fact19>Serum uric acid concentration is 8.0 mg/dL</fact19> and <fact20>erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h</fact20>. Which of the following is the most likely finding on imaging of the left knee?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>3-month history of left knee pain</fact2> and <fact3>stiffness upon waking for about 10–15 minutes</fact3>, along with the <fact4>pain worsening after standing a lot at work and when she climbs stairs</fact4>, suggests a degenerative joint condition. The absence of <fact5>trauma</fact5> and the presence of <fact17>tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line</fact17> and <fact18>crepitus and pain with full flexion and extension</fact18> further support this diagnosis. Additionally, the patient's <fact13>BMI of 31.8 kg/m2</fact13> increases her risk for osteoarthritis. Among the provided options, the most likely finding on imaging of the left knee for osteoarthritis would be the presence of osteophytes with joint-space narrowing on x-ray. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
Hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1a) is a transcription factor with increased activity under conditions of cellular hypoxia. In normoxia, von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) protein hydroxylates prolyl residues on oxygen-dependent degradation domains of HIF-1a, targeting it for proteasomal degradation. Hydroxylation by VHL is inhibited under hypoxic conditions, allowing HIF-1a to escape degradation, dimerize with HIF-1ß, and translocate to the nucleus. This results in the upregulation of hypoxic response elements, leading to angiogenesis. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can mimic the hypoxic state to promote angiogenesis by inhibiting HIF-1a hydroxylation, even in the absence of hypoxia. A researcher wants to perform an experiment to detect HIF-1a in RCC under normoxic conditions with blotting techniques. Which of the following statements are most likely to be true regarding her experiment?
A) A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.
B) A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a normoxic control cell.
C) A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a hypoxic control cell.
D) A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α, compared to a normoxic control cell.
E) A Western blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
Hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (<fact1>HIF-1a</fact1>) is a transcription factor with increased activity under conditions of cellular <fact2>hypoxia</fact2>. In <fact3>normoxia</fact3>, von Hippel-Lindau (<fact4>VHL</fact4>) protein hydroxylates prolyl residues on oxygen-dependent degradation domains of <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1>, targeting it for proteasomal degradation. Hydroxylation by <fact4>VHL</fact4> is inhibited under <fact2>hypoxic conditions</fact2>, allowing <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> to escape degradation, dimerize with HIF-1ß, and translocate to the nucleus. This results in the upregulation of hypoxic response elements, leading to <fact5>angiogenesis</fact5>. Renal cell carcinoma (<fact6>RCC</fact6>) can mimic the <fact2>hypoxic state</fact2> to promote <fact5>angiogenesis</fact5> by inhibiting <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> hydroxylation, even in the absence of <fact2>hypoxia</fact2>. A researcher wants to perform an experiment to detect <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> in <fact6>RCC</fact6> under <fact3>normoxic conditions</fact3> with blotting techniques. Which of the following statements are most likely to be true regarding her experiment?

Answer: 
Since <fact6>RCC</fact6> can mimic the <fact2>hypoxic state</fact2> even in the absence of <fact2>hypoxia</fact2>, it would lead to an increase in <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> levels due to reduced hydroxylation and subsequent degradation. Given that a Western blot is used to detect protein levels, it would show increased <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> in <fact6>RCC</fact6> under <fact3>normoxic conditions</fact3> compared to a <fact3>normoxic control cell</fact3>. A Northern blot, which detects RNA levels, might not necessarily show an increase because the issue at hand is the degradation of the <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> protein, not its transcription. A Southern blot, which detects DNA, would not be relevant for detecting changes in <fact1>HIF-1a</fact1> levels due to <fact2>hypoxia</fact2> or <fact6>RCC</fact6>. Therefore, the correct answer is {E}.

question:
A 3-week-old newborn is brought to the physician by his parents because of poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting over the past week. The vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but the patient often spits up or refuses to eat. The patient was born at term and had his first bowel movement at 50 hours of life. He has since had one bowel movement daily. He is at the 50th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 40th percentile for head circumference. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows that the patient has small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The abdomen is distended. When the finger is removed following a rectal exam, there is an explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
A) CT scan of the abdomen
B) Transabdominal ultrasonography
C) Barium enema
D) Anorectal manometry
E) Rectal suction biopsy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-week-old newborn</fact1> is brought to the physician by his parents because of <fact2>poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting</fact2> over the past week. The <fact3>vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange</fact3>. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but the patient often <fact4>spits up or refuses to eat</fact4>. The patient was born at term and had his <fact5>first bowel movement at 50 hours of life</fact5>. He has since had <fact6>one bowel movement daily</fact6>. He is at the 50th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 40th percentile for head circumference. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His <fact7>temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 140/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 40/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg</fact10>. Physical examination shows that the patient has <fact11>small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally</fact11>. The <fact12>abdomen is distended</fact12>. When the finger is removed following a rectal exam, there is an <fact13>explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum</fact13>. An <fact14>x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air</fact14>. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>3-week-old newborn</fact1> with symptoms of <fact2>poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting</fact2>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact11>small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally</fact11>, and the <fact14>x-ray of the abdomen showing a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air</fact14>, the clinical picture is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. The <fact13>explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum</fact13> upon removal of the finger following a rectal exam further supports this diagnosis. A rectal suction biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing Hirschsprung's disease as it allows for the examination of the rectal mucosa and submucosa for the absence of ganglion cells, which is characteristic of the condition. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A mother brings her 18-year-old daughter to your office because she has not menstruated yet. They recently immigrated from another country, and do not have any previous medical records. The adolescent girl looks relatively short, but otherwise looks healthy. She has no complaints except for mild intermittent lower abdominal pain for the past year. On physical examination, vitals are within normal limits. There is the presence of axillary hair, breast development, and pubic hair at Tanner stage 5. You explain to the mother and the patient that you need to perform a complete vaginal examination, however, both of them declined the procedure and would prefer that lab test be performed. Her labs are significant for the following:
FSH 7 mIU/mL
Normal values:  
   Follicular phase 3.1 – 7.9 mIU/mL
   Ovulation peak 2.3 – 18.5 mIU/mL
   Luteal phase 1.4 – 5.5 mIU/mL
   Postmenopausal 30.6 – 106.3 mIU/mL
Estradiol 28 pg/mL
Normal values:  
   Mid-follicular phase 27 – 123 pg/mL
   Periovulatory 96 – 436 pg/mL
   Mid-luteal phase 49 – 294 pg/mL
   Postmenopausal 0 – 40 pg/mL
Testosterone 52 ng/dL, 40 – 60 ng/dL
What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
A) Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI)
B) Muellerian agenesis
C) Hyperprolactinemia
D) Turner syndrome
E) Androgen insensitivity
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A mother brings her <fact1>18-year-old daughter</fact1> to your office because she has not <fact2>menstruated yet</fact2>. They recently immigrated from another country, and do not have any previous medical records. The adolescent girl looks relatively <fact3>short</fact3>, but otherwise looks healthy. She has no complaints except for <fact4>mild intermittent lower abdominal pain</fact4> for the past year. On physical examination, vitals are within normal limits. There is the presence of <fact5>axillary hair, breast development, and pubic hair at Tanner stage 5</fact5>. You explain to the mother and the patient that you need to perform a complete vaginal examination, however, both of them declined the procedure and would prefer that lab test be performed. Her labs are significant for the following:
<fact6>FSH 7 mIU/mL</fact6>
Normal values:  
   Follicular phase 3.1 – 7.9 mIU/mL
   Ovulation peak 2.3 – 18.5 mIU/mL
   Luteal phase 1.4 – 5.5 mIU/mL
   Postmenopausal 30.6 – 106.3 mIU/mL
<fact7>Estradiol 28 pg/mL</fact7>
Normal values:  
   Mid-follicular phase 27 – 123 pg/mL
   Periovulatory 96 – 436 pg/mL
   Mid-luteal phase 49 – 294 pg/mL
   Postmenopausal 0 – 40 pg/mL
<fact8>Testosterone 52 ng/dL, 40 – 60 ng/dL</fact8>
What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

Answer:
Considering the patient's age of <fact1>18 years</fact1> and lack of <fact2>menstruation</fact2>, along with her physical development of <fact5>axillary hair, breast development, and pubic hair at Tanner stage 5</fact5>, it suggests that she has undergone normal secondary sexual development but may have an issue with her reproductive system. The presence of <fact4>mild intermittent lower abdominal pain</fact4> could be indicative of a structural issue. The normal <fact6>FSH level of 7 mIU/mL</fact6> and <fact7>estradiol level of 28 pg/mL</fact7> within the normal range for the mid-follicular phase suggest that ovarian function is likely intact. The normal <fact8>testosterone level of 52 ng/dL</fact8> also supports this. Given these factors, the most likely diagnosis is Muellerian agenesis, a condition where the Muellerian ducts fail to develop, leading to the absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and vagina, which would explain the lack of menstruation despite normal secondary sexual development and hormone levels. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He reports that one hour ago he was climbing the stairs in his home when he suddenly developed excruciating chest pain. He describes the pain as ripping and radiating to the back. The patient’s past medical history is significant for a heart murmur that is being followed by his outpatient cardiologist. He takes no medications. The patient works as a carpenter and reports being monogamous with his wife. He denies any history of intravenous drug use or recent travel. In the emergency department, the patient’s temperature is 99.4°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 94/56 mmHg, pulse is 121/min, and respirations are 14/min. On physical exam, the patient appears to be in moderate distress and is clutching his chest. He is tall and has joint hypermobility. His breath sounds are equal and full bilaterally and has weak distal pulses.

Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?
A) Holosystolic, high-pitched blowing murmur at the lower left sternal border
B) Late systolic crescendo murmur at the apex with mid-systolic click
C) Mid-diastolic murmur at the apex with opening snap
D) Mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border
E) Systolic ejection murmur at the right second intercostal space
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>28-year-old male</fact1> presents to the emergency department with <fact2>chest pain</fact2>. He reports that one hour ago he was climbing the stairs in his home when he suddenly developed <fact3>excruciating chest pain</fact3>. He describes the pain as <fact4>ripping and radiating to the back</fact4>. The patient’s past medical history is significant for a <fact5>heart murmur</fact5> that is being followed by his outpatient cardiologist. He takes no medications. The patient works as a carpenter and reports being monogamous with his wife. He denies any history of intravenous drug use or recent travel. In the emergency department, the patient’s <fact6>temperature is 99.4°F (37.4°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 94/56 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 121/min</fact8>, and <fact9>respirations are 14/min</fact9>. On physical exam, the patient appears to be in moderate distress and is clutching his chest. He is tall and has <fact10>joint hypermobility</fact10>. His breath sounds are equal and full bilaterally and has <fact11>weak distal pulses</fact11>.

Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>chest pain</fact2> described as <fact4>ripping and radiating to the back</fact4>, along with the patient's history of a <fact5>heart murmur</fact5> and physical characteristics such as <fact10>joint hypermobility</fact10>, the most likely diagnosis is an aortic dissection. This condition is often associated with Marfan syndrome, which is also suggested by the patient's tall stature and joint hypermobility. Aortic dissection can lead to aortic regurgitation, which would be manifested as a diastolic murmur. Among the options provided, a mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border is the most consistent with aortic regurgitation. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of nausea and vomiting. Over the past 2 days, he has also been feeling weak and tired. When standing up after sitting for a while, he feels dizzy. He says he has to go to the bathroom more often than usual, and that he is urinating “a normal amount” each time. He has not had diarrhea. He has hypertension, for which he has been taking hydrochlorothiazide for the past 6 months. He drinks 9 glasses of water per day and takes his medication regularly. He is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 106/54 mm Hg, and pulse is 92/min. Physical examination shows whitening of the tongue. Skin that is pinched on the back of the hand retracts after 5 seconds. On mental status examination, his speech is slowed; he is oriented to person, place, and time. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Na+ 150 mEq/L
Cl− 97 mEq/L
K+ 3.6 mEq/L
HCO3− 30 mEq/L
Osmolality 354 mOsm/kg
Hemoglobin A1C 10.5%
Urine
Osmolality 400 mOsm/kg
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?"
A) Diuretic overdose
B) Osmotic diuresis
C) Gastroinstestinal fluid loss
D) Excess production of aldosterone
E) Insufficient production of antidiuretic hormone
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>75-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>7-day history of nausea and vomiting</fact2>. Over the past <fact3>2 days</fact3>, he has also been feeling <fact4>weak and tired</fact4>. When standing up after sitting for a while, he feels <fact5>dizzy</fact5>. He says he has to go to the bathroom more often than usual, and that he is urinating “a normal amount” each time. He has not had <fact6>diarrhea</fact6>. He has <fact7>hypertension</fact7>, for which he has been taking <fact8>hydrochlorothiazide</fact8> for the past <fact9>6 months</fact9>. He drinks <fact10>9 glasses of water per day</fact10> and takes his medication regularly. He is <fact11>168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall</fact11> and weighs <fact12>90 kg (198 lb)</fact12>; BMI is <fact13>32 kg/m2</fact13>. His <fact14>temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F)</fact14>, <fact15>blood pressure is 106/54 mm Hg</fact15>, and <fact16>pulse is 92/min</fact16>. Physical examination shows <fact17>whitening of the tongue</fact17>. Skin that is pinched on the back of the hand retracts after <fact18>5 seconds</fact18>. On mental status examination, his speech is <fact19>slowed</fact19>; he is oriented to person, place, and time. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
<fact20>Na+ 150 mEq/L</fact20>
<fact21>Cl− 97 mEq/L</fact21>
<fact22>K+ 3.6 mEq/L</fact22>
<fact23>HCO3− 30 mEq/L</fact23>
<fact24>Osmolality 354 mOsm/kg</fact24>
<fact25>Hemoglobin A1C 10.5%</fact25>
Urine
<fact26>Osmolality 400 mOsm/kg</fact26>
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

Answer: Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>75-year-old man</fact1> presents with symptoms of <fact2>nausea and vomiting</fact2> for <fact3>7 days</fact3>, along with <fact4>weakness and tiredness</fact4> over the past <fact3>2 days</fact3>, and <fact5>dizziness</fact5> upon standing. His laboratory results show <fact20>elevated serum sodium</fact20> and <fact24>osmolality</fact24>, indicating hypernatremia and hyperosmolality. Additionally, his <fact25>hemoglobin A1C is 10.5%</fact25>, suggesting poorly controlled diabetes. The presence of <fact17>whitening of the tongue</fact17> and <fact19>slowed speech</fact19> may indicate dehydration. However, the <fact26>urine osmolality is 400 mOsm/kg</fact26>, which is not consistent with dehydration caused by insufficient production of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) or gastrointestinal fluid loss. The <fact26>high urine osmolality</fact26> suggests that the kidneys are able to concentrate urine properly, which is not typical in cases of ADH insufficiency. Considering the <fact25>high hemoglobin A1C</fact25> and the <fact26>high urine osmolality</fact26>, the most likely explanation for these findings is osmotic diuresis due to uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, leading to the observed hypernatremia and hyperosmolality. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with increasing swelling of his right jaw for the past 2 months. She notes that he has been treated several times with different antibiotics, but that they have not helped. She reports no recent history of fever, chills, or night sweats. The boy has no significant medical history. He emigrated to the United States with his family from Nigeria 1 month ago. He is in the 85th percentile for height and weight, and he has been meeting all developmental milestones. His temperature is 37.8℃ (100.0℉). On physical examination, the patient has a prominent 8 × 8 cm mass over the right mandible. The mass has partially distorted the borders of the mandible and cheek. The overlying skin is erythematous. The mass is firm, immobile, and tender. The contralateral side of the face shows no abnormalities. An oral examination shows the disruption of the ipsilateral lower teeth and oral mucosa. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A biopsy of the mass is performed and a histopathologic analysis is seen in the image. Which of the following microorganisms is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?
A) Babesia microti
B) Bartonella henselae
C) Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
D) Epstein barr virus (EBV)
E) Yersinia pestis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>7-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the clinic by his mother with a <fact2>2-month history of increasing swelling of his right jaw</fact2>. She notes that he has been treated several times with different <fact3>antibiotics, but that they have not helped</fact3>. She reports no recent history of <fact4>fever, chills, or night sweats</fact4>. The boy has no significant medical history. He <fact5>emigrated to the United States with his family from Nigeria 1 month ago</fact5>. He is in the <fact6>85th percentile for height and weight</fact6>, and he has been meeting all <fact7>developmental milestones</fact7>. His <fact8>temperature is 37.8℃ (100.0℉)</fact8>. On physical examination, the patient has a prominent <fact9>8 × 8 cm mass over the right mandible</fact9>. The mass has partially distorted the borders of the <fact10>mandible and cheek</fact10>. The overlying <fact11>skin is erythematous</fact11>. The mass is <fact12>firm, immobile, and tender</fact12>. The contralateral side of the face shows no abnormalities. An <fact13>oral examination shows the disruption of the ipsilateral lower teeth and oral mucosa</fact13>. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A <fact14>biopsy of the mass is performed and a histopathologic analysis</fact14> is seen in the image. Which of the following microorganisms is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>2-month history of increasing swelling of his right jaw</fact2> that has not responded to <fact3>antibiotics</fact3>, along with the physical examination findings of a prominent <fact9>8 × 8 cm mass over the right mandible</fact9> with <fact11>erythematous skin</fact11> and <fact12>tender to the touch</fact12>, and the <fact14>histopathologic analysis from the biopsy</fact14>, the clinical presentation is suggestive of a malignant process, specifically Burkitt lymphoma. This type of lymphoma is known to be associated with <fact15>Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)</fact15> infection, especially in endemic regions such as Africa, which aligns with the patient's <fact5>recent emigration from Nigeria</fact5>. Therefore, the microorganism most likely associated with this patient's condition is {D}.

question:
A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 1 day. Computed tomography shows a small bowel perforation. The patient is prepared for emergent exploratory laparotomy. She is sedated with midazolam, induced with propofol, intubated, and maintained on nitrous oxide and isoflurane for the duration of the surgery. A single perforation in the terminal ileum is diagnosed intraoperatively and successfully repaired. The patient is transferred to the intensive care unit. The ventilator is set at an FiO2 of 50%, tidal volume of 1000 mL, respiratory rate of 12/min, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 2.5 cm H2O. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 111/50 mm Hg. She is responsive to painful stimuli. Lung examination shows bilateral rales. Abdominal examination shows a distended abdomen and intact abdominal surgical incisions. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH 7.44
pO2 54 mm Hg
pCO2 31 mm Hg
HCO3- 22 mm Hg
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?"
A) Increase the FiO2
B) Extubate
C) Increase the tidal volume
D) Increase PEEP
E) Increase the respiratory rate
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>70-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of <fact2>abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting</fact2> for 1 day. Computed tomography shows a <fact3>small bowel perforation</fact3>. The patient is prepared for emergent exploratory laparotomy. She is sedated with midazolam, induced with propofol, intubated, and maintained on nitrous oxide and isoflurane for the duration of the surgery. A single <fact4>perforation in the terminal ileum</fact4> is diagnosed intraoperatively and successfully repaired. The patient is transferred to the intensive care unit. The ventilator is set at an <fact5>FiO2 of 50%</fact5>, <fact6>tidal volume of 1000 mL</fact6>, <fact7>respiratory rate of 12/min</fact7>, and <fact8>positive end-expiratory pressure of 2.5 cm H2O</fact8>. Her <fact9>temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F)</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 76/min</fact10>, and <fact11>blood pressure is 111/50 mm Hg</fact11>. She is responsive to painful stimuli. Lung examination shows <fact12>bilateral rales</fact12>. Abdominal examination shows a <fact13>distended abdomen</fact13> and intact abdominal surgical incisions. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis shows:
<fact14>pH 7.44</fact14>
<fact15>pO2 54 mm Hg</fact15>
<fact16>pCO2 31 mm Hg</fact16>
<fact17>HCO3- 22 mm Hg</fact17>
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact15>pO2 of 54 mm Hg</fact15> on an <fact5>FiO2 of 50%</fact5>, this indicates hypoxemia that requires adjustment of the ventilator settings. Additionally, the presence of <fact12>bilateral rales</fact12> on lung examination suggests that increasing the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) could help in improving oxygenation by preventing alveolar collapse. Therefore, the best next step in the management of this patient is to increase the PEEP. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent painful retrosternal dullness for 4 weeks. The pain is recurrent and occurs when she exerts herself or when she is outside during cold weather. She also experiences shortness of breath and palpitations during these episodes. The symptoms resolve spontaneously when she stops or sits down for a while. Over the past few days, the episodes have increased in frequency.
