She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and osteoarthritis. Her left leg was amputated below the knee after a motorcycle accident 25 years ago. She is currently waiting for a new prosthesis and walks with crutches. Current medications include captopril, glyburide, and ibuprofen. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 144/90 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm without any signs of ischemia. Serum cardiac markers are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
A) Myocardial perfusion scan under pharmacological stress
B) Upper endoscopy
C) Coronary angiography
D) Echocardiography at rest
E) Repeat ECG under treadmill stress
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>58-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>intermittent painful retrosternal dullness for 4 weeks</fact2>. The <fact3>pain is recurrent and occurs when she exerts herself or when she is outside during cold weather</fact3>. She also experiences <fact4>shortness of breath and palpitations during these episodes</fact4>. The <fact5>symptoms resolve spontaneously when she stops or sits down for a while</fact5>. Over the past few days, the <fact6>episodes have increased in frequency</fact6>. She has <fact7>hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and osteoarthritis</fact7>. Her <fact8>left leg was amputated below the knee after a motorcycle accident 25 years ago</fact8>. She is currently waiting for a new prosthesis and walks with crutches. Current medications include captopril, glyburide, and ibuprofen. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her <fact9>pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 144/90 mm Hg</fact9>. <fact10>Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities</fact10>. An <fact11>x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities</fact11>. An <fact12>ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm without any signs of ischemia</fact12>. <fact13>Serum cardiac markers are within the reference range</fact13>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

Answer: 
Given the <fact1>58-year-old woman's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>intermittent painful retrosternal dullness for 4 weeks</fact2> that <fact3>occur with exertion or cold weather</fact3> and are accompanied by <fact4>shortness of breath and palpitations</fact4>, there is a high suspicion for coronary artery disease, especially considering her <fact7>history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact7>. However, her <fact8>inability to perform a treadmill stress test due to her amputated left leg</fact8> limits the use of exercise-based diagnostic methods. The <fact12>normal ECG without signs of ischemia</fact12> and <fact13>normal serum cardiac markers</fact13> do not rule out coronary artery disease but suggest that an acute myocardial infarction is unlikely. Given these factors, the most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be to perform a myocardial perfusion scan under pharmacological stress, which does not require physical exertion and can provide valuable information about myocardial blood flow. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
An 80-year-old man is transferred from a step-down unit to a med-surg floor in the hospital. He had undergone a successful hernia surgery 14 hours ago. Before the surgery, he was pre-treated with atropine, scopolamine, and morphine and recovered well in the PACU after the surgery. There were no complications in the step-down unit and the patient continued to recover. On the med-surg floor, his temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), the heart rate is 98/min, the respiratory rate is 15/min, the blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg, the oxygen saturation is 90%. On physical exam, he is a well-developed, obese man. His heart has a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. His incision site is clean, dry, and intact with an appropriate level of swelling and erythema. During the physical, the patient mentions some discomfort in his abdomen and pelvis and during a records review it is noted that he has not passed urine in the PACU, step-down unit, or since arriving on the med-surg floor. A bladder scan is inconclusive due to body habitus. What is the next best step in the treatment of this patient?
A) Insert a ‘straight cath’ into the patient’s bladder
B) Ultrasound the surgical site
C) Aggressive IV fluids
D) Digital rectal exam
E) Renal ultrasound
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An <fact1>80-year-old man</fact1> is transferred from a step-down unit to a med-surg floor in the hospital. He had undergone a <fact2>successful hernia surgery 14 hours ago</fact2>. Before the surgery, he was pre-treated with <fact3>atropine, scopolamine, and morphine</fact3> and recovered well in the PACU after the surgery. There were no complications in the step-down unit and the patient continued to recover. On the med-surg floor, his <fact4>temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F)</fact4>, the <fact5>heart rate is 98/min</fact5>, the <fact6>respiratory rate is 15/min</fact6>, the <fact7>blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg</fact7>, the <fact8>oxygen saturation is 90%</fact8>. On physical exam, he is a well-developed, obese man. His heart has a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. His incision site is clean, dry, and intact with an appropriate level of swelling and erythema. During the physical, the patient mentions some discomfort in his abdomen and pelvis and during a records review it is noted that he has <fact9>not passed urine in the PACU, step-down unit, or since arriving on the med-surg floor</fact9>. A <fact10>bladder scan is inconclusive due to body habitus</fact10>. What is the next best step in the treatment of this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact9>inability to pass urine since the surgery</fact9> and the <fact10>inconclusive bladder scan due to body habitus</fact10>, it is essential to assess for urinary retention, which is a common postoperative complication, especially in patients who have received <fact3>opioids like morphine</fact3> that can cause urinary retention. Given these factors, the next best step is to insert a 'straight cath' into the patient's bladder to evaluate for urinary retention and to potentially relieve it. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 16-year-old patient presents to the physician’s office with an absence of menstruations. Her last period was 6 months ago. Since almost a year and a half ago, she intentionally restricted her diet at the expense of carbohydrates, exercised intensively, and lost 18.0 kg (39.7 lb). She had her menarche at the age of 12 and menstruated normally until last year. She is not sexually active. On physical examination, the vital signs include blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate 55/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and temperature 35.9°C (96.6°F). Her weight is 55.0 kg (121.3 lb), and her height is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in). Physical examination reveals the good development of muscles and decreased adiposity. A bone scan shows decreased calcium mineral deposits. Which statement about this patient’s condition is correct?
A) Hypertrophied muscles are the source of additional androgens which interfere with the patient’s menstrual cycle
B) This patient has insulin resistance
C) Decreased adiposity contributes to hypoestrogenemia in this patient
D) The patient is likely to have decreased blood estrogen concentration due to increased liver metabolism
E) The patient should be checked for hyperthyroidism because such extensive lipolysis is likely to result from thyroid hyperfunction
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>16-year-old patient</fact1> presents to the physician’s office with an <fact2>absence of menstruations</fact2>. Her last period was <fact3>6 months ago</fact3>. Since almost a year and a half ago, she <fact4>intentionally restricted her diet at the expense of carbohydrates, exercised intensively, and lost 18.0 kg (39.7 lb)</fact4>. She had her <fact5>menarche at the age of 12</fact5> and menstruated normally until last year. She is not sexually active. On physical examination, the vital signs include <fact6>blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate 55/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and temperature 35.9°C (96.6°F)</fact6>. Her <fact7>weight is 55.0 kg (121.3 lb)</fact7>, and her <fact8>height is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in)</fact8>. Physical examination reveals the <fact9>good development of muscles and decreased adiposity</fact9>. A <fact10>bone scan shows decreased calcium mineral deposits</fact10>. Which statement about this patient’s condition is correct?

A) Hypertrophied muscles are the source of additional androgens which interfere with the patient’s menstrual cycle
B) This patient has insulin resistance
C) Decreased adiposity contributes to hypoestrogenemia in this patient
D) The patient is likely to have decreased blood estrogen concentration due to increased liver metabolism
E) The patient should be checked for hyperthyroidism because such extensive lipolysis is likely to result from thyroid hyperfunction

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>16-year-old patient</fact1> presents with an <fact2>absence of menstruations</fact2> for <fact3>6 months</fact3>, which started after she <fact4>restricted her diet, exercised intensively, and lost a significant amount of weight</fact4>. Her physical examination reveals <fact9>good development of muscles and decreased adiposity</fact9>, and a <fact10>bone scan shows decreased calcium mineral deposits</fact10>. The most plausible explanation for her condition is related to her decreased body fat. Adipose tissue plays a crucial role in the production of estrogen through the aromatization of androgens. With decreased adiposity, there is less tissue available for this conversion, leading to lower estrogen levels. Therefore, option C, which states that decreased adiposity contributes to hypoestrogenemia in this patient, is the correct answer.

question:
A previously healthy 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of an abdominal mass noticed a few days ago. He appears markedly pale and lethargic. Examination shows a 6-cm, nonmobile mass in the left upper quadrant that crosses the midline. 24-hour urine collection shows elevated homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid. Further evaluation including biopsy confirms the diagnosis of intermediate-risk neuroblastoma. The physician recommends the established standard treatment, which is initiation of neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgical resection, if possible. After a thorough discussion of the risks and benefits of chemotherapy, the likelihood of unresectability without neoadjuvant treatment, and the prognosis without it, the patient's parents steadily refuse chemotherapy because they do not want their son to suffer the side effects. They prefer to take their son home for supportive care only. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
A) Help the parents to arrange supportive care at home
B) Refer the patient to another oncologist
C) Recommend for parents to take 2 weeks to think about decision
D) Seek a court order for neoadjuvant chemotherapy
E) Attempt surgical resection of the tumor
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A previously healthy <fact1>18-month-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of an <fact2>abdominal mass noticed a few days ago</fact2>. He appears markedly <fact3>pale and lethargic</fact3>. Examination shows a <fact4>6-cm, nonmobile mass in the left upper quadrant that crosses the midline</fact4>. <fact5>24-hour urine collection</fact5> shows elevated <fact6>homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid</fact6>. Further evaluation including biopsy confirms the diagnosis of <fact7>intermediate-risk neuroblastoma</fact7>. The physician recommends the established standard treatment, which is initiation of <fact8>neoadjuvant chemotherapy</fact8> followed by <fact9>surgical resection, if possible</fact9>. After a thorough discussion of the <fact10>risks and benefits of chemotherapy</fact10>, the likelihood of <fact11>unresectability without neoadjuvant treatment</fact11>, and the <fact12>prognosis without it</fact12>, the patient's parents steadily <fact13>refuse chemotherapy</fact13> because they do not want their son to suffer the side effects. They prefer to take their son home for <fact14>supportive care only</fact14>. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

Answer: 
Given the diagnosis of <fact7>intermediate-risk neuroblastoma</fact7> and the established standard treatment of <fact8>neoadjuvant chemotherapy</fact8> followed by <fact9>surgical resection, if possible</fact9>, the parents' decision to <fact13>refuse chemotherapy</fact13> poses a significant risk to the child's health and well-being. The physician has a responsibility to act in the best interest of the child. Since the parents' decision is not in the best interest of the child, and given the <fact12>prognosis without</fact8> chemotherapy, the most appropriate action by the physician is to <fact15>seek a court order for neoadjuvant chemotherapy</fact15>. This option is not explicitly listed as a fact, but it is the most appropriate course of action given the circumstances described in the question. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
Two hours after admission to the hospital for rupture of membranes, a 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 40 weeks’ gestation is evaluated for the sudden onset of chills, dyspnea, confusion, and hypotension. The patient successfully underwent combined spinal-epidural anesthesia 1 hour ago. Her pregnancy was uncomplicated with the exception of a positive vaginal swab for group B streptococci 3 weeks ago, for which she received one dose of intravenous penicillin. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 70/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Physical examination shows labored breathing and thready pulses. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. The abdomen is nontender. Speculum examination shows pooling of bright red blood in the cervical canal. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 7.6 mg/dL and an undetectable fibrinogen concentration. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition?
A) Apical ballooning of the left ventricle
B) Allergic reaction to anesthetic agent
C) Amniotic fluid entering the endocervical veins
D) Anesthetic agent entering the subarachnoid space
E) Systemic bacterial infection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
Two hours after admission to the hospital for <fact1>rupture of membranes</fact1>, a <fact2>35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 40 weeks’ gestation</fact2> is evaluated for the sudden onset of <fact3>chills, dyspnea, confusion, and hypotension</fact3>. The patient successfully underwent <fact4>combined spinal-epidural anesthesia 1 hour ago</fact4>. Her pregnancy was uncomplicated with the exception of a <fact5>positive vaginal swab for group B streptococci 3 weeks ago</fact5>, for which she received one dose of intravenous penicillin. Her <fact6>temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F)</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 130/min</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 30/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 70/30 mm Hg</fact9>. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an <fact10>oxygen saturation of 82%</fact10>. Physical examination shows <fact11>labored breathing and thready pulses</fact11>. <fact12>Crackles are heard at both lung bases</fact12>. The abdomen is nontender. Speculum examination shows <fact13>pooling of bright red blood in the cervical canal</fact13>. Laboratory studies show a <fact14>hemoglobin concentration of 7.6 mg/dL</fact14> and an <fact15>undetectable fibrinogen concentration</fact15>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's sudden onset of <fact3>chills, dyspnea, confusion, and hypotension</fact3> after a recent <fact1>rupture of membranes</fact1> and <fact4>combined spinal-epidural anesthesia</fact4>, along with the presence of <fact12>crackles at both lung bases</fact12> and <fact13>pooling of bright red blood in the cervical canal</fact13>, the clinical picture suggests a severe coagulopathy. The laboratory findings of a significantly low <fact14>hemoglobin concentration of 7.6 mg/dL</fact14> and an <fact15>undetectable fibrinogen concentration</fact15> further support this diagnosis. Given these factors, the most likely underlying cause is amniotic fluid embolism, where <fact16>amniotic fluid enters the endocervical veins</fact16>, triggering a severe coagulopathic response. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 53-year-old man presents to his physician’s office with a persistent cough which he has had over the last few months. He was diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) the previous year and since then has been on a short-acting β-agonist to help alleviate his symptoms. Since his diagnosis, he has quit smoking, a habit which he had developed about 30 years ago. He used to smoke about 2 packs of cigarettes daily. Today, he has come in with an increase in his symptoms. He tells his physician that he has been having a fever for the past 3 days, ranging between 37.8°–39°C (100°F–102.2°F). Along with this, he has a persistent cough with copious amounts of greenish-yellow sputum. He has also been having difficulty breathing. On examination, his temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), the respirations are 22/min, the blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and the pulse is 115/min. Slight crackles and respiratory wheezes are prominent in the lower lung fields. His FEV1 is 57% of his normal predicted value. He is started on oxygen and a dose of oral prednisone. At this time, which of the following should also be considered as a treatment option?
A) Doxycycline
B) Ciprofloxacin
C) Erythromycin
D) Piperacillin
E) Antibiotics would not be appropriate at this time
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>53-year-old man</fact1> presents to his physician’s office with a <fact2>persistent cough</fact2> which he has had over the last few months. He was diagnosed with <fact3>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)</fact3> the previous year and since then has been on a <fact4>short-acting β-agonist</fact4> to help alleviate his symptoms. Since his diagnosis, he has quit <fact5>smoking</fact5>, a habit which he had developed about 30 years ago. He used to smoke about 2 packs of cigarettes daily. Today, he has come in with an increase in his symptoms. He tells his physician that he has been having a <fact6>fever for the past 3 days</fact6>, ranging between 37.8°–39°C (100°F–102.2°F). Along with this, he has a <fact7>persistent cough with copious amounts of greenish-yellow sputum</fact7>. He has also been having <fact8>difficulty breathing</fact8>. On examination, his <fact9>temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F)</fact9>, the <fact10>respirations are 22/min</fact10>, the <fact11>blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg</fact11>, and the <fact12>pulse is 115/min</fact12>. <fact13>Slight crackles and respiratory wheezes</fact13> are prominent in the lower lung fields. His <fact14>FEV1 is 57% of his normal predicted value</fact14>. He is started on <fact15>oxygen</fact15> and a dose of oral <fact16>prednisone</fact16>. At this time, which of the following should also be considered as a treatment option?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of a <fact2>persistent cough</fact2> with <fact7>copious amounts of greenish-yellow sputum</fact7>, <fact6>fever for the past 3 days</fact6>, and <fact8>difficulty breathing</fact8>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact13>slight crackles and respiratory wheezes</fact13> and a <fact14>FEV1 of 57% of his normal predicted value</fact14>, it is likely that the patient is experiencing an acute exacerbation of his <fact3>COPD</fact3>. Given the presence of purulent sputum and fever, this exacerbation is likely due to a bacterial infection. Therefore, the addition of an antibiotic to his treatment regimen would be appropriate. Among the options provided, doxycycline is a suitable choice for treating bacterial infections in COPD exacerbations. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of pallor and rash for 2 days. She had a 4-day history of diarrhea and vomiting that subsided two days ago. One month ago, she had a 3-day episode of high fever, followed by a rash with bright red discoloration over her cheeks for two days before subsiding without treatment. Her vaccinations are up-to-date. She appears pale and irritable. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows petechiae on her trunk and extremities. Abdominal examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness with hyperactive bowel sounds. The remainder of the exam shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 82 fL
Leukocyte count 17,000/mm3
Platelet count 49,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 12 seconds
Partial thromboplastin time 34 seconds
Serum
Urea nitrogen 42 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 3 mg/dL
Indirect 2.8 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase 300 U/L
Urine
Blood 2+
Protein 2+
A peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?"
A) Escherichia coli infection
B) Parvovirus B19 infection
C) Disseminated intravascular coagulation
D) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
E) Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>4-year-old girl</fact1> is brought to the physician because of <fact2>pallor and rash for 2 days</fact2>. She had a <fact3>4-day history of diarrhea and vomiting</fact3> that subsided two days ago. One month ago, she had a <fact4>3-day episode of high fever, followed by a rash with bright red discoloration over her cheeks</fact4> for two days before subsiding without treatment. Her vaccinations are up-to-date. She appears pale and irritable. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows <fact5>petechiae on her trunk and extremities</fact5>. Abdominal examination shows <fact6>diffuse abdominal tenderness with hyperactive bowel sounds</fact6>. The remainder of the exam shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: 
<fact7>Hemoglobin 8 g/dL</fact7>
<fact8>Mean corpuscular volume 82 fL</fact8>
<fact9>Leukocyte count 17,000/mm3</fact9>
<fact10>Platelet count 49,000/mm3</fact10>
<fact11>Prothrombin time 12 seconds</fact11>
<fact12>Partial thromboplastin time 34 seconds</fact12>
Serum
<fact13>Urea nitrogen 42 mg/dL</fact13>
<fact14>Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL</fact14>
Bilirubin
<fact15>Total 3 mg/dL</fact15>
<fact16>Indirect 2.8 mg/dL</fact16>
<fact17>Lactate dehydrogenase 300 U/L</fact17>
Urine
<fact18>Blood 2+</fact18>
<fact19>Protein 2+</fact19>
A peripheral blood smear shows <fact20>schistocytes</fact20>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>4-year-old girl's</fact1> presentation of <fact2>pallor and rash for 2 days</fact2>, along with a history of <fact3>4-day history of diarrhea and vomiting</fact3> and a previous episode of <fact4>high fever and rash</fact4>, her condition appears to be a complex systemic disorder. The presence of <fact5>petechiae on her trunk and extremities</fact5> and <fact6>diffuse abdominal tenderness with hyperactive bowel sounds</fact6> suggests a possible coagulopathy or vasculitis. Laboratory findings, including a low <fact7>hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL</fact7>, a normal <fact8>mean corpuscular volume</fact8>, an elevated <fact9>leukocyte count</fact9>, and a significantly low <fact10>platelet count of 49,000/mm3</fact10>, support this. Additionally, the presence of <fact20>schistocytes</fact20> on the peripheral blood smear is indicative of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, a hallmark of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). The combination of these clinical and laboratory findings makes TTP the most likely underlying cause of her condition. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 39-year-old woman with poorly controlled systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents to her rheumatologist for a follow-up visit. She has had intermittent myalgias, arthralgias, fatigue, and skin rashes over the past 10 years that have acutely worsened over the past year. She works as a school teacher but reports that she has had to miss several days of work due to her symptoms. She has been on hydroxychloroquine for several years but does not feel that it is adequately controlling her symptoms. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 18/min. On exam, she is well-appearing and in no acute distress. She has erythematous, raised plaques with keratotic scaling and follicular plugging on her hands. The physician decides to trial the patient on low-dose prednisone to better control her symptoms. At 2 months of follow-up, she reports that her flares have subsided and she has been able to return to work full-time. If this patient continues this medication regimen, she will be at an elevated risk for developing which of the following?
A) Femoral neck fracture
B) Femoral shaft fracture
C) Meniscal tear
D) Osgood-Schlatter disease
E) Proximal phalanx fracture
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>39-year-old woman</fact1> with <fact2>poorly controlled systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)</fact2> presents to her rheumatologist for a follow-up visit. She has had <fact3>intermittent myalgias, arthralgias, fatigue, and skin rashes</fact3> over the past 10 years that have <fact4>acutely worsened over the past year</fact4>. She works as a school teacher but reports that she has had to miss several days of work due to her symptoms. She has been on <fact5>hydroxychloroquine</fact5> for several years but does not feel that it is adequately controlling her symptoms. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her <fact6>temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 80/min</fact8>, and <fact9>respirations are 18/min</fact9>. On exam, she is well-appearing and in no acute distress. She has <fact10>erythematous, raised plaques with keratotic scaling and follicular plugging on her hands</fact10>. The physician decides to trial the patient on <fact11>low-dose prednisone</fact11> to better control her symptoms. At <fact12>2 months of follow-up</fact12>, she reports that her flares have subsided and she has been able to return to work full-time. If this patient continues this medication regimen, she will be at an elevated risk for developing which of the following?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>poorly controlled systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)</fact2> and the initiation of <fact11>low-dose prednisone</fact11> to manage her symptoms, long-term use of prednisone is associated with an increased risk of osteoporosis. Osteoporosis can lead to an elevated risk of fractures, particularly in weight-bearing bones. Among the options provided, a femoral neck fracture is a common complication of osteoporosis. Therefore, the patient will be at an elevated risk for developing a femoral neck fracture if she continues this medication regimen. The answer is {A}.

question:
An 81-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her son after witnessing the patient fall and hit her head. The son reports that the patient was in her usual state of health until she complained of chest palpitations. This startled her while she was climbing down the stairs and lead to a fall. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and atrial fibrillation. Medications are lisinopril, metoprolol, and warfarin. Temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 152/96 mmHg, pulse is 60/min, respirations are 12/min, and pulse oximetry is 98% on room air. On physical examination, she is disoriented and at times difficult to arouse, the left pupil is 6 mm and non-reactive to light, and the right pupil is 2 mm and reactive to light. A right-sided visual field defect is appreciated on visual field testing. There is 1/5 strength on the right upper and lower extremity; as well as 5/5 strength in the left upper and lower extremity. A computerized tomography (CT) scan of the head is shown. Which of the following most likely explains this patient’s symptoms?
A) Herniation of the uncus
B) Herniation of the cingulate gyrus
C) Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery
D) Occlusion of the basilar artery
E) Occlusion of the anterior spinal artery
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An <fact1>81-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency room by her son after witnessing the patient <fact2>fall and hit her head</fact2>. The son reports that the patient was in her usual state of health until she complained of <fact3>chest palpitations</fact3>. This startled her while she was climbing down the stairs and led to a fall. Past medical history is significant for <fact4>hypertension and atrial fibrillation</fact4>. Medications are <fact5>lisinopril, metoprolol, and warfarin</fact5>. <fact6>Temperature is 99°F (37.2°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 152/96 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 60/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 12/min</fact9>, and <fact10>pulse oximetry is 98% on room air</fact10>. On physical examination, she is <fact11>disoriented and at times difficult to arouse</fact11>, the <fact12>left pupil is 6 mm and non-reactive to light</fact12>, and the <fact13>right pupil is 2 mm and reactive to light</fact13>. A <fact14>right-sided visual field defect</fact14> is appreciated on visual field testing. There is <fact15>1/5 strength on the right upper and lower extremity</fact15>; as well as <fact16>5/5 strength in the left upper and lower extremity</fact16>. A computerized tomography (CT) scan of the head is shown. Which of the following most likely explains this patient’s symptoms?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the patient's symptoms of being <fact11>disoriented and at times difficult to arouse</fact11>, having a <fact12>left pupil that is 6 mm and non-reactive to light</fact12>, and a <fact14>right-sided visual field defect</fact14>, along with <fact15>weakness on the right upper and lower extremity</fact15>, suggest a significant intracranial event. Given the history of <fact4>hypertension and atrial fibrillation</fact4> and the use of anticoagulation with <fact5>warfarin</fact5>, the patient is at high risk for intracranial hemorrhage. The presence of <fact12>anisocoria (unequal pupil sizes)</fact12> and a <fact14>visual field defect</fact14> indicates a possible mass effect causing herniation. Among the options, the most likely explanation for the patient's symptoms is herniation of the uncus, which can cause compression of the oculomotor nerve leading to pupillary dilation and can also affect visual pathways leading to field defects. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of a sharp pain that radiates along his right hemithorax, which worsens with deep inspiration. He says this started abruptly about 6 hours ago. He says that he has not noticed that anything that makes his pain better or worse. He also denies any other symptoms. He works as a long-haul truck driver, and he informs you that he recently returned to the east coast from a trip to Utah. His medical history is significant for gout, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus type 2, and acute lymphoblastic leukemia from when he was a child. He currently smokes 2 packs of cigarettes/day, drinks a 6-pack of beer/day, and he denies any illicit drug use. The vital signs include: temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), blood pressure 126/74 mm Hg, heart rate 98/min, and respiratory rate 23/min. His physical examination shows minimal bibasilar rales, but otherwise clear lungs on auscultation, normal heart sounds, and a benign abdominal physical examination. Which of the following is the most reasonable 1st step towards ruling out the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in a low-risk patient?
A) ECG
B) V/Q scan
C) D-dimer
D) Lower extremity venous ultrasound
E) CT pulmonary angiogram with IV contrast
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>39-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency department complaining of a <fact2>sharp pain that radiates along his right hemithorax, which worsens with deep inspiration</fact2>. He says this started <fact3>abruptly about 6 hours ago</fact3>. He says that he has not noticed that anything that makes his pain better or worse. He also denies any other symptoms. He works as a <fact4>long-haul truck driver</fact4>, and he informs you that he recently returned to the east coast from a trip to Utah. His medical history is significant for <fact5>gout, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus type 2, and acute lymphoblastic leukemia</fact5> from when he was a child. He currently <fact6>smokes 2 packs of cigarettes/day</fact6>, drinks a <fact7>6-pack of beer/day</fact7>, and he denies any illicit drug use. The vital signs include: <fact8>temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure 126/74 mm Hg</fact9>, <fact10>heart rate 98/min</fact10>, and <fact11>respiratory rate 23/min</fact11>. His physical examination shows <fact12>minimal bibasilar rales</fact12>, but otherwise clear lungs on auscultation, normal heart sounds, and a benign abdominal physical examination. Which of the following is the most reasonable 1st step towards ruling out the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in a low-risk patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>sharp pain that radiates along his right hemithorax, which worsens with deep inspiration</fact2>, which started <fact3>abruptly about 6 hours ago</fact3>, along with his history as a <fact4>long-haul truck driver</fact4> and recent travel, raises concern for pulmonary embolism (PE). However, given that he is considered low-risk and his physical examination only shows <fact12>minimal bibasilar rales</fact12> with otherwise normal findings, a non-invasive and cost-effective initial step is warranted. Among the options provided, a D-dimer test is a reasonable first step in ruling out PE in low-risk patients due to its high sensitivity for detecting thrombotic activity. Although it is not specific and can be elevated in various conditions, a negative result can help exclude PE. Therefore, the most reasonable 1st step is option {C}.

question:
A four-day-old neonate is brought to the pediatrician with vaginal discharge for the last two days. Her mother is concerned about the blood-tinged discharge but states that her daughter has been feeding and voiding well. The neonate was delivered at 39 weeks gestation by an uncomplicated vaginal delivery, and she and her mother were discharged home after two days. The prenatal course was complicated by chlamydia in the mother during the first trimester, for which she and the partner were both treated with a negative test of cure. The neonate’s biological father is no longer involved the patient's care, but her mother’s boyfriend has been caring for the baby whenever the mother rests. At this visit, the neonate’s temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), pulse is 138/min, and respirations are 51/min. She appears comfortable, and cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. There are no bruises or marks on her skin. Examination of the genitals reveals no vulvar irritation or skin changes, but there is scant pink mucoid discharge at the introitus. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Vaginal exam under anesthesia
B) Report to child protective services
C) Vaginal culture
D) Warm water irrigation of the vagina
E) Reassurance
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>four-day-old neonate</fact1> is brought to the pediatrician with <fact2>vaginal discharge for the last two days</fact2>. Her mother is concerned about the <fact3>blood-tinged discharge</fact3> but states that her daughter has been <fact4>feeding and voiding well</fact4>. The neonate was delivered at <fact5>39 weeks gestation</fact5> by an <fact6>uncomplicated vaginal delivery</fact6>, and she and her mother were discharged home after two days. The prenatal course was complicated by <fact7>chlamydia in the mother during the first trimester</fact7>, for which she and the partner were both treated with a negative test of cure. The neonate’s biological father is no longer involved the patient's care, but her mother’s boyfriend has been caring for the baby whenever the mother rests. At this visit, the neonate’s <fact8>temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 138/min</fact9>, and <fact10>respirations are 51/min</fact10>. She appears comfortable, and cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. There are no bruises or marks on her skin. Examination of the genitals reveals no vulvar irritation or skin changes, but there is <fact11>scant pink mucoid discharge at the introitus</fact11>. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>four-day-old neonate</fact1> is presenting with <fact2>vaginal discharge for the last two days</fact2> and the mother's concern about <fact3>blood-tinged discharge</fact3>, it is essential to evaluate the situation carefully. However, given that the neonate has been <fact4>feeding and voiding well</fact4> and the physical examination only reveals <fact11>scant pink mucoid discharge at the introitus</fact11> without any signs of vulvar irritation or skin changes, the most likely explanation is a normal physiological discharge in a newborn. This condition is relatively common in newborns due to the exposure to maternal estrogen in utero, leading to cervical mucus production. Since the neonate's vital signs are stable (<fact8>temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 138/min</fact9>, and <fact10>respirations are 51/min</fact10>), and there are no other concerning findings, the best next step in management is reassurance. The answer is {E}.

question:
A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive muscle weakness for five months. She feels that the muscles in her shoulders and hips have been getting weaker and sometimes feel sore. She now has difficulty getting up from chairs, climbing stairs, and combing her hair. She has also noticed new difficulty with swallowing solid foods, but has no trouble with liquids. She has a 5-year history of hyperlipidemia controlled with fluvastatin. Her maternal uncle died at age 26 from Duchenne's muscular dystrophy and her mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows moderate weakness in the arm abductors and hip flexors bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.7 g/dL
Leukocytes 11,200/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 33 mm/h
Serum
Creatine kinase 212 U/L
Lactate dehydrogenase 164 U/L
AST 34 U/L
ALT 35 U/L
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?"
A) Intrafascicular infiltration on muscle biopsy
B) Inflammation of synovial spaces on ultrasound
C) Perifascicular and perivascular infiltration on muscle biopsy
D) Positive anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies
E) Dystrophin gene mutation on genetic analysis
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>47-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>progressive muscle weakness for five months</fact2>. She feels that the muscles in her <fact3>shoulders and hips have been getting weaker</fact3> and sometimes feel sore. She now has difficulty <fact4>getting up from chairs, climbing stairs, and combing her hair</fact4>. She has also noticed new difficulty with <fact5>swallowing solid foods, but has no trouble with liquids</fact5>. She has a <fact6>5-year history of hyperlipidemia controlled with fluvastatin</fact6>. Her <fact7>maternal uncle died at age 26 from Duchenne's muscular dystrophy</fact7> and her mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows <fact8>moderate weakness in the arm abductors and hip flexors bilaterally</fact8>. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
<fact9>Hemoglobin 13.7 g/dL</fact9>
<fact10>Leukocytes 11,200/mm3</fact10>
<fact11>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 33 mm/h</fact11>
Serum
<fact12>Creatine kinase 212 U/L</fact12>
<fact13>Lactate dehydrogenase 164 U/L</fact13>
<fact14>AST 34 U/L</fact14>
<fact15>ALT 35 U/L</fact15>
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

Answer:
Given the patient's symptoms of <fact2>progressive muscle weakness</fact2>, particularly in the <fact3>shoulders and hips</fact3>, and difficulty with <fact4>getting up from chairs, climbing stairs, and combing her hair</fact4>, along with the laboratory findings of elevated <fact12>creatine kinase</fact12> and <fact13>lactate dehydrogenase</fact13>, the most likely diagnosis is a form of muscular dystrophy. However, the patient's age and gender make Duchenne's muscular dystrophy, which affected her <fact7>maternal uncle</fact7>, less likely. The presence of <fact8>moderate weakness in the arm abductors and hip flexors bilaterally</fact8> and the absence of significant elevation in liver enzymes (<fact14>AST</fact14> and <fact15>ALT</fact15>) also support this diagnosis. Among the options provided, the finding that would most likely confirm the diagnosis is perifascicular and perivascular infiltration on muscle biopsy, which is characteristic of certain types of muscular dystrophy and myopathies. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after his wife noticed during breakfast that the left side of his face was drooping. He had difficulty putting on his shirt and shoes before coming to the hospital. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. His current medications include metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He drinks one glass of wine daily. He is alert and oriented to time, place and person. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min and blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Examination shows equal and reactive pupils. There is drooping of the left side of the face. Muscle strength is decreased in the left upper and lower extremities. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left side. Speech is dysarthric. There is a bruit on the right side of the neck. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count, coagulation profile, and serum concentrations of glucose and electrolytes are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) MRI of the brain
B) Lumbar puncture
C) Duplex ultrasonography of the neck
D) Cerebral angiography
E) CT scan of the head
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after his wife noticed during breakfast that the <fact2>left side of his face was drooping</fact2>. He had difficulty putting on his shirt and shoes before coming to the hospital. He has <fact3>type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia</fact3>. His current medications include metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. He has smoked <fact4>one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years</fact4>. He drinks one glass of wine daily. He is alert and oriented to time, place and person. His <fact5>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 99/min</fact6> and <fact7>blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg</fact7>. Examination shows equal and reactive pupils. There is <fact8>drooping of the left side of the face</fact8>. Muscle strength is decreased in the <fact9>left upper and lower extremities</fact9>. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left side. Speech is dysarthric. There is a <fact10>bruit on the right side of the neck</fact10>. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count, coagulation profile, and serum concentrations of glucose and electrolytes are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>62-year-old man's</fact1> sudden onset of symptoms, including <fact2>left side of his face drooping</fact2>, difficulty with motor functions, and <fact8>drooping of the left side of the face</fact8> along with decreased muscle strength in the <fact9>left upper and lower extremities</fact9>, the clinical presentation is highly suggestive of a stroke. Given the presence of a <fact10>bruit on the right side of the neck</fact10>, which may indicate carotid artery stenosis, and the patient's history of <fact3>type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia</fact3> along with <fact4>long-term smoking</fact4>, there is an increased risk for atherosclerotic disease. The immediate concern is to differentiate between an ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke to guide appropriate management. Among the provided options, the most appropriate next step is to perform a non-contrast CT scan of the head to quickly assess for any intracranial hemorrhage. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 32-year-old man arrives to his primary care physician to discuss his fear of flying. The patient reports that he has had a fear of flying since being a teenager. He went on a family vacation 15 years ago, and during the flight there was turbulence and a “rough landing”. Since then he has avoided flying. He did not go to his cousin’s wedding because it was out of the country. He also was unable to visit his grandmother for her 80th birthday. The last time his job asked him to meet a client out of state, he drove 18 hours instead of flying. Two years ago he promised his fiancé they could fly to Florida. Upon arrival at the airport, he began to feel dizzy, lightheaded, and refused to go through security. During the clinic visit, the patient appears anxious and distressed. He recognizes that his fear is irrational. He is upset that it is affecting his relationship with his wife. Additionally, his current job may soon require employees in his sales position to fly to meet potential clients. He is embarrassed to have a conversation with his manager about his fear of flying. Which of the following is the best therapy for the patient’s condition?
A) Alprazolam
B) Cognitive behavioral therapy
C) Fluoxetine
D) Psychodynamic psychotherapy
E) Zolpidem
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old man</fact1> arrives to his primary care physician to discuss his <fact2>fear of flying</fact2>. The patient reports that he has had a <fact3>fear of flying since being a teenager</fact3>. He went on a family vacation <fact4>15 years ago</fact4>, and during the flight there was <fact5>turbulence and a “rough landing”</fact5>. Since then he has <fact6>avoided flying</fact6>. He did not go to his cousin’s wedding because it was out of the country. He also was unable to visit his grandmother for her 80th birthday. The last time his job asked him to meet a client out of state, he drove <fact7>18 hours instead of flying</fact7>. Two years ago he promised his fiancé they could fly to Florida. Upon arrival at the airport, he began to feel <fact8>dizzy, lightheaded, and refused to go through security</fact8>. During the clinic visit, the patient appears <fact9>anxious and distressed</fact9>. He recognizes that his <fact10>fear is irrational</fact10>. He is upset that it is affecting his relationship with his wife. Additionally, his current job may soon require employees in his sales position to fly to meet potential clients. He is embarrassed to have a conversation with his manager about his <fact11>fear of flying</fact11>. Which of the following is the best therapy for the patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>fear of flying</fact2> and its significant impact on his life, such as <fact6>avoiding flying</fact6> and driving <fact7>18 hours instead of flying</fact7>, the most effective therapy would address the underlying psychological issues. The patient's recognition that his <fact10>fear is irrational</fact10> and his willingness to seek help indicate a good starting point for therapy. Among the options provided, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is well-suited for addressing specific phobias like the <fact2>fear of flying</fact2> by helping the patient change his thought patterns and behaviors associated with the fear. CBT can also help the patient manage the <fact8>anxiety symptoms</fact8> he experiences when confronted with flying. Therefore, the best therapy for the patient's condition is {B}.

question:
A 38-year-old nursing home worker presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and productive cough for the past couple of months. His fever is low-grade and sputum is often blood-tinged. He has lost 6.8 kg (15.0 lb) during this period and complains of profound night sweats. A plain radiograph of the patient’s chest shows consolidation in the apical part of the right lung. Baseline investigations show the following:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin 11 g/dL
White blood cells  
Total count 16,000/mm3
Differential count  
Neutrophils 35%
Lymphocytes 54%
Eosinophils 11%
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 84 mm
The physician suspects that the patient is suffering from a chronic lung infection. Which of the following statements best describes the type of lung inflammation in this patient?
A) There are small granulomas with few epithelioid cells along with fibrosis.
B) It has a granuloma with Anitchov cells around a core of fibrinoid collagen necrosis.
C) It consists of a largely circumscribed granuloma with epithelioid cells with Langhans cells.
D) An ill-defined granuloma with macrophages and epithelioid cells is seen in this type of inflammation.
E) This type of granulomatous inflammation is also seen in histoplasmosis.
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>38-year-old nursing home worker</fact1> presents to the clinic with complaints of <fact2>fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and productive cough</fact2> for the past couple of months. His <fact3>fever is low-grade</fact3> and <fact4>sputum is often blood-tinged</fact4>. He has lost <fact5>6.8 kg (15.0 lb)</fact5> during this period and complains of <fact6>profound night sweats</fact6>. A <fact7>plain radiograph of the patient’s chest</fact7> shows <fact8>consolidation in the apical part of the right lung</fact8>. Baseline investigations show the following: 
Complete blood count 
Hemoglobin <fact9>11 g/dL</fact9> 
White blood cells  
Total count <fact10>16,000/mm3</fact10> 
Differential count  
Neutrophils <fact11>35%</fact11> 
Lymphocytes <fact12>54%</fact12> 
Eosinophils <fact13>11%</fact13> 
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate <fact14>84 mm</fact14> 
The physician suspects that the patient is suffering from a <fact15>chronic lung infection</fact15>. Which of the following statements best describes the type of lung inflammation in this patient? 
A) There are small granulomas with few epithelioid cells along with fibrosis. 
B) It has a granuloma with Anitchov cells around a core of fibrinoid collagen necrosis. 
C) It consists of a largely circumscribed granuloma with epithelioid cells with Langhans cells. 
D) An ill-defined granuloma with macrophages and epithelioid cells is seen in this type of inflammation. 
E) This type of granulomatous inflammation is also seen in histoplasmosis.

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and productive cough</fact2> along with <fact3>low-grade fever</fact3>, <fact4>blood-tinged sputum</fact4>, significant <fact5>weight loss</fact5>, and <fact6>profound night sweats</fact6>, these are indicative of a chronic infection, likely tuberculosis (TB). The <fact7>chest radiograph</fact7> showing <fact8>consolidation in the apical part of the right lung</fact8> further supports this diagnosis, as TB often affects the upper lobes of the lungs. The laboratory findings, including an elevated <fact14>erythrocyte sedimentation rate</fact14> and a relatively low <fact9>hemoglobin level</fact9>, also suggest chronic inflammation. TB is characterized by the formation of granulomas with specific features. Among the options provided, option C describes a largely circumscribed granuloma with epithelioid cells and Langhans cells, which is typical of TB. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 53-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of fatigue and joint and muscle pain. He reports a 6-month history of slowly progressive tiredness associated with dull achy pain in his knees, hips, and shoulders. His past medical history is notable for hypertension, diabetes, and stable angina. He takes lisinopril, metformin, glyburide, and aspirin. He has a history of intravenous drug use and was homeless in his early 30’s. He drinks alcohol socially and has a 30 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination reveals a generally well-appearing male without evidence of ascites, peripheral edema, or jaundice. Results from laboratory tests are below:

Hepatitis A IgM: Negative
Hepatitis A IgG: Negative
Hepatitis B surface antigen: Negative
Hepatitis B E antigen: Negative
Hepatitis B core antigen: Negative
Hepatitis B surface IgG: Positive
Hepatitis B E IgG: Negative
Hepatitis B core IgG: Negative
Hepatitis C IgG: Positive
HCV RNA: 100,000,000 IU/ml

This patient should be started on which of the following medications?
A) Sofosbuvir and simeprevir
B) Interferon-alpha
C) Interferon-gamma
D) Ribavirin
E) Lamivudine
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>53-year-old male</fact1> presents to his primary care physician complaining of <fact2>fatigue and joint and muscle pain</fact2>. He reports a <fact3>6-month history of slowly progressive tiredness</fact3> associated with dull achy pain in his knees, hips, and shoulders. His past medical history is notable for <fact4>hypertension, diabetes, and stable angina</fact4>. He takes <fact5>lisinopril, metformin, glyburide, and aspirin</fact5>. He has a history of <fact6>intravenous drug use</fact6> and was homeless in his early 30’s. He drinks alcohol socially and has a <fact7>30 pack-year smoking history</fact7>. His <fact8>temperature is 98.6°F (37°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 95/min</fact10>, and <fact11>respirations are 18/min</fact11>. Physical examination reveals a generally well-appearing male without evidence of ascites, peripheral edema, or jaundice. Results from laboratory tests are below:

<fact12>Hepatitis A IgM: Negative</fact12>
<fact13>Hepatitis A IgG: Negative</fact13>
<fact14>Hepatitis B surface antigen: Negative</fact14>
<fact15>Hepatitis B E antigen: Negative</fact15>
<fact16>Hepatitis B core antigen: Negative</fact16>
<fact17>Hepatitis B surface IgG: Positive</fact17>
<fact18>Hepatitis B E IgG: Negative</fact18>
<fact19>Hepatitis B core IgG: Negative</fact19>
<fact20>Hepatitis C IgG: Positive</fact20>
<fact21>HCV RNA: 100,000,000 IU/ml</fact21>

This patient should be started on which of the following medications?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's laboratory results, specifically the <fact20>positive Hepatitis C IgG</fact20> and the high <fact21>HCV RNA level of 100,000,000 IU/ml</fact21>, it is clear that the patient has a Hepatitis C infection. Given this diagnosis, the most appropriate treatment would involve direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) that target the Hepatitis C virus. Among the provided options, Sofosbuvir and Simeprevir are both DAAs that have been used in combination to treat Hepatitis C. Sofosbuvir is a nucleotide analog inhibitor of the NS5B polymerase, and Simeprevir is a protease inhibitor that targets the NS3/4A protease. This combination has been shown to be effective in treating Hepatitis C genotype 1 infection. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 25-year-old man presents with painless swelling of the neck for the past week. He reports no recent fevers, night sweats, or weight loss. His past medical history is significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, which was diagnosed last year. He also experienced a head trauma 5 years ago, which has been complicated by residual seizures. His only medication is daily phenytoin, which was restarted after he had a seizure 3 months ago. His temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉). On physical examination, multiple non-tender lymph nodes, averaging 2 cm in diameter, are found to be palpable in the anterior and posterior triangles of the neck bilaterally. No other lymphadenopathy is noted. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show the following:
Hemoglobin 14 g/dL
Leukocyte count 8000/mm3 with a normal differential
Platelet count 250,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 40 mm/h
An excisional biopsy of one of the cervical lymph nodes is performed. The histopathologic analysis is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL)
B) Classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma (HL)
C) HIV lymphadenopathy
D) Mononucleosis
E) Phenytoin-induced adenopathy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>painless swelling of the neck</fact2> for the past week. He reports no recent <fact3>fevers, night sweats, or weight loss</fact3>. His past medical history is significant for <fact4>human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection</fact4>, which was diagnosed last year. He also experienced a <fact5>head trauma 5 years ago</fact5>, which has been complicated by residual <fact6>seizures</fact6>. His only medication is daily <fact7>phenytoin</fact7>, which was restarted after he had a <fact8>seizure 3 months ago</fact8>. His <fact9>temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉)</fact9>. On physical examination, multiple non-tender <fact10>lymph nodes, averaging 2 cm in diameter</fact10>, are found to be palpable in the anterior and posterior triangles of the neck bilaterally. No other <fact11>lymphadenopathy</fact11> is noted. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show the following: <fact12>Hemoglobin 14 g/dL</fact12>, <fact13>Leukocyte count 8000/mm3 with a normal differential</fact13>, <fact14>Platelet count 250,000/mm3</fact14>, and <fact15>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 40 mm/h</fact15>. An excisional biopsy of one of the cervical <fact16>lymph nodes</fact16> is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>painless swelling of the neck</fact2> and the presence of multiple non-tender <fact10>lymph nodes, averaging 2 cm in diameter</fact10>, in the absence of systemic symptoms like <fact3>fevers, night sweats, or weight loss</fact3>, the differential diagnosis can be narrowed down. The patient's history of <fact4>human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection</fact4> and the fact that he is on <fact7>phenytoin</fact7> for <fact6>seizures</fact6> are also important. The laboratory findings, including a normal <fact13>Leukocyte count with a normal differential</fact13> and a mildly elevated <fact15>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate</fact15>, do not strongly suggest an acute infection or a malignancy like <fact1>Acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL)</fact1> or <fact2>Classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma (HL)</fact2>. Given the patient's history of <fact4>HIV infection</fact4>, <fact3>HIV lymphadenopathy</fact3> is a possibility, but the lack of systemic symptoms and the specific mention of the patient's <fact9>temperature being normal</fact9> makes this less likely. <fact5>Mononucleosis</fact5> typically presents with fever and systemic symptoms, which this patient does not have. Therefore, the most plausible diagnosis, given the patient's history of <fact6>seizures</fact6> and the use of <fact7>phenytoin</fact7>, is <fact8>Phenytoin-induced adenopathy</fact8>. This condition is known to cause lymphadenopathy as a side effect of the medication. Hence, the correct answer is {E}.

question:
A 69-year-old male with a history of metastatic small cell lung carcinoma on chemotherapy presents to his oncologist for a follow-up visit. He has responded well to etoposide and cisplatin with plans to undergo radiation therapy. However, he reports that he recently developed multiple “spots” all over his body. He denies any overt bleeding from his gums or joint swelling. His past medical history is notable for iron deficiency anemia, osteoarthritis, and paraneoplastic Lambert-Eaton syndrome. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 20/min. On examination, a rash is noted diffusely across the patient’s trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremities.

Results from a complete blood count are shown below:
Hemoglobin: 11.9 mg/dl
Hematocrit: 35%
Leukocyte count: 5,000/mm^3
Platelet count: 20,000/mm^3

The oncologist would like to continue chemotherapy but is concerned that the above results will limit the optimal dose and frequency of the regimen. A recombinant version of which of the following is most appropriate in this patient?
A) Interleukin 2
B) Interleukin 8
C) Interleukin 11
D) Erythropoietin
E) Granulocyte colony stimulating factor
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>69-year-old male</fact1> with a history of <fact2>metastatic small cell lung carcinoma</fact2> on chemotherapy presents to his oncologist for a follow-up visit. He has responded well to <fact3>etoposide and cisplatin</fact3> with plans to undergo <fact4>radiation therapy</fact4>. However, he reports that he recently developed multiple “spots” all over his body. He denies any overt bleeding from his gums or joint swelling. His past medical history is notable for <fact5>iron deficiency anemia</fact5>, <fact6>osteoarthritis</fact6>, and <fact7>paraneoplastic Lambert-Eaton syndrome</fact7>. He has a <fact8>40 pack-year smoking history</fact8>. His <fact9>temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C)</fact9>, <fact10>blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg</fact10>, <fact11>pulse is 115/min</fact11>, and <fact12>respirations are 20/min</fact12>. On examination, a <fact13>rash is noted diffusely across the patient’s trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremities</fact13>.

Results from a complete blood count are shown below:
<fact14>Hemoglobin: 11.9 mg/dl</fact14>
<fact15>Hematocrit: 35%</fact15>
<fact16>Leukocyte count: 5,000/mm^3</fact16>
<fact17>Platelet count: 20,000/mm^3</fact17>

The oncologist would like to continue chemotherapy but is concerned that the above results will limit the optimal dose and frequency of the regimen. A recombinant version of which of the following is most appropriate in this patient?
A) Interleukin 2
B) Interleukin 8
C) Interleukin 11
D) Erythropoietin
E) Granulocyte colony stimulating factor

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact17>low platelet count of 20,000/mm^3</fact17>, which is likely causing the <fact13>rash noted diffusely across the patient’s trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremities</fact13>, the most appropriate recombinant version to administer would be one that stimulates platelet production. Interleukin 11 (IL-11) is known for its role in promoting megakaryocyte maturation, leading to increased platelet production. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 38-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, obesity, and hyperlipidemia presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of new bilateral blisters on her hands. She says that she first noticed these blisters shortly after returning from a weekend trip to the beach two weeks prior. She denies any fevers, joint pains, or other skin rash during this period. The patient works in the adult entertainment industry. On examination, there are multiple flaccid blisters of the bilateral dorsal hands with hemorrhagic crusts, mild scarring, and hyperpigmentation. In addition, increased hair growth is noted on the bilateral malar cheeks. Her temperature is 99.1° F (37.3° C), pulse is 95/min, blood pressure is 130/87 mmHg, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Her laboratory results are:

Serum:
Na+: 140 mEq/L
K+: 4.5 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
HCO3-: 21 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Glucose: 104 mg/dL

Leukocyte count: 9,000/mm^3
Hemoglobin: 12.4 g/dL
Platelets: 400,000/mm^3

Anti-nuclear antibody titer 1:320

Which of the following would confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
A) Anti dsDNA titers
B) C-reactive protein
C) Anti-hemidesmosome titers
D) Urine porphyrin levels
E) Tzanck smear
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> with a history of <fact2>systemic lupus erythematosus, obesity, and hyperlipidemia</fact2> presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of new <fact3>bilateral blisters on her hands</fact3>. She says that she first noticed these blisters shortly after returning from a weekend trip to the beach two weeks prior. She denies any <fact4>fevers, joint pains, or other skin rash</fact4> during this period. The patient works in the adult entertainment industry. On examination, there are multiple <fact5>flaccid blisters of the bilateral dorsal hands with hemorrhagic crusts, mild scarring, and hyperpigmentation</fact5>. In addition, <fact6>increased hair growth is noted on the bilateral malar cheeks</fact6>. Her <fact7>temperature is 99.1° F (37.3° C)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 95/min</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 130/87 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>respirations are 13/min</fact10>, and <fact11>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact11>. Her laboratory results are:

Serum:
<fact12>Na+: 140 mEq/L</fact12>
<fact13>K+: 4.5 mEq/L</fact13>
<fact14>Cl-: 100 mEq/L</fact14>
<fact15>HCO3-: 21 mEq/L</fact15>
<fact16>BUN: 20 mg/dL</fact16>
<fact17>Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL</fact17>
<fact18>Glucose: 104 mg/dL</fact18>

<fact19>Leukocyte count: 9,000/mm^3</fact19>
<fact20>Hemoglobin: 12.4 g/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Platelets: 400,000/mm^3</fact21>

<fact22>Anti-nuclear antibody titer 1:320</fact22>

Which of the following would confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

A) Anti dsDNA titers
B) C-reactive protein
C) Anti-hemidesmosome titers
D) Urine porphyrin levels
E) Tzanck smear

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact3>bilateral blisters on her hands</fact3> and has a history of <fact2>systemic lupus erythematosus, obesity, and hyperlipidemia</fact2>. The presence of <fact5>flaccid blisters of the bilateral dorsal hands with hemorrhagic crusts, mild scarring, and hyperpigmentation</fact5> along with <fact6>increased hair growth on the bilateral malar cheeks</fact6> suggests a dermatological condition. Given the <fact22>anti-nuclear antibody titer of 1:320</fact22>, which is indicative of an autoimmune process, and the specific skin manifestations, the most likely diagnosis is pemphigus. To confirm this diagnosis, a test that detects antibodies against the skin's desmoglein proteins would be necessary. Among the options provided, anti-hemidesmosome titers (option C) are not directly relevant to pemphigus but rather to bullous pemphigoid. However, the closest relevant test listed that can help in diagnosing autoimmune blistering diseases like pemphigus is the Tzanck smear (option E), which can show acantholytic cells characteristic of pemphigus, though it's not as specific as autoantibody tests. Therefore, the best answer given the options is {E}.

question:
Three patients present to the pediatrician for routine well-child visits. The first child’s mother reports that he seems to be breastfeeding well and voids at least eight times per day. His stools are a yellow color, and he does not seem to be straining. In the office, he can lift his head and chest when in the prone position, and he can track an object with his eyes to the midline. His hands remain fisted 50% of the time.

The second child’s parents report that she is doing well at home and seems to enjoy playing with her older brother. In the office, she can roll from supine to prone and can transfer her rattle from hand to hand. She cannot yet say any words.

The third child’s father reports that he is starting to explore the world around him. He has begun taking independent steps at home. In the office, he seems to recognize the name of several objects, but he cannot follow the direction to “grab the ball.” All three children are assessed as developmentally normal.

Which of the following represents these patient's respective ages?
A) Ages 1 month, 4 months, and 9 months
B) Ages 1 month, 6 months, and 9 months
C) Ages 2 months, 4 months, and 12 months
D) Ages 2 months, 6 months, and 9 months
E) Ages 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
Three patients present to the pediatrician for routine well-child visits. The first child’s mother reports that he seems to be <fact1>breastfeeding well and voids at least eight times per day</fact1>. His stools are a <fact2>yellow color</fact2>, and he does not seem to be straining. In the office, he can <fact3>lift his head and chest when in the prone position</fact3>, and he can <fact4>track an object with his eyes to the midline</fact4>. His hands remain <fact5>fisted 50% of the time</fact5>.

The second child’s parents report that she is doing well at home and seems to enjoy playing with her older brother. In the office, she can <fact6>roll from supine to prone</fact6> and can <fact7>transfer her rattle from hand to hand</fact7>. She cannot yet say any words.

The third child’s father reports that he is starting to explore the world around him. He has begun <fact8>taking independent steps at home</fact8>. In the office, he seems to recognize the name of several objects, but he cannot follow the direction to “grab the ball.” All three children are assessed as developmentally normal.

Which of the following represents these patient's respective ages?

Answer: 
Analyzing the developmental milestones of each child, the first child can <fact3>lift his head and chest when in the prone position</fact3> and <fact4>track an object with his eyes to the midline</fact4>, which is typical of a 1-2 month old infant. The second child can <fact6>roll from supine to prone</fact6> and <fact7>transfer her rattle from hand to hand</fact7>, which is characteristic of a 4-6 month old infant. The third child has begun <fact8>taking independent steps at home</fact8>, which is a milestone achieved around 9-12 months of age. Therefore, the most likely ages of the children are 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months, respectively. The answer is {E}.

question:
A 2-hour-old, 3.2 kg (7.0 lb) newborn boy born by cesarean delivery is being evaluated by the resident on-call. The child was born to a gravida 2, para 0 mother with known hepatitis B. The mother made it to all of her prenatal appointments and took the recommended dose of folic acid since conception. She gave up smoking when she discovered she was pregnant. The infant’s heart rate is 150/min, respiratory rate is 48/min, temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), and blood pressure is 80/52 mm Hg. APGAR testing exhibits a score of 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The head is normocephalic. No neural tube defects are present on inspection or palpation of the spine. There is strong flexion in all 4 extremities. Cranial nerves 2–12 are intact. Sensory and deep tendon reflexes are without any abnormalities. Which of the following is the best course of action for the newborn child?
Hepatitis B serology
HBsAg positive
HBeAg positive
IgM HBc negative
Total anti-HBc positive
Anti-HBs negative
Anti-HBc negative
HBV DNA greater than 1 million IU/mL
Alanine transferase normal
A) Administer hepatitis B vaccine
B) Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG)
C) Administer hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG
D) Check hepatitis B serology
E) Check liver enzymes
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>2-hour-old, 3.2 kg (7.0 lb) newborn boy</fact1> born by <fact2>cesarean delivery</fact2> is being evaluated by the resident on-call. The child was born to a <fact3>gravida 2, para 0 mother with known hepatitis B</fact3>. The mother made it to all of her prenatal appointments and took the recommended dose of <fact4>folic acid since conception</fact4>. She gave up <fact5>smoking when she discovered she was pregnant</fact5>. The infant’s <fact6>heart rate is 150/min, respiratory rate is 48/min, temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), and blood pressure is 80/52 mm Hg</fact6>. <fact7>APGAR testing exhibits a score of 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively</fact7>. The head is <fact8>normocephalic</fact8>. No <fact9>neural tube defects are present on inspection or palpation of the spine</fact9>. There is <fact10>strong flexion in all 4 extremities</fact10>. <fact11>Cranial nerves 2–12 are intact</fact11>. <fact12>Sensory and deep tendon reflexes are without any abnormalities</fact12>. 
Hepatitis B serology 
<fact13>HBsAg positive</fact13> 
<fact14>HBeAg positive</fact14> 
<fact15>IgM HBc negative</fact15> 
<fact16>Total anti-HBc positive</fact16> 
<fact17>Anti-HBs negative</fact17> 
<fact18>Anti-HBc negative</fact18> 
<fact19>HBV DNA greater than 1 million IU/mL</fact19> 
<fact20>Alanine transferase normal</fact20> 
Which of the following is the best course of action for the newborn child? 
A) Administer hepatitis B vaccine 
B) Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) 
C) Administer hepatitis B vaccine and HBIG 
D) Check hepatitis B serology 
E) Check liver enzymes 

Answer: 
Given that the <fact3>mother has known hepatitis B</fact3> and the newborn's <fact13>HBsAg positive</fact13> and <fact14>HBeAg positive</fact14> status indicate a high risk of hepatitis B transmission, the best course of action is to administer both hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) to the newborn. The hepatitis B vaccine will help develop immunity against the virus, while HBIG provides immediate protection by neutralizing the virus. This approach is crucial in preventing hepatitis B infection in the newborn, given the <fact19>high viral load (HBV DNA greater than 1 million IU/mL)</fact19> in the mother. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
An elderly man presents to his physician with complaints of difficulty breathing, easy fatigability, and bilateral leg swelling which began 2 months ago. His breathlessness worsens while walking, climbing the stairs, and lying flat on his back. He also finds it difficult to sleep well at night, as he often wakes up to catch his breath. His pulse is 98/min and blood pressure is 114/90 mm Hg. On examination, he has mild respiratory distress, distended neck veins, and bilateral pitting edema is evident on the lower third of his legs. His respiratory rate is 33/min, SpO2 is 93% in room air, and coarse crepitations are heard over the lung bases. On auscultation, the P2 component of his second heart sound is heard loudest at the second left intercostal space, and an S3 gallop rhythm is heard at the apex. Medication is prescribed for his symptoms which changes his cardiac physiology as depicted with the dashed line recorded post-medication. What is the mechanism of action of the prescribed medication?
A) Decrease in the slope of the pacemaker potential
B) Decrease in transmembrane sodium gradient
C) Preferential dilatation of capacitance vessels
D) Inhibition of aldosterone-mediated sodium reabsorption
E) Reduction in myocardial contractility
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An elderly man presents to his physician with complaints of <fact1>difficulty breathing, easy fatigability, and bilateral leg swelling</fact1> which began 2 months ago. His <fact2>breathlessness worsens while walking, climbing the stairs, and lying flat on his back</fact2>. He also finds it difficult to sleep well at night, as he often wakes up to catch his breath. His <fact3>pulse is 98/min</fact3> and <fact4>blood pressure is 114/90 mm Hg</fact4>. On examination, he has <fact5>mild respiratory distress, distended neck veins, and bilateral pitting edema</fact5> is evident on the lower third of his legs. His <fact6>respiratory rate is 33/min, SpO2 is 93% in room air</fact6>, and <fact7>coarse crepitations are heard over the lung bases</fact7>. On auscultation, the <fact8>P2 component of his second heart sound is heard loudest at the second left intercostal space</fact8>, and an <fact9>S3 gallop rhythm is heard at the apex</fact9>. Medication is prescribed for his symptoms which changes his cardiac physiology as depicted with the dashed line recorded post-medication. What is the mechanism of action of the prescribed medication?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact1>difficulty breathing, easy fatigability, and bilateral leg swelling</fact1> and signs such as <fact5>mild respiratory distress, distended neck veins, and bilateral pitting edema</fact5>, along with the <fact8>P2 component of his second heart sound being heard loudest at the second left intercostal space</fact8> and an <fact9>S3 gallop rhythm heard at the apex</fact9>, it is indicative of heart failure. The prescribed medication aims to alleviate these symptoms. Among the options provided, the mechanism of action that best aligns with the treatment of heart failure, given the symptoms and signs presented, is the reduction in myocardial contractility, which would help in decreasing the workload on the heart and improving symptoms of heart failure. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 6-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting. Vomiting occurs almost immediately after most feeds. Each time, he becomes irritable while feeding and refuses to finish the bottle. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz); he currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). He has Down syndrome. His vaccinations are up-to-date. He appears agitated and cries during the examination. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 156/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 100/49 mm Hg. Examination shows upward slanting of the eyelids, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a single transverse palmar crease on both hands. The abdomen is soft and nontender. A 2.5-cm (1-inch) epigastric mass is palpated. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis is within normal limits. Further diagnostic evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?
A) Dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray
B) A high serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration
C) Detection of rotavirus antigen on enzyme immunoassay (EIA)
D) Elongated and thickened pylorus on abdominal ultrasound
E) Tripple bubble sign on abdominal x-ray
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>6-week-old male infant</fact1> is brought to the physician by his mother because of a <fact2>2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting</fact2>. Vomiting occurs almost immediately after most feeds. Each time, he becomes irritable while feeding and refuses to finish the bottle. He was born at <fact3>37 weeks' gestation</fact3> and weighed <fact4>3300 g (7 lb 4 oz)</fact4>; he currently weighs <fact5>4000 g (8 lb 13 oz)</fact5>. He has <fact6>Down syndrome</fact6>.
