She started having sexual intercourse with her boyfriend about 3 months ago. Six months ago she had a manic episode, which was treated with risperidone. Her mother has PCOS and her father has diabetes mellitus. She is very conscious of her weight and appearance. She is 171 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 27.02 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Serum hormone studies show:
Prolactin 16 ng/mL
Thyroid-stimulating hormone 3.8 μU/mL
Follicle-stimulating hormone 6 mIU/mL
Luteinizing hormone 5.1 mIU/mL
Progesterone 0.8 ng/mL (follicular N <3; luteal N >3–5)
Testosterone 2.2 nmol/L (N <3.5)
A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?"
A) Uterine fibroids
B) Congenital defect of the Mullerian ducts
C) Purging behavior
D) Polycystic ovaries
E) Anovulation
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>15-year-old girl</fact1> comes to the physician because she has not had <fact2>menstrual bleeding for the past 3 months</fact2>. Menses had previously occurred at irregular <fact3>15–45 day intervals with moderate to heavy flow</fact3>. Menarche was at the age of <fact4>14 years</fact4>. She started having <fact5>sexual intercourse with her boyfriend about 3 months ago</fact5>. Six months ago she had a <fact6>manic episode, which was treated with risperidone</fact6>. Her mother has <fact7>PCOS</fact7> and her father has <fact8>diabetes mellitus</fact8>. She is very conscious of her <fact9>weight and appearance</fact9>. She is <fact10>171 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 27.02 kg/m2</fact10>. Her <fact11>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact11>, <fact12>pulse is 60/min</fact12>, and <fact13>blood pressure is 116/70 mm Hg</fact13>. The abdomen is <fact14>soft and nontender</fact14>. Pelvic examination shows a <fact15>normal vagina and cervix</fact15>. Serum hormone studies show: 
<fact16>Prolactin 16 ng/mL</fact16>
<fact17>Thyroid-stimulating hormone 3.8 μU/mL</fact17>
<fact18>Follicle-stimulating hormone 6 mIU/mL</fact18>
<fact19>Luteinizing hormone 5.1 mIU/mL</fact19>
<fact20>Progesterone 0.8 ng/mL (follicular N <3; luteal N >3–5)</fact20>
<fact21>Testosterone 2.2 nmol/L (N <3.5)</fact21>
A <fact22>urine pregnancy test is negative</fact22>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>15-year-old girl's</fact1> primary complaint of <fact2>amenorrhea for the past 3 months</fact2> and her previous menstrual cycles occurring at irregular <fact3>15–45 day intervals with moderate to heavy flow</fact3>, along with a <fact22>negative urine pregnancy test</fact22> which rules out pregnancy as a cause, it is essential to evaluate other potential causes. Her family history of <fact7>PCOS</fact7> might suggest a possible genetic predisposition to hormonal imbalances. However, her serum hormone studies, including <fact16>normal prolactin</fact16>, <fact17>normal thyroid-stimulating hormone</fact17>, <fact18>slightly elevated follicle-stimulating hormone</fact18>, <fact19>normal luteinizing hormone</fact19>, <fact20>low progesterone</fact20> indicative of anovulatory cycles, and <fact21>normal testosterone levels</fact21>, do not strongly support PCOS as the primary cause. The most likely cause of her symptoms, given the hormonal profile and absence of other clear pathologies, is anovulation. This is directly supported by her <fact20>low progesterone level</fact20>, which is consistent with anovulatory menstrual cycles. Therefore, the correct answer is {E}.

question:
A 27-year-old college student presents to his physician for constant fatigue. The patient states that for the past several weeks he has felt oddly fatigued and has struggled to complete his work. He is a foreign exchange student and is concerned he will fail out of his academic program. He has experienced some occasional nausea and vomiting which has caused him to lose weight. The patient is a first year college student, drinks alcohol regularly, smokes marijuana, and has unprotected sex with multiple partners. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL
Total bilirubin: 2.0 mg/dL
AST: 85 U/L
ALT: 92 U/L

Urine
Color: Amber/brown
Marijuana: Positive
Amphetamines: Positive
Cocaine: Positive

The patient refuses an examination of his genitals. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test?
A) CAGE questions
B) Direct influenza antigen
C) Uretheral swab and culture
D) Viral core antibody
E) Viral surface antibody
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old college student</fact1> presents to his physician for <fact2>constant fatigue</fact2>. The patient states that for the past several weeks he has felt oddly fatigued and has struggled to complete his work. He is a foreign exchange student and is concerned he will fail out of his academic program. He has experienced some <fact3>occasional nausea and vomiting</fact3> which has caused him to <fact4>lose weight</fact4>. The patient is a first year college student, <fact5>drinks alcohol regularly</fact5>, <fact6>smokes marijuana</fact6>, and has <fact7>unprotected sex with multiple partners</fact7>. His <fact8>temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 90/min</fact10>, <fact11>respirations are 17/min</fact11>, and <fact12>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact12>. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
<fact13>Sodium is 139 mEq/L</fact13>
<fact14>Chloride is 100 mEq/L</fact14>
<fact15>Potassium is 4.3 mEq/L</fact15>
<fact16>Bicarbonate is 25 mEq/L</fact16>
<fact17>BUN is 20 mg/dL</fact17>
<fact18>Glucose is 99 mg/dL</fact18>
<fact19>Creatinine is 1.1 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Calcium is 10.2 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Total bilirubin is 2.0 mg/dL</fact21>
<fact22>AST is 85 U/L</fact22>
<fact23>ALT is 92 U/L</fact23>

Urine
<fact24>Color is amber/brown</fact24>
<fact25>Marijuana is positive</fact25>
<fact26>Amphetamines are positive</fact26>
<fact27>Cocaine is positive</fact27>

The patient <fact28>refuses an examination of his genitals</fact28>. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>constant fatigue</fact2>, <fact3>occasional nausea and vomiting</fact3>, and <fact4>weight loss</fact4>, along with his history of <fact7>unprotected sex with multiple partners</fact7> and his refusal of a genital examination, there is a high suspicion for a sexually transmitted infection. Given the laboratory values, particularly the <fact22>elevated AST</fact22> and <fact23>ALT</fact23>, which indicate liver inflammation, the most likely diagnosis is a viral hepatitis infection. Among the options provided, the best diagnostic test would be for a viral surface antibody (option E) to confirm the presence of a hepatitis B or C infection. The patient's <fact5>regular alcohol consumption</fact5> and <fact6>marijuana use</fact6> may also be contributing factors to his liver enzyme elevation, but the primary concern is the potential viral hepatitis infection.

question:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, at 22 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department for abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding for 2 hours. She has had no prenatal care. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender, and regular contractions are felt every 2 minutes. The uterus is consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. There is blood on the vulva, introitus, and medial aspect of the thighs. Ultrasound shows complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus. Fetal heart tones are absent. An emergent cesarean delivery is performed. Following the procedure, the patient becomes tearful and distraught. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
A) “I'm sorry for your loss. This must be a difficult situation for you.”
B) “Losing a baby is difficult, but I'm sure next time it'll work out.”
C) “I'm sorry for your loss. Let's talk about how to move forward from here.”
D) “Losing a baby is difficult; but I see this every day, and I know you'll get through it.”
E) “I'm sorry for your loss. I can write you a prescription to help with your anxiety and grief.”
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, at 22 weeks' gestation</fact1> comes to the emergency department for <fact2>abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding</fact2> for 2 hours. She has had <fact3>no prenatal care</fact3>. Her <fact4>temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F)</fact4>, <fact5>pulse is 102/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations are 16/min</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg</fact7>. The abdomen is <fact8>nontender</fact8>, and <fact9>regular contractions are felt every 2 minutes</fact9>. The uterus is consistent in size with a <fact10>20-week gestation</fact10>. There is <fact11>blood on the vulva, introitus, and medial aspect of the thighs</fact11>. Ultrasound shows <fact12>complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus</fact12>. <fact13>Fetal heart tones are absent</fact13>. An <fact14>emergent cesarean delivery</fact14> is performed. Following the procedure, the patient becomes <fact15>tearful and distraught</fact15>. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's situation, having experienced a pregnancy loss at <fact10>20-week gestation</fact10> with <fact13>fetal heart tones absent</fact13> and undergoing an <fact14>emergent cesarean delivery</fact14>, she is understandably <fact15>tearful and distraught</fact15>. The most appropriate initial response by the physician should acknowledge her loss and validate her feelings. Option A, “I'm sorry for your loss. This must be a difficult situation for you,” is the most empathetic response as it directly addresses her current emotional state without minimizing her feelings or rushing to discuss future actions. This response allows the patient to feel heard and understood, which is crucial in the initial stages of grief.

question:
A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of fevers, chills, and left lower quadrant pain. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse is 126/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. There is blood oozing around the site of a peripheral intravenous line. Pelvic examination shows mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os and left adnexal tenderness. Laboratory studies show:
Platelet count 14,200/mm3
Fibrinogen 83 mg/mL (N = 200–430 mg/dL)
D-dimer 965 ng/mL (N < 500 ng/mL)
When phenol is applied to a sample of the patient's blood at 90°C, a phosphorylated N-acetylglucosamine dimer with 6 fatty acids attached to a polysaccharide side chain is identified. A blood culture is most likely to show which of the following?"
A) Coagulase-positive, gram-positive cocci forming mauve-colored colonies on methicillin-containing agar
B) Encapsulated, gram-negative coccobacilli forming grey-colored colonies on charcoal blood agar
C) Spore-forming, gram-positive bacilli forming yellow colonies on casein agar
D) Lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods forming pink colonies on MacConkey agar
E) Gamma-hemolytic, gram-positive cocci forming green colonies on vancomycin agar
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>39-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of <fact2>fevers, chills, and left lower quadrant pain</fact2>. Her <fact3>temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F)</fact3>, <fact4>pulse is 126/min</fact4>, <fact5>respirations are 28/min</fact5>, and <fact6>blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg</fact6>. There is <fact7>blood oozing around the site of a peripheral intravenous line</fact7>. <fact8>Pelvic examination</fact8> shows <fact9>mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os</fact9> and <fact10>left adnexal tenderness</fact10>. Laboratory studies show: <fact11>Platelet count 14,200/mm³</fact11> <fact12>Fibrinogen 83 mg/mL</fact12> (N = 200–430 mg/dL) <fact13>D-dimer 965 ng/mL</fact13> (N < 500 ng/mL) When phenol is applied to a sample of the patient's blood at 90°C, a <fact14>phosphorylated N-acetylglucosamine dimer with 6 fatty acids attached to a polysaccharide side chain</fact14> is identified. A blood culture is most likely to show which of the following?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the patient had <fact2>fevers, chills, and left lower quadrant pain</fact2>. Her vital signs indicate a high <fact3>temperature of 39.1°C (102.3°F)</fact3>, an elevated <fact4>pulse of 126/min</fact4>, increased <fact5>respirations at 28/min</fact5>, and a low <fact6>blood pressure of 80/50 mm Hg</fact6>, which are signs of sepsis. The presence of <fact7>blood oozing around the site of a peripheral intravenous line</fact7> suggests a possible bloodstream infection. The <fact9>mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os</fact9> and <fact10>left adnexal tenderness</fact10> found during the <fact8>pelvic examination</fact8> point towards pelvic inflammatory disease. Laboratory results show a <fact11>significantly low platelet count</fact11>, <fact12>decreased fibrinogen</fact12>, and <fact13>elevated D-dimer</fact13>, all of which are indicative of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The identification of a <fact14>phosphorylated N-acetylglucosamine dimer with 6 fatty acids attached to a polysaccharide side chain</fact14> when phenol is applied suggests the presence of lipopolysaccharides typical of certain Gram-negative bacteria. Among the options provided, choice D describes a lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rod forming pink colonies on MacConkey agar, which is characteristic of Escherichia coli, a common pathogen responsible for severe infections leading to sepsis and DIC. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 16-year-old female presents to her physician’s office after noticing a round lump in her left breast 2 months ago. She reports that the lump seemed to enlarge and became tender just preceding her last 2 menses. It is otherwise painless, and the patient denies any discharge or skin changes. She has no past medical history but her grandmother, age 72, was just diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. The patient is an avid softball player at her high school and denies alcohol, smoking, or illicit drug use. On exam, the breasts appear symmetric and normal. A 3-cm round, mobile mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is slight tenderness to deep palpation of the mass. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy on either side. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient’s condition?
A) This mass will likely require excision
B) This mass will decrease in size if the patient starts oral contraceptives
C) This mass slightly increases this patient’s risk of breast cancer in the future
D) This mass will most likely decrease in size or disappear over time
E) If this mass grows rapidly to greater than 5 cm, radiation and chemotherapy are indicated
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>16-year-old female</fact1> presents to her physician’s office after noticing a <fact2>round lump in her left breast 2 months ago</fact2>. She reports that the <fact3>lump seemed to enlarge and became tender just preceding her last 2 menses</fact3>. It is otherwise <fact4>painless</fact4>, and the patient denies any <fact5>discharge or skin changes</fact5>. She has no past medical history but her <fact6>grandmother, age 72, was just diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast</fact6>. The patient is an avid softball player at her high school and denies <fact7>alcohol, smoking, or illicit drug use</fact7>. On exam, the breasts appear <fact8>symmetric and normal</fact8>. A <fact9>3-cm round, mobile mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast</fact9>. There is <fact10>slight tenderness to deep palpation of the mass</fact10>. There is no <fact11>axillary lymphadenopathy on either side</fact11>. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's age, <fact1>16-year-old female</fact1>, and the characteristics of the breast lump, which is <fact2>round</fact2> and <fact9>mobile</fact9>, it is likely that the mass is a fibroadenoma, a common benign breast tumor in young women. The fact that the <fact3>lump seemed to enlarge and became tender just preceding her last 2 menses</fact3> suggests a possible hormonal influence, which is consistent with fibroadenoma. Given that the mass is <fact4>painless</fact4> and there are no <fact5>discharge or skin changes</fact5>, and the absence of <fact11>axillary lymphadenopathy</fact11>, the likelihood of malignancy is low. Although the patient's <fact6>grandmother was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast</fact6>, this does not significantly increase the patient's risk at this age. Therefore, the most likely outcome is that the mass will <fact12>most likely decrease in size or disappear over time</fact12>, which is a common course for fibroadenomas. The answer is {D}.

question:
A previously healthy 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation because of loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability for the past 3 weeks. He was recently kicked off of the school's football team after missing too many practices. He has also been avoiding his family and friends because he is not in the mood to see them, but he admits that he is lonely. He has not left his room for 2 days, which prompted his father to bring him to the physician. He has no medical conditions and does not take any medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. While the father is in the waiting room, a mental status examination is conducted, which shows a constricted affect. Cognition is intact. He says that he would be better off dead and refuses to be treated. He says he wants to use his father's licensed firearm to “end his misery” over the weekend when his parents are at church. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Agree to his wish for no further treatment
B) Begin paroxetine therapy
C) Involuntary hospitalization after informing the parents
D) Reassure the patient that he will feel better
E) Start outpatient psychotherapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A previously healthy <fact1>14-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician for evaluation because of <fact2>loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability</fact2> for the past <fact3>3 weeks</fact3>. He was recently kicked off of the school's football team after missing too many practices. He has also been avoiding his family and friends because he is not in the mood to see them, but he admits that he is <fact4>lonely</fact4>. He has not left his room for <fact5>2 days</fact5>, which prompted his father to bring him to the physician. He has no medical conditions and does not take any medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. While the father is in the waiting room, a mental status examination is conducted, which shows a <fact6>constricted affect</fact6>. Cognition is intact. He says that he would be <fact7>better off dead</fact7> and refuses to be treated. He says he wants to use his father's licensed firearm to “<fact8>end his misery</fact8>” over the weekend when his parents are at church. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Given the <fact1>14-year-old boy's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability</fact2> over the past <fact3>3 weeks</fact3>, along with feelings of being <fact4>lonely</fact4> and having a <fact6>constricted affect</fact6>, it is clear that he is experiencing significant emotional distress. His statements about being <fact7>better off dead</fact7> and wanting to “<fact8>end his misery</fact8>” using his father's firearm indicate a high risk of suicide. This is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention to ensure the patient's safety. Among the provided options, the most appropriate next step in management is to ensure the patient's safety through constant supervision and by removing access to means of self-harm. Therefore, involuntary hospitalization after informing the parents is the most appropriate course of action. The answer is {C}.

question:
A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care provider after feeling sad and depressed for the past several months. His wife divorced him about 6 months ago and took the kids and moved out of state. Since then he has had difficulty waking up in the morning and getting to work on time. He takes some comfort in food and has gained about 9.1 kg (20 lb). He eats out several times a week and sometimes consumes 2 whole meals in one sitting. Other than this new obsession with eating large quantities of food and excess sleeping he no longer enjoys doing things he liked doing in the past. Besides eating and sleeping he is always excited to see his children and looks forward to their visits. He says it's the one thing keeping him going. Additionally, he does not feel like he has the same drive or focuses at work. He reports that he has no interest in hurting himself or others. His blood pressure is 119/81 mm Hg, pulse rate is 85/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and the temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F). His physical exam is normal. What other symptom is most likely present in this patient?
A) Leaden paralysis
B) Depressive symptoms that are worse in the morning
C) Psychotic features
D) Stereotypies
E) Mania
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care provider after feeling <fact2>sad and depressed</fact2> for the past several months. His wife divorced him about <fact3>6 months ago</fact3> and took the kids and moved out of state. Since then he has had difficulty <fact4>waking up in the morning</fact4> and getting to work on time. He takes some comfort in food and has gained about <fact5>9.1 kg (20 lb)</fact5>. He eats out several times a week and sometimes consumes <fact6>2 whole meals in one sitting</fact6>. Other than this new obsession with eating large quantities of food and excess sleeping he no longer enjoys doing things he liked doing in the past. Besides eating and sleeping he is always excited to see his children and looks forward to their visits. He says it's the one thing keeping him going. Additionally, he does not feel like he has the same <fact7>drive or focus at work</fact7>. He reports that he has no interest in hurting himself or others. His <fact8>blood pressure is 119/81 mm Hg</fact8>, <fact9>pulse rate is 85/min</fact9>, <fact10>respiratory rate is 12/min</fact10>, and the <fact11>temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F)</fact11>. His physical exam is normal. What other symptom is most likely present in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, particularly his <fact2>sad and depressed</fact2> state, difficulty <fact4>waking up in the morning</fact4>, and lack of <fact7>drive or focus at work</fact7>, along with his physical exam being normal, suggests that he is experiencing a depressive episode. The fact that his depressive symptoms are not specified to be worse at any particular time of day except for difficulty waking up in the morning does not exclude the possibility of symptoms varying throughout the day, but it does indicate morning-related disturbances. However, among the provided options, the one that aligns most closely with the described symptoms and the typical presentation of depression, especially considering the emphasis on morning difficulties and changes in appetite or sleep, would be depressive symptoms that could vary throughout the day but are often worse in the morning due to the mentioned difficulty waking up and starting the day. The correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty discarding items in her home. She says that the accumulation of things in her kitchen and dining room makes regular use of these spaces incredibly difficult. Her behavior started when she was in high school. She feels anxious when she tries to discard her possessions and her husband tries to clean and organize the home. This behavior frustrates her because most of the items she saves have little emotional or monetary value. She reports that there has been no improvement despite attending cognitive behavioral therapy sessions for the past 6 months. She now feels that her behavior is “taking over” her life. She does not drink, smoke, or use illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/80 mm Hg. On mental status examination, she is calm, alert, and oriented to person, place, and time. Her mood is depressed; her speech is organized, logical, and coherent; and there are no psychotic symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Atomoxetine
B) Fluoxetine
C) Lamotrigine
D) Buspirone
E) Methylphenidate
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>36-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>difficulty discarding items in her home</fact2>. She says that the <fact3>accumulation of things in her kitchen and dining room makes regular use of these spaces incredibly difficult</fact3>. Her behavior started when she was in high school. She feels <fact4>anxious when she tries to discard her possessions</fact4> and her husband tries to clean and organize the home. This behavior frustrates her because most of the items she saves have <fact5>little emotional or monetary value</fact5>. She reports that there has been <fact6>no improvement despite attending cognitive behavioral therapy sessions for the past 6 months</fact6>. She now feels that her behavior is “taking over” her life. She does not drink, smoke, or use illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her <fact7>temperature is 36°C (96.8°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 90/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 12/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 116/80 mm Hg</fact10>. On mental status examination, she is <fact11>calm, alert, and oriented to person, place, and time</fact11>. Her <fact12>mood is depressed</fact12>; her <fact13>speech is organized, logical, and coherent</fact13>; and there are <fact14>no psychotic symptoms</fact14>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>36-year-old woman's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>difficulty discarding items in her home</fact2> and <fact3>accumulation of things in her kitchen and dining room making regular use of these spaces incredibly difficult</fact3>, along with feeling <fact4>anxious when trying to discard her possessions</fact4> despite them having <fact5>little emotional or monetary value</fact5>, it is suggestive of Hoarding Disorder. Given that there has been <fact6>no improvement despite attending cognitive behavioral therapy sessions for the past 6 months</fact6>, and her <fact12>mood is depressed</fact12>, the most appropriate next step in management would be to consider pharmacological treatment options for both the hoarding disorder and depression. Among the provided options, Fluoxetine, an SSRI, is commonly used to treat both depression and anxiety disorders, including hoarding disorder. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 78-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with weight loss, abdominal pain, and jaundice. CT demonstrates a mass in the head of the pancreas, and biopsy is planned for the following day. The patient's daughter approaches you outside the room to request that the results of the biopsy not be shared with the patient. She asks that the results instead be shared with her and her brother, who is the patient's documented health care proxy. She explains that she and her brother have discussed the situation and decided that it is best to not inform the patient that she has cancer. Endoscopic ultrasound-guided biopsy the next morning confirms the diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the best response to the patient's daughter's request?
A) Ask the patient's son, the documented health care proxy, how he would like to handle the situation
B) Inquire why the patient's daughter feels her mother should not be informed of the diagnosis
C) Offer to explain the diagnosis to the patient without using the word "cancer"
D) Order an ethics consult to determine how to address the situation
E) Tell the patient's daughter that the patient must be informed of the diagnosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>78-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the emergency department with <fact2>weight loss, abdominal pain, and jaundice</fact2>. CT demonstrates a <fact3>mass in the head of the pancreas</fact3>, and <fact4>biopsy is planned for the following day</fact4>. The patient's daughter approaches you outside the room to request that the <fact5>results of the biopsy not be shared with the patient</fact5>. She asks that the results instead be shared with her and her brother, who is the patient's <fact6>documented health care proxy</fact6>. She explains that she and her brother have discussed the situation and decided that it is best to not inform the patient that she has <fact7>cancer</fact7>. <fact8>Endoscopic ultrasound-guided biopsy the next morning confirms the diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma</fact8>. Which of the following is the best response to the patient's daughter's request?

Answer: 
Considering the situation, the patient's daughter has requested that the <fact5>results of the biopsy not be shared with the patient</fact5> but instead be shared with her and the patient's <fact6>documented health care proxy</fact6>, her brother. However, it is essential to respect the patient's autonomy and right to informed consent. The best course of action is to involve the patient's <fact6>documented health care proxy</fact6> in the decision-making process. Therefore, the most appropriate response is to ask the patient's son, the <fact6>documented health care proxy</fact6>, how he would like to handle the situation, especially given the confirmed diagnosis of <fact8>pancreatic adenocarcinoma</fact8>. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious. He was at a college party exhibiting belligerent behavior when he suddenly passed out and fell to the ground. His past medical history is not known. His temperature is 100°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 107/48 mmHg, pulse is 125/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is covered with emesis and responds incoherently to questions. As the patient begins to wake up he continues vomiting. The patient is started on IV fluids, analgesics, and anti-emetics and begins to feel better. Thirty minutes later the patient presents with muscle rigidity and is no longer responding coherently to questions. His temperature is 103°F (39.4°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 125/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient's basic laboratory studies are drawn and he is started on IV fluids, given lorazepam, and placed under a cooling blanket. Despite these initial measures, his symptoms persist. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Acetaminophen
B) Dantrolene
C) Diazepam
D) Intubation
E) Supportive therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious. He was at a college party exhibiting <fact2>belligerent behavior</fact2> when he suddenly passed out and fell to the ground. His past medical history is not known. His <fact3>temperature is 100°F (37.8°C)</fact3>, <fact4>blood pressure is 107/48 mmHg</fact4>, <fact5>pulse is 125/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations are 19/min</fact6>, and <fact7>oxygen saturation is 99% on room air</fact7>. The patient is covered with <fact8>emesis</fact8> and responds incoherently to questions. As the patient begins to wake up he continues <fact9>vomiting</fact9>. The patient is started on <fact10>IV fluids, analgesics, and anti-emetics</fact10> and begins to feel better. Thirty minutes later the patient presents with <fact11>muscle rigidity</fact11> and is no longer responding coherently to questions. His <fact12>temperature is 103°F (39.4°C)</fact12>, <fact13>blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg</fact13>, <fact14>pulse is 125/min</fact14>, <fact15>respirations are 18/min</fact15>, and <fact16>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact16>. The patient's basic laboratory studies are drawn and he is started on <fact17>IV fluids, given lorazepam, and placed under a cooling blanket</fact17>. Despite these initial measures, his symptoms persist. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact11>muscle rigidity</fact11> and rising <fact12>temperature of 103°F (39.4°C)</fact12> despite initial treatment with <fact17>IV fluids, lorazepam, and a cooling blanket</fact17>, the clinical presentation is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia or serotonin syndrome, but given the context (party, <fact2>belligerent behavior</fact2>), serotonin syndrome might be more likely. However, the key detail here is <fact11>muscle rigidity</fact11>, which is a hallmark of malignant hyperthermia but can also be seen in serotonin syndrome. Given the initial <fact8>emesis</fact8> and <fact9>vomiting</fact9>, which could indicate ingestion of something harmful, and considering standard treatments for serotonin syndrome and malignant hyperthermia, the most appropriate next step would be administering a medication that directly addresses these conditions. Dantrolene is used for malignant hyperthermia, and its use in serotonin syndrome is also considered in severe cases with significant muscle rigidity. Therefore, the best next step in management is {B}.

question:
A 65-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of repeated falls, postural dizziness, progressive fatigue, generalized weakness and a 13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss. He is a vegetarian. The patient’s family says that he had been high functioning but has had significant behavioral changes over the past year. The patient denies any smoking history, alcohol consumption, or illicit drug use. No significant family history. His vital signs include: blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg without postural changes, pulse 92/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉). Physical examination reveals a poorly groomed, disheveled, thin man. He is irritable, paranoid, and delusional but denies any hallucinations. An unstable, wide-based ataxic gait is noted. Laboratory results are significant for the following:
Hb 6.1 g/dL
MCV 109 fL
Platelets 90,0000/mm3
Total count 3,000/mm3
Reticulocyte count 0.8%
A peripheral blood smear demonstrates hypersegmented neutrophils. Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
 
A) Hypothyroidism
B) Folate deficiency
C) Vitamin B12 deficiency
D) Parvovirus infection
E) Pernicious anemia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>65-year-old man</fact1> presents with a <fact2>6-month history of repeated falls, postural dizziness, progressive fatigue, generalized weakness and a 13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss</fact2>. He is a <fact3>vegetarian</fact3>. The patient’s family says that he had been high functioning but has had significant <fact4>behavioral changes over the past year</fact4>. The patient denies any smoking history, alcohol consumption, or illicit drug use. No significant family history. His vital signs include: <fact5>blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg without postural changes</fact5>, <fact6>pulse 92/min</fact6>, <fact7>respiratory rate 16/min</fact7>, <fact8>temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉)</fact8>. Physical examination reveals a poorly groomed, disheveled, thin man. He is <fact9>irritable, paranoid, and delusional but denies any hallucinations</fact9>. An <fact10>unstable, wide-based ataxic gait</fact10> is noted. Laboratory results are significant for the following: <fact11>Hb 6.1 g/dL</fact11>, <fact12>MCV 109 fL</fact12>, <fact13>Platelets 90,0000/mm3</fact13>, <fact14>Total count 3,000/mm3</fact14>, <fact15>Reticulocyte count 0.8%</fact15>. A peripheral blood smear demonstrates <fact16>hypersegmented neutrophils</fact16>. <fact17>Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are negative</fact17>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>6-month history of repeated falls, postural dizziness, progressive fatigue, generalized weakness and a 13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss</fact2>, along with <fact4>behavioral changes over the past year</fact4> and being a <fact3>vegetarian</fact3>, it is essential to evaluate for potential nutritional deficiencies. The laboratory results show a <fact11>low Hb of 6.1 g/dL</fact11> with a <fact12>high MCV of 109 fL</fact12>, indicating a macrocytic anemia. The presence of <fact16>hypersegmented neutrophils</fact16> on the peripheral blood smear further supports this diagnosis. Given the patient's dietary preferences and the absence of <fact17>anti-intrinsic factor antibodies</fact17>, which rules out pernicious anemia, the most likely cause of this patient's condition is a deficiency in either vitamin B12 or folate. However, considering the neurological symptoms such as <fact9>irritability, paranoia, and delusions</fact9> and the <fact10>unstable, wide-based ataxic gait</fact10>, which are more commonly associated with vitamin B12 deficiency, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency room with chest pain. He developed severe, crushing, substernal chest pain 10 hours ago while he was hiking in the Adirondack mountains. He was with 2 friends at the time who gave him aspirin before carrying him 5 miles to a town to get phone service, where they then called emergency medical services. His past medical history is notable for hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. He takes enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history and is an avid hiker. His temperature is 100°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 28/min. He is diaphoretic and intermittently conscious. Bilateral rales are heard on pulmonary auscultation. An electrocardiogram demonstrates ST elevations in leads I and aVL. Despite appropriate management, the patient expires. An autopsy is performed demonstrating ischemia in the left atrium and posterior left ventricle. Which of the following vessels was most likely affected in this patient?
A) Left anterior descending artery
B) Left circumflex artery
C) Left coronary artery
D) Posterior descending artery
E) Right marginal artery
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>61-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency room with <fact2>chest pain</fact2>. He developed severe, crushing, substernal <fact2>chest pain</fact2> <fact3>10 hours ago</fact3> while he was hiking in the Adirondack mountains. He was with 2 friends at the time who gave him <fact4>aspirin</fact4> before carrying him 5 miles to a town to get phone service, where they then called emergency medical services. His past medical history is notable for <fact5>hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia</fact5>. He takes <fact6>enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin</fact6>. He has a <fact7>20-pack-year smoking history</fact7> and is an avid hiker. His <fact8>temperature is 100°F (37.8°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 130/min</fact10>, and <fact11>respirations are 28/min</fact11>. He is <fact12>diaphoretic and intermittently conscious</fact12>. Bilateral <fact13>rales are heard on pulmonary auscultation</fact13>. An <fact14>electrocardiogram demonstrates ST elevations in leads I and aVL</fact14>. Despite appropriate management, the patient expires. An <fact15>autopsy is performed demonstrating ischemia in the left atrium and posterior left ventricle</fact15>. Which of the following vessels was most likely affected in this patient?

A) Left anterior descending artery
B) Left circumflex artery
C) Left coronary artery
D) Posterior descending artery
E) Right marginal artery

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>chest pain</fact2> and the results of the <fact14>electrocardiogram demonstrating ST elevations in leads I and aVL</fact14>, along with the findings of the <fact15>autopsy demonstrating ischemia in the left atrium and posterior left ventricle</fact15>, it is likely that the affected vessel supplies blood to these areas. The left circumflex artery typically supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle, as well as the left atrium. Therefore, the vessel most likely affected in this patient is the left circumflex artery, option {B}.

question:
A 26-year-old Caucasian woman is admitted to the emergency department after 4 days of fever, malaise, vomiting, and nausea for which she has been taking ibuprofen and diclofenac. She has also noticed a decrease in urination. Her family and past medical history are unremarkable. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg, heart rate is 74/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Upon physical examination, her mucous membranes are moist and she has no abdominal tenderness. Four hours after admission, she has a urinary output < 0.3 mL/kg/h and laboratory tests significant for the following:
Differential blood count
White blood cells 8.1 x 109/L
Neutrophils 4.8 x 109/L
Lymphocytes 2.1 x 109/L
Eosinophils 0.9 x 109/L
Monocytes 0.3 x 109/L
Basophils 0.04 x 109/L
  Serum creatinine (SCr) 1.9 mg/dL
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 25 mg/dL
Na+ 135 mEq/L
K+ 5.4 mEq/L
Cl- 106 mEq/L
Urine dipstick
Urine density 1.010
pH 6.2
Red blood cells per field of high power 2
WBC casts Present
Which of the following skin manifestations would you also expect to find in this patient?
A) Livedo reticularis
B) Janeway lesions
C) Diffuse maculopapular rash
D) Malar rash
E) Erythema nodosum
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>26-year-old Caucasian woman</fact1> is admitted to the emergency department after <fact2>4 days of fever, malaise, vomiting, and nausea</fact2> for which she has been taking <fact3>ibuprofen and diclofenac</fact3>. She has also noticed a <fact4>decrease in urination</fact4>. Her <fact5>family and past medical history are unremarkable</fact5>. Upon physical examination, her <fact10>mucous membranes are moist</fact10> and she has <fact11>no abdominal tenderness</fact11>. Four hours after admission, she has a <fact12>urinary output < 0.3 mL/kg/h</fact12> and laboratory tests significant for the following:
Differential blood count
<fact13>White blood cells 8.1 x 109/L</fact13>
<fact14>Neutrophils 4.8 x 109/L</fact14>
<fact15>Lymphocytes 2.1 x 109/L</fact15>
<fact16>Eosinophils 0.9 x 109/L</fact16>
<fact17>Monocytes 0.3 x 109/L</fact17>
<fact18>Basophils 0.04 x 109/L</fact18>
  <fact19>Serum creatinine (SCr) 1.9 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 25 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Na+ 135 mEq/L</fact21>
<fact22>K+ 5.4 mEq/L</fact22>
<fact23>Cl- 106 mEq/L</fact23>
Urine dipstick
<fact24>Urine density 1.010</fact24>
<fact25>pH 6.2</fact25>
<fact26>Red blood cells per field of high power 2</fact26>
<fact27>WBC casts Present</fact27>
Which of the following skin manifestations would you also expect to find in this patient?
A) Livedo reticularis
B) Janeway lesions
C) Diffuse maculopapular rash
D) Malar rash
E) Erythema nodosum

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation with <fact2>4 days of fever, malaise, vomiting, and nausea</fact2>, along with a <fact4>decrease in urination</fact4> and laboratory findings indicating acute kidney injury (<fact19>Serum creatinine (SCr) 1.9 mg/dL</fact19>), the presence of <fact26>Red blood cells per field of high power 2</fact26> and <fact27>WBC casts</fact27> in the urine suggests an inflammatory process affecting the kidneys. The use of <fact3>ibuprofen and diclofenac</fact3> points towards a possible drug-induced cause. Considering these factors, a skin manifestation that could be associated with this condition is a <fact28>diffuse maculopapular rash</fact28>, which is often seen in allergic interstitial nephritis, a condition that can be caused by NSAIDs like ibuprofen and diclofenac. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A group of researchers decided to explore whether the estimates of incidence and prevalence rates of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) were influenced by the number of years it took to examine administrative data. These estimates were not only based on hospital discharges, but also on physician billing codes. For study purposes, the researchers labeled incident cases at the initial occurrence of SLE diagnosis in the hospital database, while prevalent cases were those that were coded as harboring SLE at any time, with patients maintaining their diagnosis until death. Which statement is true regarding the relationship between incidence and prevalence rates during the time period that might be chosen for this specific study?
A) Examining successively longer time periods will result in substantially lower prevalence estimates.
B) Incidence rates will be higher during shorter time periods than longer periods.
C) The prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated.
D) The inclusion of attack rates would increase incidence estimates in longer time periods.
E) The inclusion of attack rates would decrease incidence estimates in shorter time periods.
answer:
Reformatted Question: A group of researchers decided to explore whether the estimates of <fact1>incidence and prevalence rates</fact1> of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) were influenced by the <fact2>number of years it took to examine administrative data</fact2>. These estimates were not only based on <fact3>hospital discharges</fact3>, but also on <fact4>physician billing codes</fact4>. For study purposes, the researchers labeled <fact5>incident cases</fact5> at the initial occurrence of SLE diagnosis in the hospital database, while <fact6>prevalent cases</fact6> were those that were coded as harboring SLE at any time, with patients maintaining their diagnosis until death. Which statement is true regarding the relationship between <fact1>incidence and prevalence rates</fact1> during the time period that might be chosen for this specific study?

Answer: Considering the definitions provided in the study, <fact5>incident cases</fact5> are those that are newly diagnosed, while <fact6>prevalent cases</fact6> include both new and existing cases. As the <fact2>number of years it took to examine administrative data</fact2> increases, more existing cases are likely to be captured, leading to higher <fact6>prevalence rates</fact6>. Conversely, the rate of new cases (<fact5>incidence rate</fact5>) is less likely to be affected by the duration of the study period, as it only counts new occurrences. Therefore, examining successively longer time periods will likely result in higher prevalence estimates due to the accumulation of existing cases, but the incidence rate should remain relatively stable. Among the options provided, choice C suggests that the prevalence of SLE during consecutively shorter time windows will be overestimated, which is incorrect based on the reasoning above. However, none of the options directly state the correct relationship as described. The closest correct interpretation based on the given options and the context provided would be that none of the statements accurately describe the relationship in the context given, but based on typical epidemiological principles, we can infer a correct relationship: The prevalence of SLE during consecutively longer time windows will be higher due to the accumulation of cases over time, which contradicts the statements provided.

question:
A 62-year-old man presents with bright red blood in his stool which occurred 2 times this week. He denies fever, weight loss, pain, pruritus or urinary symptoms. Past medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease, and recent appendicitis, status post laparoscopic appendectomy complicated by delirium tremens. His vitals are a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg, pulse of 78/min, and respiratory rate of 12/min. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with shifting dullness on percussion. In addition, multiple purple spider web-like lesions are present on the chest and arms, which blanch when pressure is applied. Fecal occult blood test is negative. On anoscopy, a non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion is noted superior to the pectinate line. Which of the following is most likely true about this patient’s current symptoms?
A) This patient has peptic ulcer disease.
B) The vascular protrusion drains into the superior rectal vein.
C) The vascular protrusion drains into the inferior vena cava.
D) The vascular protrusion drains into the inferior rectal vein.
E) Fecal leukocytes and a stool culture are required for diagnosis.
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>bright red blood in his stool</fact2> which occurred 2 times this week. He denies <fact3>fever, weight loss, pain, pruritus or urinary symptoms</fact3>. Past medical history is significant for <fact4>gastroesophageal reflux disease</fact4>, and recent <fact5>appendicitis, status post laparoscopic appendectomy complicated by delirium tremens</fact5>. His vitals are a <fact6>temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse of 78/min</fact8>, and <fact9>respiratory rate of 12/min</fact9>. Physical examination reveals a <fact10>distended abdomen with shifting dullness on percussion</fact10>. In addition, multiple <fact11>purple spider web-like lesions</fact11> are present on the chest and arms, which blanch when pressure is applied. <fact12>Fecal occult blood test is negative</fact12>. On anoscopy, a <fact13>non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion</fact13> is noted superior to the pectinate line. Which of the following is most likely true about this patient’s current symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>bright red blood in his stool</fact2> and the finding of a <fact13>non-tender, dilated vascular protrusion</fact13> superior to the pectinate line on anoscopy, this is indicative of an internal hemorrhoid. Internal hemorrhoids are located above the pectinate line and drain into the superior rectal vein. Therefore, the statement that "The vascular protrusion drains into the superior rectal vein" is most likely true about this patient's current symptoms. The answer is {B}.

question:
A one-day-old male is evaluated in the hospital nursery for bilious vomiting. The patient has urinated multiple times since birth but has not yet passed meconium. He was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 36-year-old gravida 3 via vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes. The patient’s mother received routine prenatal care and declined first trimester screening. She subsequently underwent a quadruple screen at 15 weeks gestation that demonstrated decreased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), increased beta-hCG, decreased unconjugated estriol, and increased inhibin A. Her last ultrasound prior to onset of labor demonstrated an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 28 cm. The patient’s two older siblings are both healthy. The patient’s temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 58/37 mmHg, pulse is 166/min, and respirations are 38/min. On physical exam, the patient is in moderate distress. His abdomen is firm and distended with hypoactive bowel sounds.

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this fetus’s presentation?
A) Duodenal atresia
B) Intestinal malrotation
C) Meconium ileus
D) Necrotizing enterocolitis
E) Pyloric stenosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>one-day-old male</fact1> is evaluated in the hospital nursery for <fact2>bilious vomiting</fact2>. The patient has urinated multiple times since birth but has not yet passed <fact3>meconium</fact3>. He was born at <fact4>38 weeks gestation</fact4> to a <fact5>36-year-old gravida 3</fact5> via vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was complicated by <fact6>gestational diabetes</fact6>. The patient’s mother received routine prenatal care and declined first trimester screening. She subsequently underwent a <fact7>quadruple screen at 15 weeks gestation</fact7> that demonstrated <fact8>decreased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)</fact8>, <fact9>increased beta-hCG</fact9>, <fact10>decreased unconjugated estriol</fact10>, and <fact11>increased inhibin A</fact11>. Her last ultrasound prior to onset of labor demonstrated an <fact12>amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 28 cm</fact12>. The patient’s two older siblings are both healthy. The patient’s <fact13>temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C)</fact13>, <fact14>blood pressure is 58/37 mmHg</fact14>, <fact15>pulse is 166/min</fact15>, and <fact16>respirations are 38/min</fact16>. On physical exam, the patient is in moderate distress. His abdomen is firm and distended with hypoactive bowel sounds.

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this fetus’s presentation?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>one-day-old male</fact1> with <fact2>bilious vomiting</fact2> and failure to pass <fact3>meconium</fact3>, along with the findings of a firm and distended abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds, suggests an intestinal obstruction. The <fact7>quadruple screen at 15 weeks gestation</fact7> results showing <fact8>decreased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)</fact8> and <fact9>increased beta-hCG</fact9> are associated with an increased risk of Down syndrome, which has a higher incidence of duodenal atresia. Additionally, the presence of <fact2>bilious vomiting</fact2> indicates that the obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater, consistent with duodenal atresia. Therefore, the most likely etiology of this fetus’s presentation is {A}.

question:
A 41-year-old man presents to the emergency room with sudden onset of blurry vision one hour ago. He states that he was resting at home when he noticed he had difficulty reading. Currently, he is also starting to see double, and is seeing two images on top of each other. Earlier today, he felt ill with nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea, which he attributed to food he had eaten at a picnic the day before. When asked which foods he ate, he lists potato salad, a hamburger, deviled eggs, and pickles made by his neighbor. He also heard that his friend who went to the picnic with him has developed similar symptoms and was seen in another hospital earlier. While in the emergency room, the patient’s temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg, and respirations are 13/min. Cranial nerve exam is notable for fixed pupillary dilation, and difficulty depressing both eyes. The remainder of his exam is normal. Which of the following is the pathogenesis of this patient’s presentation?
A) Decreased acetylcholine release
B) Overactivation of adenylate cyclase
C) Release of interferon-gamma
D) Degradation of phospholipids
E) Inhibition of GABA release
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>41-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency room with <fact2>sudden onset of blurry vision</fact2> one hour ago. He states that he was resting at home when he noticed he had <fact3>difficulty reading</fact3>. Currently, he is also starting to see double, and is seeing two images on top of each other. Earlier today, he felt ill with <fact4>nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea</fact4>, which he attributed to food he had eaten at a picnic the day before. When asked which foods he ate, he lists <fact5>potato salad, a hamburger, deviled eggs, and pickles made by his neighbor</fact5>. He also heard that his friend who went to the picnic with him has developed similar symptoms and was seen in another hospital earlier. While in the emergency room, the patient’s <fact6>temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C)</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 75/min</fact7>, <fact8>blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg</fact8>, and <fact9>respirations are 13/min</fact9>. <fact10>Cranial nerve exam</fact10> is notable for <fact11>fixed pupillary dilation</fact11>, and <fact12>difficulty depressing both eyes</fact12>. The remainder of his exam is normal. Which of the following is the pathogenesis of this patient’s presentation?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>sudden onset of blurry vision</fact2>, <fact3>difficulty reading</fact3>, and <fact11>fixed pupillary dilation</fact11>, along with <fact12>difficulty depressing both eyes</fact12>, it is suggestive of a condition affecting the cranial nerves, specifically those controlling eye movements. The presence of <fact4>nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea</fact4> prior to the onset of visual symptoms, and the fact that a friend who ate the same food developed similar symptoms, points towards a possible foodborne illness. Among the options provided, the pathogenesis that best fits this presentation is the one involving a toxin that can cause such neurological symptoms. Botulism, caused by the toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum, can be transmitted through improperly preserved or canned foods, such as the <fact5>pickles made by his neighbor</fact5>. This toxin works by <fact13>decreasing acetylcholine release</fact13>, leading to the observed symptoms. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being stabbed 12 times in various parts of his body. Paramedics report extensive blood loss at the scene where he was found. Due to his Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3, an endotracheal airway and large-bore access are secured prior to arrival. He is aggressively resuscitated with a massive transfusion protocol as the operating room is prepared for an exploratory laparotomy. An arterial line and central access are obtained. His temperature is 95°F (35°C), blood pressure is 50/40 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min, and respirations are controlled at 20/min on lung-protective volume control. After a 6:6:1 ratio of red blood cells, plasma, and platelets and the use of continuous phenylephrine infusion, the patient's vital signs remain the same. The surgical team reports no active blood loss. A stat ScvO2 results as 39% with a SaO2 of 100% on 100% oxygen. His extremities remain cold despite having the ambient room temperature increased to 80°F (26.7°C). What is the most likely cause of his presentation?
A) Cardiac tamponade
B) Cervical spinal cord transection
C) Occult hemorrhage
D) Pulmonary embolism
E) Undiagnosed pneumonia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency department after being <fact2>stabbed 12 times</fact2> in various parts of his body. Paramedics report <fact3>extensive blood loss</fact3> at the scene where he was found. Due to his <fact4>Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3</fact4>, an endotracheal airway and large-bore access are secured prior to arrival. He is aggressively resuscitated with a <fact5>massive transfusion protocol</fact5> as the operating room is prepared for an exploratory laparotomy. An arterial line and central access are obtained. His <fact6>temperature is 95°F (35°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 50/40 mmHg</fact7>, and <fact8>pulse is 80/min</fact8>, and respirations are controlled at 20/min on lung-protective volume control. After a <fact9>6:6:1 ratio of red blood cells, plasma, and platelets</fact9> and the use of continuous phenylephrine infusion, the patient's vital signs remain the same. The surgical team reports <fact10>no active blood loss</fact10>. A stat <fact11>ScvO2 results as 39%</fact11> with a <fact12>SaO2 of 100%</fact12> on 100% oxygen. His <fact13>extremities remain cold</fact13> despite having the ambient room temperature increased to 80°F (26.7°C). What is the most likely cause of his presentation?

Answer: 
Given the patient's <fact1>45-year-old man</fact1> presentation with <fact2>stabbed 12 times</fact2> and <fact3>extensive blood loss</fact3>, the initial suspicion would be hemorrhagic shock. However, despite <fact5>massive transfusion protocol</fact5> and <fact9>6:6:1 ratio of red blood cells, plasma, and platelets</fact9>, his vital signs, including <fact7>blood pressure</fact7> and <fact8>pulse</fact8>, have not improved. Additionally, the surgical team reports <fact10>no active blood loss</fact10>, which makes ongoing hemorrhage less likely. The low <fact11>ScvO2 of 39%</fact11> despite a <fact12>SaO2 of 100%</fact12> on 100% oxygen suggests inadequate oxygen extraction or utilization at the tissue level. The patient's <fact13>extremities remain cold</fact13>, indicating poor perfusion. Considering these factors, the most likely cause of his presentation is cardiac tamponade, which would impede cardiac output and lead to inadequate tissue perfusion without necessarily causing overt signs of hemorrhage. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 72-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a 6-month history of shortness of breath. He says that he used to enjoy playing golf with his friends but now he cannot walk for long enough to play. The shortness of breath is now starting to complicate his ability to get around in daily life. His past medical history is significant for diabetes, hypertension, and early stage prostate cancer that was removed 10 years ago without recurrence. He has smoked 1 pack per day for the past 55 years and drinks about 6 drinks per week. On presentation he is found to be breathing with pursed lips. Physical exam reveals decreased breath sounds on auscultation, increased chest diameter, and hyperresonance to percussion. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen in this patient?
A) Decreased residual volume and decreased 1 second forced expiratory volume
B) Decreased residual volume and increased 1 second forced expiratory volume
C) Increased residual volume and decreased 1 second forced expiratory volume
D) Increased residual volume and increased 1 second forced expiratory volume
E) Normal residual volume and decreased 1 second forced expiratory volume
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>72-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician with a <fact2>6-month history of shortness of breath</fact2>. He says that he used to enjoy playing golf with his friends but now he cannot walk for long enough to play. The <fact3>shortness of breath</fact3> is now starting to complicate his ability to get around in daily life. His past medical history is significant for <fact4>diabetes, hypertension, and early stage prostate cancer</fact4> that was removed 10 years ago without recurrence. He has <fact5>smoked 1 pack per day for the past 55 years</fact5> and drinks about 6 drinks per week. On presentation he is found to be <fact6>breathing with pursed lips</fact6>. Physical exam reveals <fact7>decreased breath sounds on auscultation, increased chest diameter, and hyperresonance to percussion</fact7>. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>6-month history of shortness of breath</fact2> and <fact3>shortness of breath</fact3> that is now affecting his daily life, along with the physical exam findings of <fact7>decreased breath sounds on auscultation, increased chest diameter, and hyperresonance to percussion</fact7>, it is suggestive of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). The patient's long history of <fact5>smoking 1 pack per day for the past 55 years</fact5> further supports this diagnosis, as smoking is a major risk factor for COPD. Additionally, the observation of the patient <fact6>breathing with pursed lips</fact6> is a classic sign of COPD, indicating an attempt to increase lung volume and improve gas exchange. In COPD, there is typically an increase in residual volume due to air trapping and a decrease in the 1-second forced expiratory volume (FEV1) due to obstruction. Therefore, the most likely finding in this patient would be an increased residual volume and decreased 1-second forced expiratory volume. The answer is {C}.

question:
Three days after admission to the intensive care unit for septic shock and bacteremia from a urinary tract infection, a 34-year-old woman has persistent hypotension. Her blood cultures are positive for Escherichia coli, for which she has been receiving appropriate antibiotics since admission. She has no history of any serious illness. She does not use illicit drugs. Current medications include norepinephrine, ceftriaxone, and acetaminophen. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate is 96/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows costovertebral tenderness bilaterally. Examination of the thyroid gland shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
  Hospital day 1 Hospital day 3
Leukocyte count 18,500/mm3 10,300/mm3
Hemoglobin 14.1 mg/dL 13.4 mg/dL
Serum
Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL 0.9 mg/dL
Fasting glucose 95 mg/dL 100 mg/dL
TSH   1.8 µU/mL
T3, free   0.1 ng/dL
T4, free   0.9 ng/dL
Repeat blood cultures are negative. A chest X-ray shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
A) Bromocriptine
B) Levothyroxine
C) Removing toxic drugs
D) Thiamine therapy
E) Treating the underlying illness
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>34-year-old woman</fact1> has persistent <fact2>hypotension</fact2> three days after admission to the intensive care unit for <fact3>septic shock and bacteremia from a urinary tract infection</fact3>. Her blood cultures are positive for <fact4>Escherichia coli</fact4>, for which she has been receiving <fact5>appropriate antibiotics</fact5> since admission. Current medications include <fact6>norepinephrine, ceftriaxone, and acetaminophen</fact6>. Her <fact7>temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F)</fact7>, <fact8>heart rate is 96/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg</fact9>. Laboratory studies show a decrease in <fact10>leukocyte count from 18,500/mm3 to 10,300/mm3</fact10> and a decrease in <fact11>serum creatinine from 1.4 mg/dL to 0.9 mg/dL</fact11> over three days. Her <fact12>TSH is 1.8 µU/mL</fact12>, <fact13>T3, free is 0.1 ng/dL</fact13>, and <fact14>T4, free is 0.9 ng/dL</fact14>. 

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact1>34-year-old woman</fact1> condition, she is experiencing persistent <fact2>hypotension</fact2> despite receiving <fact5>appropriate antibiotics</fact5> for her <fact3>septic shock and bacteremia from a urinary tract infection</fact3> and her current medications include <fact6>norepinephrine, ceftriaxone, and acetaminophen</fact6>. Her laboratory results show a decrease in <fact10>leukocyte count</fact10> and a decrease in <fact11>serum creatinine</fact11> over three days, indicating an improvement in her infection and renal function. However, her thyroid function tests reveal a low <fact13>T3, free</fact13> level, which is consistent with euthyroid sick syndrome, a condition often seen in critically ill patients. The most appropriate treatment in this case is to focus on <fact15>treating the underlying illness</fact15>, which is her septic shock and its complications. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 25-year-old male involved in a knife fight presents with a penetrating wound to the chest. The patient is unconscious and cannot provide any further history. Vitals show a temperature of 37-0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure of 85/55 mm Hg, pulse of 115/min, respirations of 19/min, and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is diaphoretic and unresponsive. Extremities are pale and cool. There is a 3-inch long penetrating wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space on the left side of the chest, which is bleeding profusely. Transthoracic echocardiography reveals a full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall. There are no apparent injuries to any coronary arteries or major branches. The patient is intubated and aggressive fluid resuscitation is initiated, including a blood transfusion. Which of the following is the best definitive surgical approach to take in this patient?
A) Immediate cardiac transplant
B) Watchful waiting while resuscitative fluids are initiated
C) Interrupted 2-0 polypropylene suture with supporting pledgets
D) Needle thoracostomy over the 2nd intercostal space
E) Surgical adhesive glue
answer:
