A <fact1>25-year-old male</fact1> involved in a knife fight presents with a <fact2>penetrating wound to the chest</fact2>. The patient is unconscious and cannot provide any further history. Vitals show a <fact3>temperature of 37-0°C (98.6°F)</fact3>, <fact4>blood pressure of 85/55 mm Hg</fact4>, <fact5>pulse of 115/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations of 19/min</fact6>, and <fact7>oxygen saturation of 92% on room air</fact7>. On physical examination, the patient is <fact8>diaphoretic and unresponsive</fact8>. Extremities are <fact9>pale and cool</fact9>. There is a <fact10>3-inch long penetrating wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space on the left side of the chest</fact10>, which is <fact11>bleeding profusely</fact11>. <fact12>Transthoracic echocardiography reveals a full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall</fact12>. There are no apparent injuries to any <fact13>coronary arteries or major branches</fact13>. The patient is <fact14>intubated and aggressive fluid resuscitation is initiated, including a blood transfusion</fact14>. Which of the following is the best definitive surgical approach to take in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>penetrating wound to the chest</fact2> with a <fact10>3-inch long penetrating wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space on the left side of the chest</fact10> that is <fact11>bleeding profusely</fact11>, along with the <fact12>transthoracic echocardiography revealing a full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall</fact12>, a prompt and effective surgical intervention is necessary to repair the cardiac injury. Given that there are no apparent injuries to any <fact13>coronary arteries or major branches</fact13>, a direct repair of the ventricular free wall is feasible. Among the provided options, the use of <fact15>interrupted 2-0 polypropylene suture with supporting pledgets</fact15> is a well-established technique for repairing cardiac lacerations, offering a secure and durable closure. Therefore, the best definitive surgical approach for this patient is option {C}.

question:
A 38-year-old man presents with progressive tiredness and shortness of breath on exertion. Past medical history is significant for peptic ulcer disease diagnosed 2 years ago for which he is not compliant with his medications. He reports a 10-pack-year smoking history and occasionally alcohol use. His vital signs include: temperature 37.1°C (98.7°F), blood pressure 142/91 mm Hg, pulse 98/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Hemoglobin 9.7 g/dL
Hematocrit 29.1%
Red cell count 3.7 million/mm3
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 71 μm3
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) 21.3 pg/cell
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) 28.4 Hb/cell
Reticulocyte count 0.2 %
Red cell distribution width (RDW) 17.8 (ref: 11.5–14.5%)
White blood cell count 8100/mm3
Platelet count 420,000/mm3
Iron studies show:
Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) 620 μg/dL
Transferrin saturation 9%
Which of the following findings would most likely be found on a bone marrow biopsy in this patient?
A) Hypocellularity with fatty infiltration
B) ↑ megakaryocytes
C) ↓ hemosiderin stores
D) Ringed sideroblasts
E) Myeloblasts with immature precursors
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>38-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>progressive tiredness and shortness of breath on exertion</fact2>. Past medical history is significant for <fact3>peptic ulcer disease diagnosed 2 years ago</fact3> for which he is not compliant with his medications. He reports a <fact4>10-pack-year smoking history</fact4> and occasionally <fact5>alcohol use</fact5>. His vital signs include: <fact6>temperature 37.1°C (98.7°F)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure 142/91 mm Hg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse 98/min</fact8>. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
<fact9>Hemoglobin 9.7 g/dL</fact9>
<fact10>Hematocrit 29.1%</fact10>
<fact11>Red cell count 3.7 million/mm3</fact11>
<fact12>Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 71 μm3</fact12>
<fact13>Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) 21.3 pg/cell</fact13>
<fact14>Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) 28.4 Hb/cell</fact14>
<fact15>Reticulocyte count 0.2 %</fact15>
<fact16>Red cell distribution width (RDW) 17.8 (ref: 11.5–14.5%)</fact16>
<fact17>White blood cell count 8100/mm3</fact17>
<fact18>Platelet count 420,000/mm3</fact18>
Iron studies show:
<fact19>Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) 620 μg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Transferrin saturation 9%</fact20>
Which of the following findings would most likely be found on a bone marrow biopsy in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>progressive tiredness and shortness of breath on exertion</fact2> along with laboratory findings of <fact9>low hemoglobin</fact9>, <fact10>low hematocrit</fact10>, and <fact11>low red cell count</fact11>, these are indicative of anemia. The <fact12>low MCV</fact12> and <fact13>low MCH</fact13> suggest a microcytic hypochromic anemia. The <fact15>low reticulocyte count</fact15> indicates inadequate bone marrow response to the anemia. The <fact19>high TIBC</fact19> and <fact20>low transferrin saturation</fact20> are characteristic of iron deficiency anemia. Given these findings, the most likely result on a bone marrow biopsy would be a decrease in hemosiderin stores, which reflects the body's iron storage status. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
Ten days after undergoing a cadaveric renal transplant, a 21-year-old man has pain in the right lower abdomen and generalized fatigue. During the past 2 days, he has had decreasing urinary output. He passed 5 liters of urine on the second postoperative day and serum studies showed a creatinine concentration of 2.1 mg/dL. He has adult polycystic kidney disease and was on maintenance hemodialysis for 2 months prior to transplantation. Current medications include azathioprine, cyclosporine, prednisone, and enalapril. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 164/94 mm Hg. Examination shows a healing surgical incision in the right lower abdomen. The graft site shows tenderness to palpation. His blood urea nitrogen concentration is 52 mg/dL, creatinine concentration is 4.1 mg/dL. A biopsy of the transplanted kidney shows tubulitis. C4d staining is negative. Which of the following is the most likely responsible for this patient's findings?
A) Recipient T-cells in the graft
B) Drug-induced nephrotoxicity
C) Fibrosis of the glomerular vessels
D) Polyomavirus-associated nephropathy
E) Newly formed anti-HLA antibodies
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: Ten days after undergoing a <fact1>cadaveric renal transplant</fact1>, a <fact2>21-year-old man</fact2> has <fact3>pain in the right lower abdomen and generalized fatigue</fact3>. During the past <fact4>2 days</fact4>, he has had <fact5>decreasing urinary output</fact5>. He passed <fact6>5 liters of urine on the second postoperative day</fact6> and serum studies showed a <fact7>creatinine concentration of 2.1 mg/dL</fact7>. He has <fact8>adult polycystic kidney disease</fact8> and was on <fact9>maintenance hemodialysis for 2 months prior to transplantation</fact9>. Current medications include <fact10>azathioprine, cyclosporine, prednisone, and enalapril</fact10>. He appears <fact11>lethargic</fact11>. His <fact12>temperature is 37.8°C (100°F)</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 101/min</fact13>, and <fact14>blood pressure is 164/94 mm Hg</fact14>. Examination shows a <fact15>healing surgical incision in the right lower abdomen</fact15>. The <fact16>graft site shows tenderness to palpation</fact16>. His <fact17>blood urea nitrogen concentration is 52 mg/dL, creatinine concentration is 4.1 mg/dL</fact17>. A <fact18>biopsy of the transplanted kidney shows tubulitis</fact18>. <fact19>C4d staining is negative</fact19>. Which of the following is the most likely responsible for this patient's findings?

Answer: The patient's symptoms of <fact3>pain in the right lower abdomen and generalized fatigue</fact3>, along with <fact5>decreasing urinary output</fact5> and elevated <fact17>creatinine concentration of 4.1 mg/dL</fact17>, suggest a graft dysfunction. The <fact18>biopsy of the transplanted kidney shows tubulitis</fact18>, which is a hallmark of acute cellular rejection. The absence of <fact19>C4d staining</fact19> makes antibody-mediated rejection less likely. Given these findings, the most likely cause is an immune response mediated by <fact2>recipient T-cells in the graft</fact2>, which is a common mechanism of acute cellular rejection. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for dysarthria and left-sided facial droop. She is accompanied by her son, who states that the patient had just returned home an hour ago from walking the dog when suddenly the patient stated she felt “strange.” When her son asked her what was wrong, her speech was slurred and her "face looked funny.” The son quickly called an ambulance. The paramedic upon arrival noted that the patient had left-sided facial droop. Her medical history includes asthma and sickle cell disease. She takes hydroxyurea, uses oxycodone as needed for pain, and an albuterol inhaler as needed for shortness of breath. The patient’s temperature is 97°F (36.1°C), blood pressure is 145/72 mmHg, pulse is 93/min, and respirations are 14/min with an oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. On physical examination, a left-sided facial droop is appreciated. She has trouble articulating her words, and her speech is garbled. She is put on 2 L of oxygen by nasal cannula. Labs are obtained and pending. Which of the following therapies is most likely indicated?
A) Alteplase
B) Exchange transfusion
C) Hydralazine
D) Naloxone
E) Warfarin
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>57-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for <fact2>dysarthria and left-sided facial droop</fact2>. She is accompanied by her son, who states that the patient had just returned home an hour ago from walking the dog when suddenly the patient stated she felt “strange.” When her son asked her what was wrong, her <fact3>speech was slurred</fact3> and her "<fact4>face looked funny</fact4>.” The son quickly called an ambulance. The paramedic upon arrival noted that the patient had <fact5>left-sided facial droop</fact5>. Her medical history includes <fact6>asthma</fact6> and <fact7>sickle cell disease</fact7>. She takes <fact8>hydroxyurea</fact8>, uses <fact9>oxycodone as needed for pain</fact9>, and an <fact10>albuterol inhaler as needed for shortness of breath</fact10>. The patient’s <fact11>temperature is 97°F (36.1°C)</fact11>, <fact12>blood pressure is 145/72 mmHg</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 93/min</fact13>, and <fact14>respirations are 14/min</fact14> with an <fact15>oxygen saturation of 96% on room air</fact15>. On physical examination, a <fact16>left-sided facial droop</fact16> is appreciated. She has trouble articulating her words, and her <fact17>speech is garbled</fact17>. She is put on <fact18>2 L of oxygen by nasal cannula</fact18>. Labs are obtained and pending. Which of the following therapies is most likely indicated?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>dysarthria and left-sided facial droop</fact2>, along with <fact3>slurred speech</fact3> and a <fact4>funny-looking face</fact4>, it is clear that she is experiencing a stroke. Given that she has a history of <fact7>sickle cell disease</fact7>, which increases the risk of stroke, and her current presentation, the most appropriate therapy would be aimed at quickly restoring blood flow to the affected area of the brain. Among the options provided, alteplase is a thrombolytic agent used in the treatment of acute ischemic stroke, making it the most likely indicated therapy in this scenario. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 95-year-old woman who is a resident at a long term care facility, got up from her chair, tripped on a rug, and fell on her right knee. She could not get up without assistance and complained of severe pain in her right hip and buttock. The nurse who evaluated her tried to stand her up, but when the patient tried to stand on her right leg, she dropped her left hip and lost her balance. The nurse then recognized that her patient had a foreshortened right leg fixed in the adducted position and a large swelling in her right buttock. At the receiving hospital, the patient was confused and, though she knew her name, she couldn’t remember the date and insists to leave the hospital immediately to see her family. Past medical history includes diabetes, congestive heart failure, and incontinence. She is currently taking metformin, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metoprolol, and oxybutynin. Physical exam confirmed the nurse’s findings. Radiographs proved the presence of a right posterior hip dislocation without fractures. What medication is most likely associated with this patient’s confusion?
A) Metformin
B) Oxybutynin
C) Metoprolol
D) Lisinopril
E) Hydrochlorothiazide
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>95-year-old woman</fact1> who is a resident at a long term care facility, got up from her chair, tripped on a rug, and fell on her right knee. She could not get up without assistance and complained of severe pain in her right hip and buttock. The nurse who evaluated her tried to stand her up, but when the patient tried to stand on her right leg, she dropped her left hip and lost her balance. The nurse then recognized that her patient had a <fact2>foreshortened right leg fixed in the adducted position</fact2> and a large swelling in her right buttock. At the receiving hospital, the patient was <fact3>confused</fact3> and, though she knew her name, she couldn’t remember the date and insists to leave the hospital immediately to see her family. Past medical history includes <fact4>diabetes</fact4>, <fact5>congestive heart failure</fact5>, and <fact6>incontinence</fact6>. She is currently taking <fact7>metformin</fact7>, <fact8>lisinopril</fact8>, <fact9>hydrochlorothiazide</fact9>, <fact10>metoprolol</fact10>, and <fact11>oxybutynin</fact11>. Physical exam confirmed the nurse’s findings. Radiographs proved the presence of a right posterior hip dislocation without fractures. What medication is most likely associated with this patient’s <fact3>confusion</fact3>?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact3>confusion</fact3> and her current medications, the most likely cause is a medication with anticholinergic properties. Among the options provided, <fact11>oxybutynin</fact11> is known for its anticholinergic effects, which can cause confusion, especially in elderly patients. The other medications listed, such as <fact7>metformin</fact7> for <fact4>diabetes</fact4>, <fact8>lisinopril</fact8> and <fact9>hydrochlorothiazide</fact9> for <fact5>congestive heart failure</fact5>, and <fact10>metoprolol</fact10> for heart conditions, are less likely to cause confusion as a primary side effect. Therefore, the medication most likely associated with this patient's <fact3>confusion</fact3> is {B}.

question:
A 1-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents. They are concerned that she becomes lethargic and irritated between meals. They found that feeding her often with small servings helps. She was born at 39 weeks via spontaneous vaginal delivery and is meeting all developmental milestones. Her mother has one brother that occasionally requires blood transfusions. Today, her blood pressure is 55/33 mm Hg, his heart rate is 120/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, and temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the infant is irritated. She is slightly jaundiced. Her heart has a regular rate and rhythm and her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. question:
A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with chest pain. She reports sudden severe and crushing substernal chest pain that started 1 hour ago. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, obesity, and a prior myocardial infarction requiring a coronary artery bypass graft 2 years ago. She takes aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, spironolactone, atorvastatin, and insulin. She is retired and lives a sedentary lifestyle at home. Her temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 109/68 mmHg, pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 24/min. Before being able to start the physical examination, the patient loses consciousness. Her pulse is palpable but weak. Her blood pressure is now 88/50 mmHg and pulse is 130/min. Her skin is pale, cold, and clammy. An electrocardiogram demonstrates ST elevations in leads I, aVL, V3, V4, V5, and V6. A medication that primarily stimulates which of the following receptors would be most appropriate to improve the hemodynamic status of this patient?
A) Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor
B) Alpha-2 adrenergic receptor
C) Beta-1 adrenergic receptor
D) Beta-2 adrenergic receptor
E) D2 receptor
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>68-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the emergency room with <fact2>chest pain</fact2>. She reports <fact3>sudden severe and crushing substernal chest pain</fact3> that started <fact4>1 hour ago</fact4>. Her past medical history is notable for <fact5>hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, obesity, and a prior myocardial infarction requiring a coronary artery bypass graft 2 years ago</fact5>. She takes <fact6>aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, spironolactone, atorvastatin, and insulin</fact6>. She is retired and lives a <fact7>sedentary lifestyle at home</fact7>. Her <fact8>temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 109/68 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 118/min</fact10>, and <fact11>respirations are 24/min</fact11>. Before being able to start the physical examination, the patient <fact12>loses consciousness</fact12>. Her <fact13>pulse is palpable but weak</fact13>. Her <fact14>blood pressure is now 88/50 mmHg</fact14> and <fact15>pulse is 130/min</fact15>. Her <fact16>skin is pale, cold, and clammy</fact16>. An <fact17>electrocardiogram demonstrates ST elevations in leads I, aVL, V3, V4, V5, and V6</fact17>. A medication that primarily stimulates which of the following receptors would be most appropriate to improve the hemodynamic status of this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact3>sudden severe and crushing substernal chest pain</fact3> and <fact17>electrocardiogram demonstrating ST elevations in leads I, aVL, V3, V4, V5, and V6</fact17>, she is experiencing an acute myocardial infarction. Her <fact14>low blood pressure of 88/50 mmHg</fact14> and <fact15>elevated pulse of 130/min</fact15> indicate cardiogenic shock. To improve her hemodynamic status, a medication that increases cardiac contractility and heart rate is necessary. Beta-1 adrenergic receptors primarily stimulate the heart, increasing heart rate and contractility. Therefore, a medication that primarily stimulates Beta-1 adrenergic receptors, such as dobutamine, would be most appropriate. The answer is {C}.

question:
A 24-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of an inability to urinate. She states that this has been one of many symptoms she has experienced lately. At times she has had trouble speaking and has noticed changes in her vision however these episodes occurred over a month ago and have resolved since then. Two days ago she experienced extreme pain in her face that was exacerbated with brushing her teeth and plucking out facial hairs. The patient has no relevant past medical history, however, the patient admits to being sexually abused by her boyfriend for the past year. Her current medications include ibuprofen for menstrual cramps. On physical exam it is noted that leftward gaze results in only the ipsilateral eye gazing leftward. The patient's initial workup is started in the emergency department. Her vital signs are within normal limits and you note a pale and frightened young lady awaiting further care. Which of the following is the best initial test for this patient's chief complaint?
A) Head CT
B) Head MRI
C) Lumbar puncture
D) Post void residual volumes
E) Domestic abuse screening and exploring patient's life stressors
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>24-year-old female</fact1> presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of an <fact2>inability to urinate</fact2>. She states that this has been one of many symptoms she has experienced lately. At times she has had trouble <fact3>speaking and has noticed changes in her vision</fact3> however these episodes occurred over a month ago and have resolved since then. Two days ago she experienced <fact4>extreme pain in her face</fact4> that was exacerbated with <fact5>brushing her teeth and plucking out facial hairs</fact5>. The patient has no relevant past medical history, however, the patient admits to being <fact6>sexually abused by her boyfriend for the past year</fact6>. Her current medications include ibuprofen for menstrual cramps. On physical exam it is noted that <fact7>leftward gaze results in only the ipsilateral eye gazing leftward</fact7>. The patient's initial workup is started in the emergency department. Her vital signs are within normal limits and you note a pale and frightened young lady awaiting further care. Which of the following is the best initial test for this patient's chief complaint?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's chief complaint of an <fact2>inability to urinate</fact2> along with other neurological symptoms such as <fact3>trouble speaking and changes in vision</fact3>, and the physical exam finding of <fact7>leftward gaze resulting in only the ipsilateral eye gazing leftward</fact7>, it is crucial to evaluate for potential neurological causes. Given the complexity of the patient's symptoms, including <fact4>extreme pain in her face</fact4> exacerbated by <fact5>brushing her teeth and plucking out facial hairs</fact5>, a comprehensive imaging study is necessary. Among the options provided, a Head MRI is the most appropriate initial test as it can provide detailed images of the brain and spinal cord, helping to identify any underlying neurological conditions that may be causing the patient's symptoms. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of unusual behavior that started 3 hours ago while he was at a party. He has a history of major depressive disorder and seasonal allergies. His mother has a history of anxiety. He drinks 5 beers on the weekends. Current medications include amitriptyline and diphenhydramine. The patient does not respond to questions and repeatedly says, ""The government is following me everywhere."" His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 160/89 mm Hg. He is diaphoretic. He is not oriented to place or time. Neurologic examination shows dilated pupils bilaterally and diffuse hyperreflexia. His feet are cold, and capillary refill time is 3 seconds. After the examination, the patient starts screaming and tries to bite the physician. Urine toxicology screening is positive for ethyl glucuronide. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?"
A) Brief psychotic disorder
B) Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
C) Anticholinergic toxicity
D) Lysergic acid diethylamide intoxication
E) Synthetic cathinone intoxication
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>19-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of <fact2>unusual behavior</fact2> that started <fact3>3 hours ago</fact3> while he was at a party. He has a history of <fact4>major depressive disorder</fact4> and <fact5>seasonal allergies</fact5>. His mother has a history of <fact6>anxiety</fact6>. He drinks <fact7>5 beers on the weekends</fact7>. Current medications include <fact8>amitriptyline</fact8> and <fact9>diphenhydramine</fact9>. The patient does not respond to questions and repeatedly says, ""<fact10>The government is following me everywhere</fact10>."" His <fact11>temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F)</fact11>, <fact12>pulse is 115/min</fact12>, <fact13>respirations are 24/min</fact13>, and <fact14>blood pressure is 160/89 mm Hg</fact14>. He is <fact15>diaphoretic</fact15>. He is not oriented to place or time. Neurologic examination shows <fact16>dilated pupils bilaterally</fact16> and <fact17>diffuse hyperreflexia</fact17>. His <fact18>feet are cold</fact18>, and <fact19>capillary refill time is 3 seconds</fact19>. After the examination, the patient starts <fact20>screaming and tries to bite the physician</fact20>. Urine toxicology screening is positive for <fact21>ethyl glucuronide</fact21>. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>unusual behavior</fact2>, including <fact10>paranoid delusions</fact10> and <fact20>aggression towards the physician</fact20>, along with the presence of <fact16>dilated pupils bilaterally</fact16> and <fact17>diffuse hyperreflexia</fact17>, it is suggestive of an anticholinergic toxidrome. The patient's current medications include <fact8>amitriptyline</fact8> and <fact9>diphenhydramine</fact9>, both of which have anticholinergic properties. The positive urine toxicology screening for <fact21>ethyl glucuronide</fact21> indicates alcohol consumption, but the patient's symptoms are more consistent with anticholinergic toxicity than alcohol intoxication. Therefore, the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms is {C}.

question:
A 30-year-old primigravid woman at 22 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband for lethargy, nausea, and vomiting for 4 days. This morning she became drowsy. She returned from a business trip to Sudan 3 weeks ago. She denies eating any seafood while traveling. Medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Her immunizations are up-to-date and she has never received blood products. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. She is oriented to person and place. Examination shows jaundice and mild asterixis. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 22-week gestation. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL
Prothrombin time 18 sec (INR=2.0)
Serum
Total bilirubin 4.4 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 398 U/L
AST 4,702 U/L
ALT 3,551 U/L
Lactate dehydrogenase 3,412 U/L
Anti-nuclear antibody negative
Anti-smooth muscle antibody negative
Anti-CMV antibody negative
Anti-EBV nuclear antigen antibody negative
An ELISA for HIV is negative. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?"
A) HBsAg
B) Anti-HAV IgG
C) HCV RNA
D) Anti-HCV IgG
E) Anti-HEV IgM
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>30-year-old primigravid woman</fact1> at <fact2>22 weeks' gestation</fact2> is brought to the emergency department by her husband for <fact3>lethargy, nausea, and vomiting for 4 days</fact3>. This morning she became <fact4>drowsy</fact4>. She returned from a <fact5>business trip to Sudan</fact5> 3 weeks ago. She denies eating any <fact6>seafood while traveling</fact6>. Medications include <fact7>iron supplements and a multivitamin</fact7>. Her immunizations are up-to-date and she has never received <fact8>blood products</fact8>. Her <fact9>temperature is 38.9°C (102°F)</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 92/min</fact10>, and <fact11>blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg</fact11>. She is oriented to person and place. Examination shows <fact12>jaundice</fact12> and mild <fact13>asterixis</fact13>. <fact14>Pelvic examination</fact14> shows a uterus consistent in size with a <fact15>22-week gestation</fact15>. Laboratory studies show: 
<fact16>Hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL</fact16> 
<fact17>Prothrombin time 18 sec (INR=2.0)</fact17> 
Serum 
<fact18>Total bilirubin 4.4 mg/dL</fact18> 
<fact19>Alkaline phosphatase 398 U/L</fact19> 
<fact20>AST 4,702 U/L</fact20> 
<fact21>ALT 3,551 U/L</fact21> 
<fact22>Lactate dehydrogenase 3,412 U/L</fact22> 
<fact23>Anti-nuclear antibody negative</fact23> 
<fact24>Anti-smooth muscle antibody negative</fact24> 
<fact25>Anti-CMV antibody negative</fact25> 
<fact26>Anti-EBV nuclear antigen antibody negative</fact26> 
An <fact27>ELISA for HIV is negative</fact27>. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>30-year-old primigravid woman</fact1> at <fact2>22 weeks' gestation</fact2> presenting with <fact3>lethargy, nausea, and vomiting for 4 days</fact3>, followed by becoming <fact4>drowsy</fact4>, and having recently returned from a <fact5>business trip to Sudan</fact5>, a region where hepatitis E is prevalent, her symptoms and laboratory results suggest a diagnosis of hepatitis E. The presence of <fact12>jaundice</fact12> and mild <fact13>asterixis</fact13> on examination, along with significantly elevated liver enzymes (<fact20>AST 4,702 U/L</fact20> and <fact21>ALT 3,551 U/L</fact21>), indicate severe liver dysfunction. Given these factors, the most likely test to confirm the diagnosis is the detection of antibodies against hepatitis E virus, specifically <fact28>Anti-HEV IgM</fact28>, which is indicative of an acute infection. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 38-year-old woman presents to the office for a routine examination. She has no complaints and offers very little information voluntarily. She answers each question with soft, short sentences and avoids eye contact. She appears timid, anxious and admits that this is one of the very few times she has left the house in the last several years. Medical history is significant for essential hypertension. She takes hydrochlorothiazide and a daily vitamin. She has worked from home as a web graphic designer for 20 years. Questions about her social life reveal that she is very shy with few friends, and she often makes excuses to avoid parties and social gatherings. Despite this, she expresses a strong desire to be in a relationship. Today, her blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg, heart rate is 95/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical examination, her heart has a regular rhythm and her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Which of the following is most consistent with her behavior?
A) Body dysmorphic disorder
B) Schizoid personality disorder
C) Avoidant personality disorder
D) Antisocial personality disorder
E) Agoraphobia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the office for a routine examination. She has no complaints and offers very little information voluntarily. She answers each question with <fact2>soft, short sentences and avoids eye contact</fact2>. She appears <fact3>timid, anxious</fact3> and admits that this is one of the very few times she has left the house in the last several years. Medical history is significant for <fact4>essential hypertension</fact4>. She takes hydrochlorothiazide and a daily vitamin. She has worked from home as a <fact5>web graphic designer for 20 years</fact5>. Questions about her social life reveal that she is very <fact6>shy with few friends</fact6>, and she often makes excuses to avoid parties and social gatherings. Despite this, she expresses a <fact7>strong desire to be in a relationship</fact7>. Today, her <fact8>blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg, heart rate is 95/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact8>. On physical examination, her heart has a regular rhythm and her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Which of the following is most consistent with her behavior?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>38-year-old woman's</fact1> behavior, particularly her tendency to answer questions with <fact2>soft, short sentences and avoid eye contact</fact2>, and her <fact3>timid and anxious</fact3> demeanor, it is clear that she struggles with social interactions. Her <fact6>shyness and having few friends</fact6>, along with making excuses to avoid social gatherings, further supports this. However, her expressed <fact7>strong desire to be in a relationship</fact7> indicates that she is not indifferent to social relationships but rather struggles with feelings of inadequacy or fear of rejection. This pattern of behavior is most consistent with Avoidant Personality Disorder, characterized by pervasive feelings of social inadequacy, hypersensitivity to criticism or rejection, and avoidance of social interactions due to fear of criticism or rejection. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 68-year-old man presents with difficulty breathing for the last 3 hours. Upon asking about other symptoms, he mentions that he had a cough for the last 4 months which he attributes to his smoking. He says he had frequent nasal stuffiness and headaches over the last 3 months, for which he takes over-the-counter cold medications and analgesics. Over the last 2 months, he often felt that his face was mildly swollen, especially in the morning hours, but he did not consider it to be anything serious. No significant past medical history. He reports a 20-pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 108/78 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 24/min. On physical examination, auscultation of the chest reveals rhonchi and crepitus over the right lung. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. A chest radiograph reveals a mass in the middle lobe of the right lung. Which of the following clinical signs would most likely be present in this patient?
A) Bilateral pedal edema
B) Distended veins over lower abdomen
C) Papilledema
D) Positive Adson test
E) Sensory loss over the ulnar aspect of right forearm and right hand
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>68-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>difficulty breathing</fact2> for the last 3 hours. Upon asking about other symptoms, he mentions that he had a <fact3>cough for the last 4 months</fact3> which he attributes to his <fact4>smoking</fact4>. He says he had frequent <fact5>nasal stuffiness and headaches</fact5> over the last 3 months, for which he takes over-the-counter cold medications and analgesics. Over the last 2 months, he often felt that his <fact6>face was mildly swollen</fact6>, especially in the morning hours, but he did not consider it to be anything serious. No significant past medical history. He reports a <fact7>20-pack-year smoking history</fact7>. His <fact8>temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 96/min</fact9>, <fact10>blood pressure is 108/78 mm Hg</fact10>, and the <fact11>respiratory rate is 24/min</fact11>. On physical examination, auscultation of the chest reveals <fact12>rhonchi and crepitus over the right lung</fact12>. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. A <fact13>chest radiograph reveals a mass in the middle lobe of the right lung</fact13>. Which of the following clinical signs would most likely be present in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, particularly the <fact6>swelling of the face</fact6> in the morning hours, and the presence of a <fact13>mass in the middle lobe of the right lung</fact13> as shown on the chest radiograph, it is suggestive of superior vena cava syndrome. This condition is often associated with obstruction of the superior vena cava by a tumor, which can cause facial swelling and distension of veins in the upper body. Among the provided options, distended veins over the lower abdomen are less likely to be directly related to this condition. However, considering the typical presentation of superior vena cava syndrome, the most relevant clinical sign that would be expected but is not directly listed is distension of the veins in the upper body, such as the neck and chest. Given the options, the closest sign related to venous obstruction, although not typically associated with superior vena cava syndrome, is bilateral pedal edema, which can occur in various conditions affecting venous return or cardiac function. However, the direct effects of a lung mass causing superior vena cava syndrome would more likely manifest in the upper body. Since none of the options directly describe the expected clinical signs of superior vena cava syndrome (such as distended neck veins), but looking for the closest venous-related sign, the answer is {A}, though it's a less direct consequence and more related to general venous or cardiac issues rather than a specific sign of superior vena cava syndrome which is more likely to present with upper body venous distension.

question:
In order to assess the feasibility and evaluate the outcomes of cerclage wiring as a supportive approach to osteosynthesis in femur fractures, a group of orthopedic surgeons studied 14 patients with primary and periprosthetic fractures of the thigh bone. Parameters such as patient demographic, type of implant, number of wires used, fracture union rate, and potential complications were thoroughly recorded and analyzed in all the patients, with a mean duration of patient follow-up of 16 months. Union was achieved in all patients with a mean duration of 90 days, and there were no complications found in patients included in the study. The authors were satisfied with their findings and, due to the prospective nature of their research, submitted their study to a journal as a cohort study (which they noted in the study title as well). However, the journal editor returned the article, suggesting that it should be submitted as a case series instead. The editor made this suggestion to the authors for which of the following reasons?
A) Lack of a comparison group
B) No prevalence assessment
C) Low number of patients
D) Ascertainment bias
E) Lack of risk calculation
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A group of orthopedic surgeons studied <fact1>14 patients with primary and periprosthetic fractures of the thigh bone</fact1> to assess the feasibility and evaluate the outcomes of cerclage wiring as a supportive approach to osteosynthesis in femur fractures. Parameters such as <fact2>patient demographic, type of implant, number of wires used, fracture union rate, and potential complications</fact2> were thoroughly recorded and analyzed in all the patients, with a <fact3>mean duration of patient follow-up of 16 months</fact3>. Union was achieved in all patients with a <fact4>mean duration of 90 days</fact4>, and there were <fact5>no complications found in patients included in the study</fact5>. The authors were satisfied with their findings and, due to the <fact6>prospective nature of their research</fact6>, submitted their study to a journal as a <fact7>cohort study</fact7> (which they noted in the study title as well). However, the journal editor returned the article, suggesting that it should be submitted as a <fact8>case series instead</fact8>. The editor made this suggestion to the authors for which of the following reasons?

Answer: 
The editor suggested submitting the study as a <fact8>case series instead</fact8> of a <fact7>cohort study</fact7> likely because of the <fact1>low number of patients</fact1> (14 patients) and the lack of a comparison group, which are essential characteristics of a cohort study. A cohort study typically involves a larger sample size and compares outcomes between two or more groups over time. In contrast, a case series is a descriptive study that reports on a series of patients with a particular condition or treatment, often without a comparison group. Although the <fact6>prospective nature of their research</fact6> is a strong aspect of the study, the small sample size and absence of a comparison group make it more suitable as a case series. Therefore, the correct answer is {A} Lack of a comparison group, but the low number of patients (option C) is also a contributing factor.

question:
A 65-year-old woman presents to a physician with painful ankles for 2 days. Her symptoms began 1 week ago with a severe fever (40℃ (104℉)) for 3 days. When the fever subsided, she developed a maculopapular rash over the trunk and extremities with painful wrists and fingers. She also reports abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and headaches. Last week she returned from a trip to Africa where she spent several weeks, mostly in rural areas. Her temperature is 37.5℃ (99.5℉); pulse is 75/min; respiratory rate is 13/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. A maculopapular rash is observed over the trunk and limbs. Both ankles are swollen and painful to active and passive motion. The abdomen is soft without organomegaly. Laboratory studies show the following:
Laboratory test
Hemoglobin 11.4 g/d
Mean corpuscular volume 90 µm3
Leukocyte count 4,500/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 70%
Lymphocytes 15%
Platelet count 250,000/mm3
Ring-form trophozoites are absent on the peripheral blood smear. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s illness?
A) Babesia babesia
B) Chikungunya virus
C) Dengue virus
D) Leishmania major
E) Tropheryma whipplei
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>65-year-old woman</fact1> presents to a physician with <fact2>painful ankles</fact2> for 2 days. Her symptoms began 1 week ago with a <fact3>severe fever (40℃ (104℉))</fact3> for 3 days. When the fever subsided, she developed a <fact4>maculopapular rash</fact4> over the trunk and extremities with <fact5>painful wrists and fingers</fact5>. She also reports <fact6>abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and headaches</fact6>. Last week she returned from a <fact7>trip to Africa</fact7> where she spent several weeks, mostly in rural areas. Her <fact8>temperature is 37.5℃ (99.5℉)</fact8>; <fact9>pulse is 75/min</fact9>; <fact10>respiratory rate is 13/min</fact10>, and <fact11>blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg</fact11>. A <fact12>maculopapular rash</fact12> is observed over the trunk and limbs. Both <fact13>ankles are swollen and painful</fact13> to active and passive motion. The <fact14>abdomen is soft without organomegaly</fact14>. Laboratory studies show the following: 
Laboratory test 
Hemoglobin 11.4 g/d 
Mean corpuscular volume 90 µm3 
Leukocyte count 4,500/mm3 
Segmented neutrophils 70% 
Lymphocytes 15% 
Platelet count 250,000/mm3 
<fact15>Ring-form trophozoites are absent on the peripheral blood smear</fact15>. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s illness? 
A) Babesia babesia 
B) Chikungunya virus 
C) Dengue virus 
D) Leishmania major 
E) Tropheryma whipplei 

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>painful ankles</fact2>, <fact4>maculopapular rash</fact4>, <fact5>painful wrists and fingers</fact5>, and <fact6>abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and headaches</fact6>, along with her recent <fact7>trip to Africa</fact7>, the most likely cause of her illness is an infection common in that region. The absence of <fact15>ring-form trophozoites on the peripheral blood smear</fact15> helps rule out malaria. Among the options provided, Chikungunya virus is known to cause symptoms similar to those described, including severe joint pain and swelling, particularly in the <fact13>ankles</fact13>, along with fever and rash. This virus is also prevalent in Africa, making it a likely candidate given her travel history. Therefore, the answer is {B}.
